444,"<summary>
• VA's mission is to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of veterans by providing medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials.
• The department is the second largest federal department with field offices across the U.S., territories, and the Philippines.
• It operates through three major components: Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and National Cemetery Administration (NCA).
• Collectively, these components rely on approximately 340,000 employees working in various facilities nationwide.
• IT infrastructure is critical to VA's operations, supporting data storage, transmission, and communication needs.
• VA faces challenges with outdated IT systems and modernization efforts.
• Two legacy systems, PAID and BDN, are over 50 years old and need replacement.
• The department has plans to retire these systems by 2017 and 2018, respectively.
• VA's strategic plan emphasizes increasing access to benefits, eliminating claims backlog, and ending veteran homelessness.
• The department's IT budget has been increasing, with $4.3 billion requested for fiscal year 2017.
• VA's IT transformation strategy aims to improve processes and outcomes.
• The CIO's strategy includes establishing five new functions within the Office of Information and Technology (OI&T).
• These functions focus on program management, account management, quality and compliance, data management, and strategic sourcing.
• The transformation is expected to be completed by the first quarter of fiscal year 2017.
• VA health care was designated a high-risk area due to IT challenges, including system interoperability with DOD.
• VA's efforts to modernize and improve IT systems have faced setbacks.
• The outpatient appointment scheduling system modernization failed after spending $127 million over 9 years.
• VA and DOD's joint electronic health record system (iEHR) was abandoned due to cost and schedule concerns.
• VA's VistA modernization effort is ongoing, but the department is reconsidering its approach.
• VBA's VBMS system for processing disability claims has made progress but still faces issues with cost estimation, system availability, and user satisfaction.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
445,"<summary>
* HCFA oversees Medicare, serving 33 million fee-for-service beneficiaries and processing 900 million claims annually.
* Manages over 400 managed care health plans for 5 million beneficiaries.
* Medicare benefits divided into Part A (hospital insurance) and Part B (supplementary medical insurance).
* Part A covered 39 million aged and disabled beneficiaries in 1997.
* Part B requires a monthly premium and covers physician and outpatient services.
* HCFA employs nearly 4,000 full-time employees, with 65% at headquarters.
* Oversees 60 claims processing contractors employing 22,200 people.
* Contractors include Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Mutual of Omaha, and CIGNA.
* Contractors perform Medicare claims processing and review functions.
* HCFA faces challenges with contractor oversight and ensuring accurate payments.
* HIPAA and BBA grant HCFA authority to reform Medicare and combat fraud.
* HIPAA enhances anti-fraud-and-abuse activities with new penalties.
* BBA introduces new health plan options and payment reforms.
* Medicare+Choice program offers PPOs, PSOs, and private fee-for-service plans.
* BBA mandates prospective payment systems for various healthcare services.
* HCFA is modernizing its information systems to address year 2000 issues.
* Plans to repair managed care enrollment systems.
* Modifications to existing systems are interim measures.
* Comprehensive reengineering planned under the Information Technology Management Reform Act.
* Efforts include making claims processing and payment mechanisms more efficient.
* HCFA faces challenges with staff expertise and loss of institutional experience.
* Need for specialized technical expertise in various fields.
* Loss of experienced staff impacts implementation of new payment systems.
* Recruiting and training new employees is time-consuming.
* High turnover rate with 40% of staff changing in the past 5 years.
* HCFA restructured in July 1997 to better focus on its mission.
* Combined activities to redirect resources to managed care.
* Shifted from claims payer to purchaser of healthcare services.
* Established components focused on beneficiaries, health plans, and providers.
* Managers face challenges with new communication and coordination links.
* Managers concerned about resource distribution and specialized expertise.
* ""Robbing Peter to pay Paul"" describes resource allocation issues.
* BBA-related tasks add to workload and impose deadlines.
* Staff reassigned to managed care issues, impacting contractor oversight.
* Concerns",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
446,"<summary>
* FAA is primarily funded by the Trust Fund (82%) and General Fund revenues (18%).
* Trust Fund revenues come from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments.
* The Trust Fund supports FAA’s capital accounts, including AIP and F&E, and part of the Operations account.
* General Fund contributions vary annually based on Trust Fund revenues and FAA expenditures.
* In fiscal year 2006, $2.6 billion was appropriated from the General Fund for FAA operations.
* The administration proposes changing FAA’s financing system to cost-based charges.
* Funding for ATO would come from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation.
* AIP, EAS, and part of RE&D would be funded by equal fuel taxes on all aviation and international passenger taxes.
* Safety and Operations would be funded mostly by General Fund contributions and some fees.
* The proposal includes creating an advisory board and granting FAA limited borrowing authority.
* FAA’s new cost allocation study divides users into high-performance and piston aircraft groups.
* High-performance aircraft require more complex air traffic control resources.
* Piston aircraft operations are less time-sensitive and use less complex equipment.
* Differences in speed and cruising altitudes affect en route costs.
* The study’s methodology is based on the assumption that high-performance users compete for the same resources.
* Concerns about the current funding structure include long-term revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency.
* Revenues depend on ticket prices, which are not linked to FAA’s workload and costs.
* The administration’s proposal aims to link revenues more closely with costs.
* The proposal would eliminate most excise taxes, retaining only fuel and international passenger taxes.
* Direct user charges and fuel taxes would fund ATO, with General Fund contributions for exempt aircraft.
* The proposed funding structure’s effectiveness depends on FAA’s cost allocation method.
* FAA’s cost allocation study has raised concerns and may need further analysis.
* The study did not conduct a statistical cost analysis for different aircraft types.
* Fixed costs are assigned to the primary user group of air traffic control services.
* More time may be needed to reach a consensus on the cost allocation methodology.
* The proposal includes a congestion charge for using terminal airspace near busy airports.
* The charge would not apply to all aircraft flying through the airspace.
* The decision aims to create incentives for general aviation to avoid busy airports.
",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
447,"<summary>

* GSA's Federal Technology Service, in collaboration with the IMC, is responsible for providing federal agencies with necessary telecommunications services through programs like FTS2001 and the upcoming Networx acquisition program.

column2: * GSA awarded contracts to Sprint and MCI WorldCom for FTS2001, and plans to replace these with Networx Universal and Networx Select contracts to ensure continuity, best value, and competition in telecommunications services.

column1: * Significant challenges for the Networx program include ensuring accurate inventory information, defining measures of success, structuring contracts to encourage competition, and planning for a smooth transition from current contracts.

column2: * GSA must address these challenges by establishing clear requirements, performance measures, and effective transition planning to avoid past issues and meet federal agencies' mission needs efficiently.

448,"<summary>
• FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
• Programs include Direct Loan, Guaranteed Loan, Federal Pell Grant, and campus-based programs.
• Annually provides over $50 billion in aid to about 8 million students.
• Oversees approximately $200 billion in outstanding loans for about 100 million borrowers.
• Involves 5,300 schools, 4,100 lenders, and 36 guaranty agencies.
• Congress established FSA as the first Performance-Based Organization (PBO) in October 1998.
• Aimed to improve service, reduce costs, and increase accountability.
• Required the appointment of a Chief Operating Officer (COO) and development of performance plans.
• Allowed for performance bonuses and certain personnel and procurement flexibilities.
• Modeled after the British Next Steps initiative.
• FSA's performance plan includes three strategic goals: increase customer and employee satisfaction, and reduce unit costs.
• Uses American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) and Gallup Q12 to measure satisfaction.
• Developed a unit cost measure to track cost reductions.
• Faces challenges in calculating unit cost consistently across years.
• Needs to improve reporting on systems integration and program integrity.
• FSA has taken steps toward systems integration but needs clearer goals and measures.
• Adopted middleware technology for database integration.
• Performance plans lack clear information on systems integration progress.
• IG recommended an overall systems integration goal.
• COO disagreed, stating strategic goals inherently require systems integration.
• FSA's efforts to enhance program integrity include technical assistance and default management.
• Fiscal year 2002 plan may include a strategic goal for program integrity.
• Relies on technical assistance to schools for compliance.
• Needs better indicators of schools' compliance.
• Limited information on strategies for default management.
• FSA has adopted the balanced scorecard to link team activities with strategic goals.
• Reports on team-specific contributions toward strategic goals.
• Some staff find it difficult to link their work to scorecard results.
• Issues with understanding customer satisfaction and unit cost measures.
• COO and senior managers' bonuses tied to performance agreements.
• FSA's human capital strategy has gaps and needs improvement.
• Reorganized into customer-oriented channels and enterprise units.
• Management Council ensures strategic communication.
• Human capital senior manager not actively involved in strategic direction.
• Needs a",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
449,"<summary>
* NIH made over 21,500 grant awards using Recovery Act funds by the end of fiscal year 2010.

column2: ** * NIH used standard review processes and criteria for awarding these grants, which varied in size, duration, and methods.

column1: * NIH and HHS implemented processes to ensure data quality and reporting on the number of jobs supported by Recovery Act funds.

column2: ** * NIH collects FTE data from www.federalreporting.gov and annual progress reports, and participates in the Star Metrics program to track impacts.

column1: * Principal investigators reported that Recovery Act funding supported new positions, prevented job reductions, and contributed to scientific advancements.

column2: ** * Funding was used for purchasing supplies, equipment, and services, and provided scientific training to healthcare professionals.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
450,"<summary>
* Transit-oriented development (TOD) is generally described as a compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhood near transit stations.

column2: * Typically located up to a half-mile from a transit station.
* Can encompass multiple city blocks with pedestrian-friendly environments.
* Can be found in both urban centers and suburban neighborhoods.
* Aims to increase access to various opportunities and reduce road congestion.

column1: * Key stakeholders in TOD include local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, local governments, private developers, and lenders.

column2: * Local transit agencies build, maintain, and operate transit systems.
* State and local departments develop transportation plans and infrastructure.
* Local governments control land use planning and zoning policies.
* Private developers create and manage housing and commercial developments.

column1: * The Federal Transit Administration (FTA) has expanded its role in TOD by funding research, coordinating with other federal agencies, and implementing a TOD planning pilot program.

column2: * FTA provides grants for advance planning efforts supporting TOD.
* Coordinates with the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Environmental Protection Agency.
* Aims to support environmentally and economically sustainable community development.
* Plans to distribute $19.98 million in grant funding to state and local agencies in 2015.

column1: * Factors supporting TOD include market demand for real estate, availability of large parcels of land, resident support, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers.

column2: * Strong local economies drive market demand for real estate.
* Surface parking lots and underutilized industrial land offer development opportunities.
* Younger residents tend to support TOD due to preferences for amenities and shorter commutes.
* Efficient transit routes connecting residential areas to job centers are crucial.

column1: * Challenges hindering TOD include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance, lengthy local approval processes, unsupportive local populations, and unattractive land around transit stations.

column2: * Mixed-use buildings and parking garages increase construction costs.
* Lenders perceive TOD as riskier due to higher market risks.
* Zoning variances and discretionary entitlement processes add uncertainty.
* Negative perceptions of transit and car culture reduce demand for TOD.

column1: * Local governments can encourage TOD through zoning regulations, area planning, targeted infrastructure investments, and tax incentives.

column2: * Zoning codes that allow higher density and fewer parking spaces facilitate development.
* Area plans provide detailed guidance and resolve contentious issues.
* Investments in multi-modal transportation choices enhance transit attractiveness.
* Tax credits help mitigate environmental clean-up costs on vacant industrial land.

column1: *",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
451,"<summary>
* The Social Security Act of 1935 allows workers to review their earnings records.
* SSA introduced PEBES in 1988 to help workers review earnings and estimate benefits.
* Less than 2% of workers request these statements annually.
* SSA aims to mail PEBES to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000.
* SSA's goals for PEBES include public information, financial planning assistance, and accurate earnings records.
* Accurate records are crucial for benefit eligibility and size.
* Early error correction reduces time and cost for SSA and the public.
* The initiative's projected cost for fiscal year 2000 is $80 million.
* SSA's approach to estimating retirement benefits is generally reasonable.
* Assumes continuous work and stable earnings until retirement.
* Does not account for special circumstances affecting benefits.
* Descriptions of potential benefit variations are included in statements.
* Public reaction to unsolicited PEBES has been favorable.
* Majority of respondents in a 1994 survey were glad to receive statements.
* 95% found the information helpful for their families.
* Older individuals reacted more favorably than younger ones.
* The current PEBES statement is too complex and overwhelming.
* Contains too much information, confusing readers.
* Lacks effective layout and design for easy navigation.
* Important explanations are scattered and not easily accessible.
* SSA has revised the PEBES based on feedback but still faces challenges.
* Applied readability formulas to ensure comprehension at a seventh-grade level.
* Focus groups indicated a preference for simplified forms.
* SSA has not conducted formal comprehension tests.
* SSA's front-line workers provide valuable feedback on public response.
* Current data collection lacks sufficient detail.
* Workers frequently guide callers to answers within the document.
* Detailed feedback could help improve the statement's clarity.
* Experts suggest several design improvements for PEBES.
* Clear purpose and easy-to-read design.
* Simplified explanations of complex information.
* Better organization and use of features like bulleting and highlighting.
* SSA has tested alternative formats but needs further evaluation.
* Canadian model uses a two-part document for clarity.
* SSA's tests showed mixed preferences for single vs. two-part formats.
* Future redesigns should consider cost-effectiveness and user comprehension.
* SSA's senior leadership should prioritize improving PEBES.
* Balance public information needs with simplicity.
* Conduct formal comprehension tests and",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
452,"<summary>
• SSA administers two disability benefit programs, DI and SSI, which use the same definition of disability but differ in purpose and eligibility requirements.
• DI is an insurance program established in 1956, requiring work credits and financed by payroll taxes.
• SSI, established in 1972, provides income for individuals with disabilities or aged individuals with limited income and assets.
• DI benefits are linked to the worker’s earnings history, while SSI benefits are paid from general revenues.
• Concurrent beneficiaries can receive both DI and SSI benefits if they meet eligibility criteria for both programs.
• Work incentive provisions in DI and SSI programs differ significantly, affecting beneficiaries' cash benefits and medical coverage.
• DI beneficiaries have a trial work period where earnings do not affect benefits, but benefits stop if earnings exceed a specified level after this period.
• SSI benefits are reduced gradually by $1 for every $2 earned over the first $65.
• Concurrent beneficiaries must report work activity to SSA, which applies work incentive provisions independently for each program.
• SSA field offices use specialists or generalists to handle DI and SSI cases, but lack integrated guidance for concurrent beneficiaries.
• Concurrent beneficiaries, who make up about 14% of SSA’s disability population, often have mental impairments and are predominantly female.
• They have an average age of 45, with 53% being female.
• About 11% of concurrent beneficiaries work, with a median earned income of $250 per month.
• Most working concurrent beneficiaries have mental impairments, with those having mental retardation working at twice the rate of those with mental illness.
• Concurrent beneficiaries receive an average DI payment of $430 per month and an SSI payment of $150 per month.
• SSA faces challenges in effectively serving concurrent beneficiaries due to complex program rules and lack of integrated guidance.
• Field office staff may not always know when an individual is a concurrent beneficiary or what information to collect.
• There is little coordination between SSI and DI program rules, leading to potential overpayments.
• SSA has created a new position and software to handle work-related issues, but these initiatives are still being tested.
• SSA’s guidance is voluminous and not integrated, making it difficult for staff to serve concurrent beneficiaries effectively.
• SSA’s procedures for adjusting DI benefits when concurrent beneficiaries work are often untimely, leading to overpayments.
• Field offices can adjust SSI benefits immediately but must wait for the trial work period to end to adjust DI benefits.

453,"<summary>
* The Stafford Act authorizes federal assistance during major disasters like Hurricane Katrina.

column2: * FEMA uses the Disaster Relief Fund for relief and recovery efforts.
* Nearly $88 billion was appropriated by Congress for Gulf Coast hurricane relief by June 2006.
* FEMA received $60 billion initially, with other funds allocated to DOD and COE.

column1: * FEMA issues mission assignments to other federal agencies for disaster relief tasks.

column2: * Mission assignments provide budgetary authority, not actual funds transfer.
* Agencies bill FEMA for reimbursement after performing the work.
* FEMA uses the IPAC system for immediate funds transfer upon reimbursement request.

column1: * FEMA's reporting mechanisms are inadequate for tracking and reporting governmentwide hurricane relief funds.

column2: * FEMA lacks mechanisms to collect and report information from other agencies.
* No framework exists to consolidate information from all 23 federal agencies involved.
* Decision makers lack complete data on federal spending for hurricane relief.

column1: * FEMA's reported obligations and expenditures are often inaccurate.

column2: * FEMA records obligations upfront, overstating governmentwide obligations.
* Expenditures are understated due to delayed billing and reimbursement processes.
* Examples show discrepancies between FEMA's reports and actual agency obligations.

column1: * Some federal agencies did not record mission assignments in their internal systems.

column2: * Agencies' financial management offices were not informed of mission assignments.
* Discrepancies were found in obligations recorded by FEMA and agencies.
* Examples include HHS and EPA not recording certain mission assignments.

column1: * FEMA's expenditure data does not accurately reflect federal spending.

column2: * Timing issues cause discrepancies between FEMA's and agencies' expenditure records.
* Agencies recognize expenditures when costs are paid, FEMA upon reimbursement approval.
* Examples include DOD and the U.S. Forest Service showing higher expenditures than FEMA reported.

column1: * FEMA faces challenges with billing documentation and charge-backs.

column2: * Agencies must provide detailed documentation for reimbursement approval.
* FEMA charged back $267 million due to insufficient documentation.
* DOD and other agencies are gathering additional documentation to address charge-backs.

column1: * COE experiences payment delays due to manual billing processes.

column2: * COE does not use the IPAC system, leading to reimbursement delays.
* COE had $1.2 billion in outstanding bills as of February 2006.
* FEMA had not received documentation for $800 million of COE's outstanding bills.

column1: * Recommendations to improve tracking and reporting of hurricane relief funds.

column2: * FEMA should explain discrepancies in reported obligations and expenditures.

column1: 456,"<summary>
* Solar energy technologies include photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.

column2: * * Photovoltaic cells convert sunlight directly into electricity and are used in various applications, including residential, commercial, and space technologies.
* * Concentrated solar power uses mirrors or lenses to focus sunlight and generate electricity through thermal energy conversion processes.

column1: * Federal agencies support solar energy through various initiatives, focusing on different types of technologies and stages of development.

column2: * * In fiscal years 2010 and 2011, six federal agencies (DOD, DOE, EPA, NASA, NSF, and USDA) supported 65 solar-related initiatives.
* * These initiatives ranged from basic research to commercialization, with a significant emphasis on applied research and demonstration activities.

column1: * Funding for solar projects was provided through multiple mechanisms, primarily grants and contracts.

column2: * * DOE obligated around $2.3 billion of the total $2.6 billion for solar projects, with significant funds coming from the Title XVII Section 1705 Loan Guarantee Program.
* * Other agencies also provided funding, but DOE's contributions were the largest by a significant margin.

column1: * Coordination among initiatives is crucial to avoid duplication and enhance effectiveness.

column2: * * Officials from 57 of the 65 initiatives reported engaging in coordination activities with other solar-related initiatives.
* * Coordination practices included establishing joint strategies, leveraging resources, and developing mechanisms to monitor and report results.

column1: * Initiatives often supported multiple types of recipients, including universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal laboratories.

column2: * * DOE’s Solar ADEPT initiative, for example, awarded cooperative agreements to a variety of recipients, including universities and federal labs.
* * NSF’s initiatives primarily supported universities, while DOD’s initiatives often supported industry recipients.

column1: * Some initiatives focused on specific goals, such as integrating solar energy into the grid or developing lightweight, portable energy sources.

column2: * * DOE’s Smart Grid Research and Development initiative aimed to integrate renewable energies into the grid.
* * DOD’s initiatives focused on providing portable energy solutions for military applications.

column1: * Overlapping initiatives did not necessarily lead to duplication due to differences in focus and complementary efforts.

column2: * * For example, the Army and Marine Corps developed different versions of flexible solar substrates for military use.
* * DOE officials noted that multiple federal initiatives might fund different components of a larger project, supporting a common goal without duplicative efforts.

column1: * Agencies reported various coordination activities to avoid duplication and enhance collaboration.

column1: 457,"<summary>
* DOD's current chemical and biological protective equipment is outdated, causing issues such as heat stress, limited movement, and interoperability problems.

column2: * DOD is developing new equipment like the JSLIST suit and improved gloves, boots, and masks, but procurement and inventory management issues persist, leading to inaccurate risk assessments and potential shortages.

column1: * DOD's inventory management systems are fragmented and unreliable, leading to miscounts and difficulty tracking equipment expiration and defects.

column2: * Recommendations include implementing an integrated inventory system, evaluating risk based on complete ensembles, and ceasing the practice of counting undelivered equipment as on hand.

458,"<summary>
* Program evaluations are systematic studies using research methods to assess program performance.

column2: * They supplement performance measurement by isolating causal impacts and assessing effectiveness.
* Evaluations provide feedback for program planning, management, and oversight.

column1: * Federal managers reported limited access to recent evaluations.

column2: * Only about a third had recent evaluations, but those who did found them useful for understanding performance and making improvements.
* Lack of resources was a common barrier to implementing evaluation findings.

column1: * Strategies to facilitate evaluation influence include leadership support, building a strong body of evidence, and stakeholder engagement.

column2: * Leadership support and organizational resources are crucial for conducting and using evaluations.
* Engaging stakeholders throughout the evaluation process enhances relevance and credibility.

column1: * GPRAMA emphasizes the use of evidence in decision making and accountability for results.

column2: * Agencies are required to establish and review priority goals and report progress publicly.
* Performance Improvement Officers (PIOs) play a central role in promoting evaluation use.

column1: * OMB has issued guidance to strengthen the use of rigorous impact evaluation and evidence in decision making.

column2: * Agencies are encouraged to develop evidence and innovation agendas.
* Interagency workgroups and workshops promote sharing of evaluation expertise.

column1: * The Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act and FATAA support federal agency evaluation.

column2: * The Commission recommended appointing Chief Evaluation Officers and developing learning agendas.
* FATAA requires guidelines for monitoring and evaluating federal foreign assistance.

column1: * Surveys in 2013 and 2017 showed no significant change in managers' access to evaluations.

column2: * About 40% of managers reported having recent evaluations, with SES managers having more access.
* Evaluations were credited with improving program management and performance.

column1: * Barriers to evaluation use include lack of resources, stakeholder disagreements, and difficulty distinguishing program results from other factors.

column2: * Lack of resources to implement findings was the most frequently reported barrier.
* Collaboration with stakeholders can help ensure evaluations address relevant issues.

column1: * Recommendations include preparing annual agency-wide evaluation plans and consulting stakeholders.

column2: * OMB should direct agencies to create evaluation plans describing key questions and consulted stakeholders.
* Congressional consultation on evaluation plans could increase credibility and relevance.

459,"<summary>

• The federal government has implemented various initiatives to promote the employment of individuals with disabilities, including special hiring authorities like Schedule A and the POWER Initiative, as well as Executive Order 13548, which mandates federal agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities.

column2: •• Schedule A allows noncompetitive appointments for individuals with intellectual, severe physical, or psychiatric disabilities, and veterans with 30% or more disability.
•• Executive Order 13548 requires agencies to designate a senior-level official accountable for disability hiring goals and to develop and implement hiring plans.
•• The POWER Initiative aims to improve return-to-work outcomes for employees injured on the job by setting performance targets and prioritizing effective safety and health management programs.

column1: • Despite these efforts, challenges remain in achieving the goals of the executive order, including underreporting of disability status due to voluntary disclosure, and the need for more comprehensive training for hiring managers and human resource personnel.

column2: •• OPM found that many agency plans did not meet all criteria, with deficiencies such as lack of numerical goals and senior-level accountability.
•• Training programs for hiring managers and HR personnel are still in development, which may delay the dissemination of best practices and tools for hiring individuals with disabilities.
•• Accurate measurement of disability status is hindered by underreporting, and strategies to encourage voluntary disclosure are needed to improve data reliability.

460,"<summary>
• BLM's mission and ALMRS/Modernization project:

column2: • BLM manages 270 million acres of public lands and 300 million acres of subsurface mineral resources.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project aims to automate land and mineral records, integrate databases, and modernize technology infrastructure.

column1: • Project funding and cost management:

column2: • Initial life-cycle cost estimates for ALMRS/Modernization were reduced from $880 million to $403 million.
• BLM faced funding challenges, leading to delays in hardware installation and the need to reallocate funds from other operations.

column1: • Project progress and challenges:

column2: • BLM has met most milestones but faces tight schedules with little room for delays.
• Independent verification and validation, as well as comprehensive stress testing, are recommended to ensure system performance and reliability.

461,"<summary>
• IAEA's Role and Challenges in Nuclear Safeguards

column2: • IAEA implements safeguards to ensure nuclear materials are not diverted to weapons, using inspections, material accounting, containment, and surveillance.
• Challenges include limited information on non-NPT countries, incomplete adoption of the Additional Protocol, and a looming human capital crisis.

column1: • Efforts and Limitations of the Nuclear Suppliers Group

column2: • The Nuclear Suppliers Group helps curb nuclear proliferation by requiring IAEA safeguards for nuclear exports and controlling dual-use items.
• Limitations include incomplete export licensing information sharing, consensus-based decision-making, and the voluntary, nonbinding nature of membership.

462,"<summary>
* The Year 2000 (Y2K) computing crisis poses a high risk of disrupting critical services in both government and private sectors.

column2: * Financial transactions, flights, power, and national defense could be severely affected.
* Interdependencies among public and private enterprises could cause widespread repercussions from a single failure.
* Key sectors at risk include information and telecommunications, banking and finance, health, safety, emergency services, transportation, power, water, manufacturing, and small business.

column1: * The telecommunications sector is particularly crucial due to its role in various essential operations.

column2: * It enables electronic fund transfers, power distribution, and control of gas and oil pipelines.
* It is vital for the service economy, manufacturing, and delivery of goods.
* It supports emergency services through interconnected networks of carriers, service providers, and equipment manufacturers.

column1: * The global nature of the Y2K problem adds to the risks, with many countries lagging in readiness.

column2: * A World Bank survey found only 14% of countries had a national Y2K program.
* A Gartner Group survey indicated that many countries, including Germany, India, Japan, and Russia, were significantly behind the U.S.
* 23% of companies, mostly small businesses, had not started Y2K efforts.

column1: * The federal government faces significant challenges in addressing Y2K issues due to outdated and poorly documented systems.

column2: * Many systems were designed 20-25 years ago and use obsolete computer languages.
* The government relies on telecommunications for services like Medicare payments, which traverse multiple networks.
* Facilities with embedded systems, such as security and HVAC, could malfunction.

column1: * Progress in fixing federal systems has been slow and uneven across agencies.

column2: * In May 1998, only 40% of mission-critical systems were Y2K compliant.
* Some agencies are significantly behind schedule and at high risk of not meeting the deadline.
* Recommendations include establishing governmentwide priorities, developing contingency plans, and ensuring accurate reporting and testing.

column1: * State and local governments also face major risks of Y2K-induced failures in vital services.

column2: * Surveys indicate that many states have not completed assessments, remediation, and testing of critical systems.
* State audit organizations have identified significant concerns and recommended increased oversight and planning.
* Data exchanges between federal, state, and local governments must be made Y2K compliant to avoid disruptions.

column1: * Leadership and partnerships are essential to mitigate Y2K risks and ensure continuity of services.

column2: * The President's Council",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 463,"<summary>
* IQA consists of two major elements:

column2: * OMB to develop guidelines by end of fiscal year 2001.
* Federal agencies to develop their own guidelines by end of fiscal year 2002.
* Establish mechanisms for ""affected persons"" to seek corrections.
* Periodically report IQA complaints to OMB.

column1: * OIRA's role in IQA implementation:

column2: * Developed governmentwide IQA guidelines.
* Assisted agencies in developing their own guidelines.
* Conducted workshops and issued memorandums for clarity.
* Monitored IQA correction requests and assisted in responses.

column1: * Challenges in accessing IQA information:

column2: * Difficulty locating IQA information on agency websites.
* Lack of clear guidance on web placement of IQA information.
* Agencies working to improve transparency and accessibility.
* OMB aware of the need for better public access.

column1: * Impact of IQA on agencies:

column2: * Agencies do not track IQA-related costs or workloads.
* Addressing IQA requests can take significant time and resources.
* No adverse effects on overall operations reported.
* Agencies incorporate IQA responsibilities into existing roles.

column1: * Recommendations for improving IQA implementation:

column2: * OMB to work with DHS to fulfill IQA requirements.
* Identify and assist other agencies without IQA guidelines.
* Clarify guidance on improving public access to IQA information.
* Enhance public involvement in promoting high-quality information.

464,"<summary>
* Mutual fund companies and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and channel them back into the economy.

column2: * Banks use deposits to make loans or invest in debt securities.
* Mutual funds invest in securities, primarily bonds and stocks.
* The importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining since the 1960s.

column1: * Securitization has reduced the reliance on bank loans for financing.

column2: * Banks and thrifts sell mortgage, credit card, and automobile loans to financial intermediaries.
* These intermediaries use the loans as collateral for marketable securities.
* The securities market becomes the ultimate source of financing.

column1: * The growth of mutual funds has impacted bank deposits.

column2: * Mutual funds have attracted sizable amounts of money that might have been placed in bank deposits.
* At year-end 1994, mutual funds held $2,172 billion compared to $3,462 billion in bank deposits.
* The Federal Reserve and SIA agree that mutual funds have significantly impacted bank deposits.

column1: * The impact of mutual funds on deposits is difficult to quantify.

column2: * Direct withdrawals and diversion of new receipts into mutual funds are factors.
* The ratio of deposits to GDP provides a benchmark for estimating the impact.
* The total impact on deposits from 1990 to 1994 is estimated to be less than $700 billion.

column1: * The movement of money from deposits to mutual funds does not affect the total supply of loanable funds.

column2: * Both banks and mutual funds invest a substantial portion of the funds they receive.
* Mutual funds invest mainly in securities, while banks invest in loans and certain securities.
* Mutual funds have advanced the securitization process.

column1: * The availability of finance for different borrower sectors varies.

column2: * Residential finance has been extensively securitized.
* Consumer credit is still largely provided by commercial banks.
* The corporate sector has increased its access to finance raised in the securities markets.

column1: * Small businesses may face credit availability constraints.

column2: * Small businesses are more dependent on bank loans than large businesses.
* Small banks might have to cut back on loans if they lose deposits to mutual funds.
* Small banks have ample liquidity in the form of bonds and other securities.

column1: * The Federal Reserve reviewed the report and had no further comments.

column2: * The report provides a timely review of the flow of funds between mutual funds and bank deposits.
* The report does not make recommendations to the Federal Reserve.
* Copies of the report are",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 465,"<summary>
• The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 mandates activities to enhance bioterrorism preparedness.

column2: •• It includes improving coordination, developing countermeasures, and enhancing state, local, and hospital preparedness.
•• HHS has funded over $2.7 billion for public health preparedness and over $1 billion for hospital preparedness since 2002.

column1: • The President's 2004 executive order aims for electronic health records for most Americans within 10 years.

column2: •• The National Coordinator for Health Information Technology was appointed to develop a strategic plan for interoperable health IT.
•• HHS issued a framework for strategic action with four broad goals, including improvements in public health.

column1: • CDC's Public Health Information Network (PHIN) is a major IT initiative to integrate public health information systems.

column2: •• PHIN aims to support early event detection, outbreak management, and laboratory system connections.
•• CDC expects states to meet PHIN Preparedness requirements by September 2005 to receive funding.

column1: • Challenges remain in integrating federal public health IT initiatives and ensuring interoperability.

column2: •• Coordination among federal, state, and local agencies is essential but challenging.
•• HHS and DHS need to align their IT initiatives with the national health IT strategy and address standards implementation.

466,"<summary>
* Employers have made significant changes to their pension and benefit offerings over the past decade.

column2: * 81% modified DB plan formulas, 52% converted nonbargaining DB plans to hybrid plans, and 62% reported plan freezes.
* Reasons for changes include funding volatility for nonbargaining plans and competitive pressures for bargaining plans.
* Health benefits remain a major cost, with 46% of firms no longer offering retiree health benefits to new hires.

column1: * Future changes to pension plans are likely to be influenced by legislation and economic factors.

column2: * 50% of respondents are likely to add or expand automatic enrollment features in 401(k) plans.
* 45% may change investment policies to increase fixed income assets in DB plans.
* Most firms are unlikely to form new DB plans, citing regulatory and funding challenges.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
467,"<summary>

* The Refugee Act of 1980 established a systematic procedure for admitting and resettling refugees in the U.S., involving multiple federal, state, and local agencies, as well as private organizations.

column2: * The President determines the annual refugee admission cap, and refugees are placed in communities by national voluntary agencies based on community capacity assessments.

column1: * Challenges in refugee resettlement include inadequate consultation with local stakeholders, leading to unpreparedness in providing necessary services, and issues with secondary migration affecting local resources.

column2: * Recommendations include improving consultation guidance, increasing responsiveness of grants for secondary migrants, and revising performance measures to focus on long-term integration and self-sufficiency.

column1: * Benefits of refugee resettlement include cultural enrichment and economic contributions, but it can also strain local resources such as schools and healthcare systems.

column2: * Effective strategies for integration and resettlement include community-based advisory committees and formal strategic plans, which help manage the impact and support refugee integration.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
468,"<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established NFIP to provide government-guaranteed flood insurance and reduce federal disaster repair costs.

column2: * FEMA, under DHS, oversees NFIP, which has been strengthened by subsequent legislation like the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 and the National Flood Insurance Reform Act of 1994.

column1: * NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk premiums, with subsidized rates applying to about 22% of policies, but these do not fully cover the risk of flood damage.

column2: * Subsidized premiums are about 40-45% of full-risk rates, leading to financial instability and reliance on Treasury borrowing, especially after catastrophic events like the 2005 hurricanes.

column1: * FEMA uses mitigation efforts like elevation, relocation, and demolition to reduce flood damage, but the number of repetitive loss properties has grown.

column2: * Repetitive loss properties account for a significant portion of claims, and FEMA has limited authority to compel mitigation, which could reduce costs.

column1: * Increasing premium rates to reflect full risk could decrease taxpayer costs and encourage private market participation but might lead to reduced policy purchases.

column2: * Phasing out subsidized rates and providing targeted assistance to low-income property owners could mitigate these disadvantages.

column1: * Expanding NFIP participation, especially in low- and moderate-risk areas, could diversify the risk pool and lower premium rates.

column2: * Outreach efforts and mandatory purchase requirements could help increase participation, but NFIP cannot reject high-risk applicants, which could increase losses.

column1: * Encouraging private market participation could transfer risk from taxpayers to private insurers, but private rates are generally higher than NFIP rates.

column2: * Strategies like requiring private coverage for all property owners and providing federal support could mitigate disadvantages.

column1: * FEMA faces operational and management challenges, including strategic planning, human capital planning, and information technology issues.

column2: * Addressing these challenges is vital for NFIP's long-term stability and efficiency.

column1: * Congressional action is needed to reform NFIP, including measures to charge premiums reflecting actual risks and funding for mitigation efforts.

column2: * Congress could also explore private sector alternatives and provide FEMA with authority to deny coverage to non-mitigating repetitive loss property owners.

column1: * FEMA needs to improve its operational and managerial practices to ensure NFIP's stability and effectiveness.

column2: * This includes better strategic planning, human capital management, and intra-agency collaboration.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
469,"<summary>
* Section 287(g) of the INA allows ICE to enter into agreements with state or local law enforcement to perform immigration officer functions.

column2: * ** These agreements are not required for communication or cooperation with ICE.
* ** Officers can access ICE databases and process aliens for removal.
* ** ICE has discretion to establish enforcement priorities.
* ** Written agreements must detail responsibilities and supervision.

column1: * The 287(g) program is managed by ICE’s Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC).

column2: * ** OSLC provides information about ICE programs to local agencies.
* ** OSLC assesses resources and needs before approving applicants.
* ** ICE may suggest other ACCESS programs if more appropriate.
* ** Three models exist: jail, task force, and joint models.

column1: * The program has grown rapidly, with increased funding and support from Congress.

column2: * ** Initial funding in 2006 was $5 million, increasing to $54.1 million by 2009.
* ** Emphasis on monitoring compliance and extensive training.
* ** Financial assistance available through ICE or DOJ grants.
* ** Concerns about management controls and program objectives.

column1: * ICE has not documented the program’s objectives or specific use of 287(g) authority.

column2: * ** Lack of clarity on when and how authority should be used.
* ** Inconsistent communication in MOAs and training materials.
* ** Potential misuse of authority by participating agencies.
* ** Need for clear objectives to prioritize serious criminal activity.

column1: * ICE supervision of participating agencies is not well-defined.

column2: * ** MOAs lack detail on the nature and extent of supervision.
* ** Variation in perceptions of supervisory activities among ICE officials.
* ** Shortage of supervisory resources affects oversight.
* ** Need for defined supervision activities to ensure proper implementation.

column1: * Data collection and reporting requirements are unclear.

column2: * ** MOAs do not specify what data should be tracked or how.
* ** Confusion among participating agencies about reporting requirements.
* ** Importance of consistent data collection for program assessment.
* ** Need for clear guidance on data collection and reporting.

column1: * ICE has not developed performance measures for the 287(g) program.

column2: * ** Performance measures are essential for tracking progress.
* ** ICE is beginning compliance inspections but lacks performance assessments.
* ** Challenges in developing measures due to unique agreements.
* ** Need for a plan and timeline for developing performance measures.

column1: * ICE and participating agencies report benefits and concerns.

column2: * ** Benefits include",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 470,"<summary>
* SEC oversees mutual funds through OCIE, Division of Investment Management, and Division of Enforcement.

column2: * OCIE examines compliance with federal securities laws.
* Division of Investment Management administers securities laws and reviews disclosure documents.
* Division of Enforcement investigates and prosecutes violations.

column1: * SEC regulates mutual funds under several acts, including the Investment Company Act of 1940.

column2: * Mutual funds must register with SEC and comply with operational requirements.
* The Investment Advisers Act requires advisers to register and prohibits fraudulent practices.
* The Securities Act regulates fund shares and advertising.

column1: * SEC has shifted its examination approach post-2003 to focus on higher-risk areas.

column2: * Increased emphasis on sweep and cause examinations.
* Routine examinations now focus on high-risk funds every 2-3 years.
* Continuous monitoring of the largest mutual funds.

column1: * SEC established the Office of Risk Assessment (ORA) to analyze risks.

column2: * ORA gathers data on new trends and risks.
* Works with internal risk teams and a Risk Management Committee.
* Aims to identify and assess new areas of concern.

column1: * SEC's revised examination approach involves significant tradeoffs.

column2: * Limited capacity to examine lower-risk advisers and funds.
* Historically, routine examinations were the cornerstone of oversight.
* New approach may limit the ability to develop industry risk ratings.

column1: * SEC has integrated quality controls but could benefit from additional measures.

column2: * Supervisory review of risk scorecards is not expressly required.
* Written examination plans are optional and not consistently used.
* Periodic reviews of completed examinations and work papers are not conducted.

column1: * SEC's broker-dealer oversight examinations provide limited information on SRO oversight.

column2: * Different sampling methodologies and examination guidelines are used.
* SEC cannot reliably determine if violations are due to SRO weaknesses.
* SEC plans to enhance tracking of identified weaknesses in SRO programs.

column1: * SEC's changes to its mutual fund examination program involve tradeoffs and challenges.

column2: * Limited capacity to review lower-risk funds and conduct timely risk assessments.
* New rule requiring hedge fund advisers to register will increase workload.
* SEC must explore efficiencies before requesting additional resources from Congress.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
471,"<summary>
• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.

column2: • It focuses on improving navigation, promoting regional development, and controlling floodwaters.

column1: • TVA finances its power program through electricity sales and borrowing, with a debt ceiling of $30 billion.

column2: • It must design rates to cover all costs while keeping them as low as feasible.

column1: • TVA's Board of Directors, nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate, administers TVA.

column2: • The board sets goals, appoints the CEO, develops long-range plans, and approves the budget and rate changes.

column1: • TVA uses a 10-year long-range financial plan to determine funds for capital investment.

column2: • It files quarterly and annual financial reports with the SEC and submits budget proposals to Congress and OMB.

column1: • TVA's 2015 IRP found no immediate need for new baseload plants beyond specific nuclear projects.

column2: • It relies on natural gas generation, energy efficiency, and renewable power.

column1: • TVA's debt ceiling has not changed since 1979, but its business and operations have grown.

column2: • It uses debt financing for new generation capacity and environmental controls.

column1: • TVA's retirement system (TVARS) is a separate legal entity managed by a seven-member Board of Directors.

column2: • The TVARS board manages investment portfolios, interest rates, and benefits.

column1: • TVA plans to reduce its debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through rate increases, limiting operating expenses, and reducing capital expenditures.

column2: • It aims to increase financial flexibility to ensure room under the debt ceiling for future investments.

column1: • Several factors could affect TVA's ability to meet its debt reduction goal, including regulatory pressures, changes in demand, and unforeseen events.

column2: • TVA's unfunded pension liabilities and market conditions could also impact its financial health and operations.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
472,"<summary>
* First City Bancorporation of Texas, Inc. faced financial difficulties in the 1980s due to high-risk loans and a struggling energy sector.

column2: * By 1986, First City reported operating losses and required a $970 million capital infusion from FDIC in 1988.
* The recapitalization agreement reduced subsidiary banks from nearly 60 to about 20 and created a ""collecting bank"" for troubled assets.
* Despite efforts, First City banks failed by 1992 due to continued loan portfolio problems and high operating expenses.

column1: * FDIC and OCC monitored First City banks closely, considering various resolution plans from 1991 to 1992.

column2: * First City favored a Type B transaction but shifted to Type A due to difficulties in raising new capital.
* FDIC rejected a Type A bid due to high costs and pursued self-rescue proposals (Type C) from First City.
* Both self-rescue proposals were rejected due to concerns about viability and capital shortfalls.

column1: * In October 1992, OCC declared First City-Houston insolvent, leading to the closure of the entire First City banking organization.

column2: * FDIC chose to operate the banks as bridge banks until a sale could be arranged.
* The January 1993 sale attracted 30 bids, resulting in a surplus of about $60 million.
* FDIC's initial $500 million loss estimate was revised to no cost to BIF, with a potential surplus exceeding $200 million.

column1: * Lawsuits were filed by First City Bancorporation against federal and state regulators, alleging wrongful closure and violation of due process.

column2: * The lawsuits claimed FDIC used cross-guarantee provisions to gain control of First City banks.
* FDIC and First City reached a settlement in June 1994, with First City receiving over $200 million.
* The settlement ensured no loss to BIF and allowed for creditor and shareholder distributions.

column1: * FDIC and OCC identified lessons from the First City experience to improve future resolution processes.

column2: * Greater consultation with regulatory counterparts on economic assumptions could lead to more realistic projections.
* Assistance agreements should include safeguards to ensure adherence to agreed-upon business strategies.
* Improved documentation of examination findings is necessary for clear and well-supported closure decisions.

column1: * Regulatory and legislative changes since the 1980s have expanded authorities to deal with troubled financial institutions.

column2: * FIRREA and FDICIA provided greater authority for early intervention and resolution of troubled banks.
* FDIC",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 473,"<summary>
• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was enacted to address concerns about the lack of oversight and accountability for federal assistance to state and local governments.

column2: •• The act replaced multiple grant audits with a single, organization-wide audit to ensure proper use of federal funds.
•• The 1996 amendments refined the act, extending its coverage to all federal grant recipients and increasing the audit threshold to $300,000, later raised to $500,000 in 2003.
•• Oversight responsibilities are shared among OMB, federal agencies, and their OIGs, with OMB issuing guidelines and agencies ensuring compliance.

column1: • The quality of single audits has been a longstanding concern, with significant deficiencies identified in many audits.

column2: •• The National Single Audit Sampling Project found that 51% of audits had deficiencies, with higher rates of acceptable audits for entities expending $50 million or more.
•• Recommendations to improve audit quality include revising standards, establishing minimum training requirements, and enhancing disciplinary processes.
•• Additional considerations include evaluating simplified alternatives for smaller audits and assessing the adequacy of federal oversight structures.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
474,"<summary>
• Medicare is a federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled beneficiaries.

column2: • Part A covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and certain home health services.
• Part B covers physician and outpatient hospital services, laboratory, and other services.
• Claims are processed by intermediaries (Part A) and carriers (Part B).

column1: • Medicare contracting deviates from the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR).

column2: • No full and open competition for intermediary or carrier contracts.
• Intermediaries are nominated by provider associations.
• Carriers are chosen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services from a small pool of health insurers.

column1: • The number of Medicare contractors has significantly declined since 1980.

column2: • Many contractors have shifted focus to other business lines.
• This has reduced the pool of available contractors.
• The decline necessitates legislative changes to broaden the contractor pool.

column1: • CMS has proposed legislative changes to allow competitive contracting.

column2: • Repeal of provider nomination authority.
• Explicit authority to contract with entities other than health insurers.
• Competitive awards to qualified companies, including data processing firms.

column1: • Functional contracting could improve program management.

column2: • Specialization in specific claims administration activities.
• Potential for better performance and efficiency.
• Example: Separate contractors for educating providers and responding to beneficiaries.

column1: • Financial incentives for high-quality performance could benefit Medicare.

column2: • Current cost-based reimbursement precludes profit.
• Repeal of cost-based restrictions could allow performance-based contracts.
• Potential for improved operations and lower administrative costs.

column1: • Termination of contractors needs more flexibility.

column2: • Current process requires a public hearing before termination.
• Contractors can terminate without cause with 180 days notice.
• Legislative changes could align Medicare with other federal contracting practices.

column1: • Implementing contracting reforms requires careful planning.

column2: • Development of clear statements of work and selection criteria.
• Efficient integration of new contractors into Medicare operations.
• Experimental, incremental approach recommended.

column1: • Effective evaluation criteria are essential for new contracting arrangements.

column2: • Clear statements of expected outcomes and quantifiable measures.
• Prior experiments with financial incentives had mixed results.
• Careful and deliberate implementation needed to avoid past issues.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
475,"<summary>
• DOD aims to increase modernization investments without raising defense budgets by reducing support operation costs.
• DOD's support structure is inefficient and consumes a large budget share.
• Savings from support cost reductions could fund modernization and other priorities.
• OSD requested DSB to identify activities for efficient private sector outsourcing.
• DSB issued two reports in 1996 on outsourcing and reducing support services costs.
• DSB's first report suggested 30-40% savings in logistics costs through outsourcing.
• Evidence from CNA studies supported these savings.
• Public sector savings from outsourcing could be higher due to inefficiencies.
• Aggressive outsourcing could save $7-$12 billion annually by 2002.
• The second report expanded on these findings, proposing a new vision for DOD.
• DSB's second report projected $30 billion annual savings by 2002, mainly through outsourcing.
• $6 billion savings from CONUS logistics infrastructure activities.
• $4.2 billion from outsourcing, $1.8 billion from inventory management improvements.
• DSB estimated $14 billion annual CONUS logistics costs.
• Navy's reported $8.5 billion maintenance costs in 1996 supported this estimate.
• DOD needs dramatic changes to achieve significant savings.
• Must exit material management/distribution and repair business.
• Expand contractor logistics support and use prime vendors.
• Prime vendors would handle inventory, reducing DOD's middleman role.
• Best practices from the private sector indicate significant savings opportunities.
• PA&E's analysis found DSB's $6 billion savings estimate overstated by $1 billion.
• Contract administration and oversight costs were understated.
• One-time inventory savings were claimed as steady state savings.
• $1 billion savings difficult but possible with legislative changes.
• $2 billion savings unlikely due to timing and DOD's culture.
• Our analysis confirmed PA&E's findings on DSB's savings estimates.
• Reliability improvement savings overstated by over $1 billion.
• DSB's 25% savings rate from outsourcing overly optimistic.
• Competitive markets for some logistics activities do not exist.
• Sole-sourced contracts reduce potential savings.
• Legal and cultural barriers hinder full implementation of DSB's recommendations.
• Core logistics capability must be maintained by government.
• Legislative restrictions on outsourcing depot maintenance.
• Public-private competition required for certain workloads.
• Cultural resistance to outsourcing within DOD.
• DOD",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
476,"<summary>
• Federal employment levels were reduced starting in 1993 to cut costs and control deficits.

column2: •• The Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 mandated a reduction of 272,900 FTE positions by 1999.
•• The National Performance Review recommended streamlining operations and reducing management control.
•• Agencies were required to measure performance under the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993.

column1: • Specific agencies experienced significant workforce reductions between 1993 and 1996.

column2: •• HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM saw reductions ranging from 2% to 100%.
•• HUD’s Office of Housing and GSA’s PBS had the largest percentage reductions within their agencies.
•• NASA’s Human Space Flight Program and OPM’s Investigations Service were also heavily downsized.

column1: • Agencies took various actions to maintain performance during downsizing.

column2: •• Refocused missions to increase efficiency, such as BOR shifting to water resources management.
•• Reengineered work processes, including consolidating functions and increasing reliance on contractors.
•• Took steps to build and maintain employee skills through retraining and consolidating expertise.

column1: • Performance and customer satisfaction were generally maintained, but concerns existed.

column2: •• Limited performance measurement data showed goals were generally met.
•• Customer satisfaction surveys indicated mixed results, with some dissatisfaction linked to downsizing.
•• Officials and employees expressed concerns about maintaining performance with further downsizing.

column1: • Lessons learned emphasized the importance of communication and planning.

column2: •• Open lines of communication between management and employees were crucial.
•• Employee input in planning processes was necessary for successful downsizing.
•• Compassionate treatment of employees and careful planning of buyouts were important.

column1: • HUD’s Office of Housing took specific actions to maintain performance.

column2: •• Consolidated activities into fewer offices and implemented paperless processing.
•• Used contractors to supplement staff and implemented work sharing among offices.
•• Faced challenges with staffing levels and skill mixes, as noted by the HUD Inspector General.

column1: • BOR reengineered its operations and focused on water resources management.

column2: •• Established the Reclamation Service Center to provide various services.
•• Consolidated project offices and rotated employees to develop future supervisors.
•• Faced challenges with computer support and employee stress due to increased workloads.

column1: • GSA’s PBS reengineered work processes and focused on building employee skills.

column2: •• Decentralized property development operations and implemented new programs.
•• Retrained staff in asset management and planned to improve automated data processing systems.
••",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 477,"<summary>
• IRS designed the National Research Program (NRP) to gather data on taxpayer compliance with tax laws.

column2: • NRP focuses on voluntary reporting compliance and aims to minimize taxpayer burden while collecting accurate data.

column1: • NRP's reporting compliance study involves three processes: casebuilding, classification, and taxpayer audits.

column2: • Casebuilding compiles data from various sources, classification determines audit necessity, and audits verify unconfirmed items.

column1: • IRS conducted tests and training to ensure the effectiveness of NRP processes before full implementation.

column2: • Tests identified areas for improvement, and training was provided to classifiers and auditors to ensure consistency and accuracy.

column1: • Quality assurance measures are in place to ensure the accuracy of NRP data.

column2: • Reviews of audits and classification decisions are conducted to identify and correct errors, ensuring reliable data collection.

column1: • IRS aims to use NRP results to improve audit selection formulas and reduce taxpayer burden.

column2: • The program seeks to better target noncompliant taxpayers and reduce unnecessary audits of compliant taxpayers.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
478,"<summary>
* Thorough planning and preparation are crucial for the cost-effectiveness and success of large projects like the decennial census.
* Poor planning in the 2000 Census led to increased costs, risks, and controversy.
* Recommendations were made to improve planning for the 2010 Census, including comprehensive information and performance measures.
* The Bureau's 2010 Census design aims to address past issues with four principal goals.
* Goals include increasing relevance and timeliness of data, reducing operational risk, improving coverage and accuracy, and containing costs.
* The Bureau's new approach involves a ""three-legged stool"" strategy focusing on address list accuracy, the American Community Survey (ACS), and technology improvements.
* The Bureau faces significant challenges in securing congressional approval and managing operational risks.
* Congressional support is necessary for stable planning and funding.
* The Bureau must demonstrate the feasibility and benefits of its design to gain support.
* The Bureau's planning process for the 2010 Census has improved but still has weaknesses.
* A comprehensive project plan with clear goals, milestones, and cost estimates is needed.
* Performance data from the 2000 Census is lacking, making it difficult to inform 2010 planning.
* The Bureau's cost estimates for the 2010 Census are high, with potential for further increases.
* The estimated cost is $11.3 billion, with a repeat of the 2000 approach costing even more.
* Greater fiscal transparency and detailed cost assumptions are needed for effective oversight.
* The Bureau's reengineering efforts include modernizing address lists and implementing ACS.
* The MAF/TIGER Enhancements Program aims to correct address and map data issues.
* ACS is intended to replace the long form, providing more timely and accurate data.
* Recommendations were made to improve the Bureau's planning and cost transparency.
* OMB should ensure the Bureau provides detailed life cycle cost estimates and explanations for changes.
* The Bureau should develop a comprehensive operational plan and research procedures for adjusting census results if necessary.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
479,"<summary>
• Widespread use of health information technology, such as electronic prescribing, can improve care quality and reduce costs.

column2: •• Electronic prescribing allows direct transmission of prescriptions from providers to pharmacies.
•• It involves multiple entities accessing an individual's health information electronically.

column1: • Federal laws and regulations, including HIPAA and the HITECH Act, govern the use and protection of individually identifiable health information (PHI).

column2: •• HIPAA establishes privacy and security standards for PHI.
•• The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA's privacy and security protections and enforcement.

column1: • The HIPAA Privacy Rule regulates the use and disclosure of PHI and requires reasonable efforts to use the minimum necessary information.

column2: •• It provides methods for de-identifying PHI to reduce the risk of re-identification.
•• The Safe Harbor and expert determination methods are used for de-identification.

column1: • The HIPAA Security Rule specifies safeguards to protect electronic PHI from unauthorized access or disclosure.

column2: •• Covered entities must implement administrative, technical, and physical safeguards.
•• Security measures should be appropriate to the entity's size, complexity, and risk level.

column1: • The HITECH Act requires breach notification regulations and extends certain HIPAA requirements to business associates.

column2: •• OCR issued the Breach Notification Rule and the HITECH Enforcement Rule.
•• OCR proposed additional modifications to the HIPAA rules to strengthen privacy and security.

column1: • OCR has developed an enforcement process focused on investigating complaints and breach notifications.

column2: •• Investigations often result in corrective actions, such as policy revisions and staff training.
•• OCR has issued resolution agreements and civil money penalties for noncompliance.

column1: • OCR initiated a pilot audit program to assess compliance with HIPAA rules but has not yet established a sustained audit capability.

column2: •• The pilot program aims to identify privacy and security issues at covered entities.
•• OCR plans to review the pilot program to determine how to fully implement an audit function.

column1: • HHS has promoted public awareness and provided guidance on HIPAA compliance but has not issued required de-identification guidance.

column2: •• OCR has developed resources and toolkits to assist covered entities.
•• Delays in issuing de-identification guidance increase the risk of improper implementation.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
480,"<summary>
• The MHSS's primary mission is medical readiness, spending over $15 billion annually.

column2: •• Provides medical support to active-duty personnel during combat and peacetime.
•• Supports nonactive-duty beneficiaries when resources allow.
•• Purchases civilian health care services when MHSS resources are insufficient.

column1: • Psychiatrists and clinical psychologists play key roles in MHSS's mental health care.

column2: •• Psychiatrists can prescribe medication due to their medical training.
•• Clinical psychologists focus on psychosocial approaches and cannot prescribe medication.
•• The PDP was created to train psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication.

column1: • The PDP aimed to expand clinical psychologists' scope of practice in the military.

column2: •• Established in response to a 1988 conference report.
•• Training included coursework at USUHS and clinical experience at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.
•• Graduates received a certificate and became known as ""prescribing psychologists.""

column1: • The PDP faced several implementation challenges.

column2: •• Difficulty recruiting participants and unspecified selection criteria.
•• Frequent changes in curriculum and delays in granting prescribing privileges.
•• Unresolved supervision issues and lack of a clearly defined role for prescribing psychologists.

column1: • The MHSS has no current or upcoming need for additional prescribing psychologists.

column2: •• Surplus of psychiatrists and clinical psychologists to meet readiness requirements.
•• Psychologists cannot fully substitute for psychiatrists in treating combat stress.
•• No separate readiness requirement for prescribing psychologists.

column1: • The cost of the PDP was substantial, with questionable cost-effectiveness.

column2: •• Total cost estimated at $6.1 million, or $610,000 per graduate.
•• Overhead and training costs were significant.
•• Cost-effectiveness analysis showed mixed results depending on assumptions used.

column1: • The PDP produced some benefits but also faced persistent issues.

column2: •• Reduced psychiatrists' workloads in some facilities.
•• Mixed perceptions among psychiatrists, psychologists, and primary care physicians.
•• Unclear cost-effectiveness and substantial implementation difficulties.

column1: • Recommendations for future consideration of prescribing psychologists.

column2: •• Clearly demonstrate cost savings and define their role and scope of practice.
•• Design an appropriate curriculum and determine supervision needs.
•• Congress should require DOD to address these issues if prescribing psychologists are needed.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
481,"<summary>

* The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a complex, infrared-optimized space telescope designed to succeed the Hubble Space Telescope, with a 5-year mission to study the first stars and galaxy evolution, operating 1.5 million kilometers from Earth.

column2: * JWST features a 6.5-meter primary mirror, a multi-layered sunshield, and a cryocooler for the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI), developed by NASA, contractors, and international partners, with significant integration and testing phases to mitigate risks before its planned October 2018 launch.

column1: * JWST has faced significant cost and schedule challenges, including technical issues with the cryocooler and sunshield, leading to increased workforce and cost reserves, with ongoing independent oversight to manage risks and ensure mission success.

column2: * Despite these challenges, the project remains on schedule with 8.75 months of schedule reserve, but must address over 100 technical risks and ensure timely resolution of problem reports to avoid further delays and cost overruns.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
482,"<summary>
• Chemical facilities are high-risk targets for terrorism, but comprehensive security assessments are lacking.

column2: • EPA regulates around 15,000 facilities under the Clean Air Act, requiring risk management plans, but many facilities with hazardous chemicals are not subject to these requirements.

column1: • DHS is developing a Chemical Sector-Specific Plan to reduce vulnerabilities, using EPA's RMP database to identify high-risk facilities.

column2: • DHS's RAMCAP methodology will prioritize facilities based on threat levels, vulnerabilities, and potential attack consequences, with voluntary participation from facility owners.

column1: • Industry associations have promoted security measures, but participation and effectiveness vary.

column2: • ACC and other associations require vulnerability assessments and security enhancements, but smaller companies face financial challenges in implementing these measures.

column1: • DHS lacks authority to mandate security measures at chemical facilities, prompting calls for federal legislation.

column2: • Proposed legislation would grant DHS or EPA authority to enforce security requirements, with debates on including inherently safer technologies.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
483,"<summary>
• The Privacy Act of 1974 and the E-Government Act of 2002 are key laws for protecting personal privacy in federal agencies.

column2: • The Privacy Act limits collection, disclosure, and use of personal information, requiring public notification for changes in systems of records.

column1: • The E-Government Act mandates privacy impact assessments (PIAs) to analyze how personal information is managed in federal systems.

column2: • PIAs ensure compliance with privacy laws, assess risks, and evaluate protections for personal data.

column1: • The Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) requires federal agencies to secure information systems and protect personal data.

column2: • FISMA mandates agencywide information security programs, including for contractors, to prevent unauthorized access and disclosure.

column1: • DHS faces challenges in addressing privacy concerns in data mining, passenger prescreening, use of commercial data, RFID technology, and information sharing.

column2: • DHS has been advised to conduct PIAs, develop privacy policies, and issue comprehensive guidance to ensure consistent privacy protections.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
484,"<summary>
• Social Security is a major federal program in the U.S., providing benefits to retirees, disabled workers, and dependents.

column2: •• In 2006, it paid about $546 billion to over 49 million beneficiaries, including nearly 7 million disabled workers and over 11 million dependents.
