628,"<summary>
* Hydatid cyst disease is a significant zoonotic disease caused by the larval stage of the Echinococcus granulosus parasite.

column2: * Canines such as dogs, wolves, foxes, and jackals are the final hosts.
* Canines become infected by eating contaminated viscera and spread the eggs through feces.
* Humans and herbivores are intermediate hosts, infected by consuming contaminated food or water.

column1: * The disease is prevalent worldwide, especially in regions with extensive animal husbandry.

column2: * Common in tropical regions and countries like Argentina, Peru, East Africa, Central Asia, China, and South America.
* In endemic regions, incidence rates can exceed 50 per 100,000 person-years.
* Iran is considered a hyper-endemic area by WHO due to close human-animal interactions.

column1: * A cross-sectional study was conducted in Khorasan Razavi province, Iran, from 2011 to 2014.

column2: * The study included all diagnosed cases in governmental and private health facilities.
* Data collection involved demographic details, clinical symptoms, and risk factors.
* Statistical analysis was performed using Stata software, version 12.

column1: * A total of 357 hydatid cyst cases were registered during the study period.

column2: * The highest percentage of cases was in Mashhad (51.8%), followed by Ghoochan (7.8%), Neishabour (7.0%), and Fariman (4.8%).
* 54.9% of cases were women, and 40.3% were from rural areas.
* The mean age of women was higher than that of men (39.1 vs. 34.7 years, p-value=0.025).

column1: * The most common clinical symptom was abdominal pain (42.3%).

column2: * Other symptoms included hepatomegaly (27.4%), chest pain (21.6%), and cough (8.7%).
* Liver involvement was reported in 59.4% of patients.
* 8.4% had multiple organ involvement.

column1: * Diagnostic methods included radiology (42.3%) and CT scan (37.8%).

column2: * These methods are the most available tools for detecting hydatid cysts in Iran.
* Previous studies also highlighted the use of ultrasonography and CT scans.
* Consistent with findings from other regions.

column1: * Risk factors included contact with dogs and improper vegetable washing.

column2: * 45.9%",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 629,"<summary>
* Ciliated hepatic foregut cysts (CHFCs) are rare congenital lesions first described by Friederich in 1857.

column2: * Wheeler and Edmonson coined the term CHFC and identified its specific histological characteristics.
* CHFCs are thought to result from the evagination of the foregut during embryogenesis.

column1: * Only 103 cases of CHFCs have been reported worldwide, with a slight female predominance.

column2: * The average age of presentation is 52 years, ranging from 3 months to 82 years.
* CHFCs are most frequently found in the median segments of the liver and are usually asymptomatic.

column1: * Imaging techniques have improved the detection of CHFCs, with 55 cases reported in the last 25 years.

column2: * CHFCs appear as non-enhancing, rounded lesions on CT and hyperintense cysts on T2-weighted MRI images.
* Ultrasound shows CHFCs as anechoic or hypoechoic cysts with spotty hyperechoic areas.

column1: * Histologically, CHFCs have four layers: pseudostratified columnar epithelium, sub-epithelial connective tissue, smooth muscle, and an outer fibrous capsule.

column2: * The presence of these layers differentiates CHFCs from other hepatic cysts.
* A rare morphologic variant of CHFC without a smooth muscle layer has been reported.

column1: * CHFCs can be mistaken for other hepatic cysts, such as simple cysts, hydatid cysts, and bronchogenic cysts.

column2: * Elevated CA19-9 levels can be associated with benign CHFCs.
* CHFCs can harbor squamous cell carcinoma in 4.4% of reported cases.

column1: * Surgical excision is recommended for CHFCs larger than 4-5 cm, symptomatic lesions, or those with wall abnormalities.

column2: * Laparoscopic excision is preferred for its minimally invasive nature and effectiveness.
* Lesions in segments II to VI are more accessible for laparoscopic excision.

column1: * The case of a 32-year-old woman with a CHFC was successfully treated with laparoscopic excision.

column2: * The cyst was initially suspected to be a simple liver cyst but was found to be a CHFC upon pathological review.
* The patient benefited from a minimally invasive procedure, reducing the risk of malignant transformation.

630,"<summary>
•• The oral route is preferred for drug administration due to safety, ease, and patient acceptability.

column2: •• About 60% of conventional dosage forms are oral solid forms, but issues like low bioavailability and difficulty swallowing lead to alternatives like parenterals and liquid forms.

column1: •• Fast dissolving tablets (FDTs) dissolve in the mouth within 60 seconds without water, improving patient compliance.

column2: •• FDTs are beneficial for patients with dysphagia, motion sickness, and sudden coughing episodes.

column1: •• Orally dissolving strips (ODS) are an advanced form of oral dosage, offering flexibility and comfort.

column2: •• ODS dissolve in the oral cavity within a minute, providing quick absorption and bioavailability.

column1: •• ODS are particularly useful for pediatric, geriatric, bedridden, and emetic patients.

column2: •• They are also beneficial during sudden allergic attacks or coughing episodes.

column1: •• Clobazam, an antiepileptic drug, is ideal for ODS formulation due to its low dose requirement and use in children.

column2: •• The study aimed to develop and optimize ODS of clobazam using PVA (film former) and SSG (disintegrant).

column1: •• A 3 factorial design was used to evaluate the influence of PVA and SSG on the film's properties.

column2: •• The study assessed in vivo performance and IVIVC of the optimized formulation in healthy rabbits.

column1: •• The optimized ODS formulation (F6) showed the highest dissolution rate, suitable disintegration time, and satisfactory tensile strength.

column2: •• In vivo studies indicated no significant difference between F6 and marketed clobazam tablets.

column1: •• Stability studies showed that the prepared formulation was stable for at least 6 months.

column2: •• The ODS formulation of clobazam is potentially useful for treating epileptic attacks with improved patient compliance.

631,"<summary>
* Stroke is a major cause of death and disability worldwide, with significant long-term impacts on survivors.

column2: * Many survivors experience impairments requiring additional care or support one year post-stroke.
* Stroke can lead to social isolation, mood disturbances, communication difficulties, and reduced mobility.
* Recovery is complex, involving biomedical, psychological, and sociological elements.
* Self-management practices are key to promoting recovery and improving health outcomes.

column1: * Self-management interventions (SMIs) are designed to help individuals manage their health more effectively.

column2: * Evaluation of SMIs must consider skill development and resulting health improvements.
* The UK Medical Research Council emphasizes establishing the theoretical basis of interventions.
* The COSMIN checklist is used to assess the methodological quality of outcome measures.
* There is a lack of consensus on appropriate measures for evaluating stroke SMIs.

column1: * The review highlights the need for better conceptualization and measurement of stroke self-management.

column2: * Many studies use unreported or modified measures without established reliability or validity.
* Physical function is often used as an indicator of effective self-management, but its role requires clarification.
* There is a need for outcome measures developed with input from stroke survivors.
* Researchers and clinicians should select measures with proven reliability and validity for stroke populations.

632,"<summary>
* Osteoarthritis (OA) in the knee joint is a common cause of disability in older adults in India, affecting their quality of life.
* Physiotherapy aims to reduce pain and improve daily living activities (ADL) and quality of life (QOL).
* Both self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests are used to monitor progress.
* Self-reported questionnaires provide subjective information quickly and without examiner bias.
* Examples include WOMAC, SF-36, and KOOS.
* They measure disability, combining social and psychological aspects of functional limitation.
* Performance-based tests objectively measure a patient's ability to perform ADL activities.
* Examples include the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG), Six-Minute Walk Test (6-MWT), and Stair Climbing Test.
* These tests are influenced by motivation but not by psychogenic factors.
* The study aimed to correlate the KOOS questionnaire with the 6-MWT, age, height, weight, and BMI.
* KOOS consists of 42 questions covering pain, symptoms, ADL, sports and recreation, and QOL.
* The 6-MWT measures walking ability and endurance.
* Results showed varying degrees of correlation between KOOS subscales and objective measures.
* 6-MWT had weak to very strong correlations with different KOOS subscales.
* BMI showed strong to very strong correlations with KOOS subscales, while weight had weak to strong correlations.
* The study's findings align with previous research, supporting the use of KOOS in Indian OA knee patients.
* There was no significant correlation between age and most KOOS subscales.
* The study confirms the importance of using both self-reported and performance-based tests for comprehensive assessment.

633,"<summary>
• Obesity and Inflammation

column2: •• Obesity is a chronic inflammatory disease influenced by diet, lifestyle, and genetics.
•• Adipose tissue secretes both proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory factors.
•• High-fat diets in rodents induce metabolic changes and chronic inflammation.
•• Endotoxins and saturated fats activate toll-like receptor 4, triggering cytokine production.

column1: • Menopause and Obesity

column2: •• Menopause increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases due to hormonal changes.
•• Estrogen has anti-inflammatory effects but its role is controversial.
•• Hormonal changes during menopause lead to physical and metabolic remodeling.
•• Estrogen's effects on inflammation and metabolism need further investigation.

column1: • Study Design and Methods

column2: •• Female Wistar rats were used, divided into control and hyperlipidic diet groups.
•• Rats underwent ovariectomy or sham surgery and were monitored for 8 weeks.
•• Body weight, food intake, and various metabolic parameters were measured.
•• Protein and lipid content in tissues were analyzed using specific assays.

column1: • Key Findings

column2: •• Hyperlipidic diet combined with ovariectomy increased body weight and hyperleptinemia.
•• Cytokine levels in liver and muscle remained unchanged, but decreased in mesenteric adipose tissue.
•• Ovariectomy alone did not significantly alter metabolic parameters.
•• High-fat diet and ovariectomy together led to increased adiposity and altered cytokine levels.

column1: • Implications and Recommendations

column2: •• Postmenopausal women should reduce fat intake to mitigate obesity-related inflammation.
•• Estrogen replacement therapy may help in managing weight and metabolic health.
•• Further research is needed to understand estrogen's role in inflammation.
•• The study highlights the importance of diet and hormonal balance in managing obesity.

634,"<summary>
•• Hemoptysis, a common symptom in respiratory diseases, has a high mortality rate when massive.

column2: •• Quick treatment is essential to stop bleeding.
•• Historically, surgical methods were used if conservative management failed.
•• Bronchial artery embolization (BAE) is now a safe and effective treatment.
•• BAE is effective for both massive and chronic hemoptysis.

column1: •• A retrospective study analyzed 344 patients who underwent BAE at Tianjin Haihe Hospital.

column2: •• Patients had hemoptysis volumes ranging from 50-2000 ml/24 h.
•• 186 men and 158 women, with a mean age of 57 years.
•• 234 patients had acute and massive hemoptysis.
•• 110 patients had chronic and recurrent hemoptysis.

column1: •• Imaging and angiography findings were crucial for identifying bleeding sources.

column2: •• Chest CT scans identified blood lobes in 30.5% of cases.
•• Angiography showed abnormal bronchial arteries in 38.1% of patients.
•• 944 responsible bronchial arteries were identified.
•• Spinal arteries were identified in three patients.

column1: •• BAE was performed in 336 of 344 patients, with a high success rate.

column2: •• Immediate control of hemoptysis was achieved in 96% of patients.
•• 17.7% had recurrent hemoptysis within 1 month.
•• 21.5% had recurrent hemoptysis over 1 month.
•• Common complications included fever, chest pain, and back pain.

column1: •• Long-term follow-up showed varying outcomes.

column2: •• 248 patients had follow-up periods ranging from 6 months to 8 years.
•• 28 patients died, with six from massive hemorrhage.
•• 21 patients had recurrent hemoptysis after repeated BAE.
•• 199 patients had no evidence of recurrent hemoptysis.

635,"<summary>

•• The study investigates the relationship between Helicobacter pylori (HP) infection and celiac disease (CD) in pediatric patients, focusing on lymphocytic gastritis (LG) and the immunophenotype of gastric mucosa.

column2: •• CD patients, with or without HP infection, showed significantly higher numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs), particularly CD8+ IELs, compared to controls.
•• HP infection alone did not significantly increase CD8+ IELs, but was associated with a higher number of lymphoid aggregates in the gastric mucosa.

column1: •• The study suggests that immunohistochemical analysis of CD8+ lymphocytes and lymphoid follicles in the antrum can help differentiate between CD and HP infection in pediatric patients with overlapping clinical and histological features.

column2: •• Higher counts of CD8+ IELs may indicate CD rather than HP gastritis.
•• The presence of more lymphoid follicles points towards HP infection.

636,"<summary>
• Angiogenesis, driven by VEGF, is crucial for tumor growth, making VEGF a key target for cancer therapy.

column2: •• Anti-VEGF therapies like bevacizumab, 2C3, and R84 have shown effectiveness in reducing tumor size, microvessel density, and macrophage infiltration in breast cancer models.
•• These therapies work by blocking VEGF from binding to its receptors, thereby inhibiting tumor growth and modulating immune cell infiltration.

column1: • Anti-VEGF treatments have broader implications beyond angiogenesis inhibition, affecting immune cell behavior in the tumor microenvironment.

column2: •• Studies have shown that anti-VEGF therapies reduce the number of various immune cells, including macrophages, neutrophils, and myeloid-derived suppressor cells, within tumors.
•• Combination therapies with anti-VEGF agents and conventional chemotherapy have demonstrated enhanced antitumoral effects, suggesting potential for future clinical applications.

637,"<summary>

•• Vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) is a common condition in postmenopausal women, often leading to symptoms like dyspareunia, vaginal dryness, and irritation, which can significantly impact quality of life.

column2: •• Many women are unaware that their symptoms are related to menopause, and there is poor communication between women and healthcare providers (HCPs) about VVA.
•• The Revive survey highlights that a large number of women do not discuss their VVA symptoms with HCPs, and those who do often find the information and treatment options inadequate.

column1: •• Treatment for VVA includes over-the-counter (OTC) products and prescription therapies, but many women are dissatisfied with current treatments due to concerns about efficacy, safety, and convenience.

column2: •• Only 35% of women using any treatment for VVA are satisfied, with vaginal estrogen users generally more satisfied than those using OTC products.
•• There is a preference for oral treatments among younger patients and those who have never used VVA treatments, indicating a need for more effective and convenient treatment options.

638,"<summary>
* In Denmark, women planning to conceive are advised to take 400 g folic acid (FA) daily until the 12th week of gestation to reduce neural tube defects (NTDs).
* Starting FA supplementation before conception is crucial as the neural tube closes by gestational week 6.
* Despite campaigns, only 5-10% of Danish women of fertile age have sufficient dietary folate intake.
* The study analyzed data from the ""Snart-Gravid"" internet-based cohort study of Danish pregnancy planners from 2007 to 2011.
* Participants were recruited via a health-related website and press releases.
* Eligible women were aged 18-40, in stable relationships, not using birth control, and attempting to conceive for no more than 12 months.
* Data on FA and multivitamin (MV) supplement use, along with sociodemographic, lifestyle, reproductive, and medical variables, were collected.
* Women were categorized as users if they took FA or MV supplements.
* Nonusers included those who took other single vitamins or no supplements at all.
* The study found that 62.1% of the 5383 participants used FA or MV supplements.
* 7.7% used FA exclusively, 20.4% used MV exclusively, and 34.0% used both.
* 37.9% did not use any FA or MV supplements.
* Higher age, education, and income were associated with increased FA or MV use.
* Women who finished high school were more likely to use supplements.
* Higher household income also correlated with higher supplement use.
* Lifestyle factors such as intercourse frequency and previous spontaneous abortion were linked to higher FA or MV use.
* Women with higher intercourse frequency were more likely to use supplements.
* Those with a history of spontaneous abortion had a higher prevalence of supplement use.
* Risky behaviors like smoking, high alcohol intake, and obesity were associated with lower FA or MV use.
* Women with higher pack-years of smoking were less likely to use supplements.
* Higher alcohol intake and obesity also correlated with lower supplement use.
* The study highlighted the need for targeted interventions for women at high risk of not following FA recommendations.
* Excessive alcohol intake can impede folate bioavailability and metabolism.
* Women with chronic illnesses showed little association with increased FA or MV use.
* The study's findings suggest that more than one-third of pregnancy planners do not follow the FA recommendation",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
639,"<summary>
•• Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is linked to high oxidative stress and increased cardiovascular risk.

column2: •• PAD often results from atherosclerosis, leading to intermittent claudication in older adults.
•• Oxidative stress and high cholesterol levels are significant contributors to PAD progression.
•• Statins, such as simvastatin, are used to manage PAD by lowering lipid levels and reducing oxidative stress.

column1: •• The study compared oxidative stress markers and antioxidant capacity in PAD patients undergoing surgery versus those on simvastatin therapy.

column2: •• Group I (surgical) showed higher oxidative stress markers before surgery compared to Group II (statin therapy).
•• Post-surgery, Group I did not show significant reductions in oxidative stress markers.
•• Statin therapy was associated with lower oxidative stress markers and improved antioxidant capacity.

column1: •• Findings suggest that statin therapy is beneficial for PAD patients, but further research is needed.

column2: •• Statins may reduce oxidative stress by decreasing reactive oxygen species (ROS) production.
•• Surgical treatment showed diverse oxidative state responses, indicating the need for additional studies.
•• The study supports the efficacy of statins in managing PAD and highlights the importance of understanding both lipid-related and non-lipid-related effects.

640,"<summary>
* The demand for herbal remedies in Nigeria is rising, but there is a lack of scientific data to support their medicinal claims.

column2: * Herbal remedies are popular due to perceived health benefits and limited access to formal healthcare.
* The commercial promotion of herbals necessitates safety and validity assessments.
* Studies have shown toxic effects from indiscriminate use of packaged herbals.

column1: * The study aimed to determine the effects of oral and repeated exposure to the FIJK herbal mixture on rat plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology.

column2: * FIJK is a mixture of 13 medicinal plants and is claimed to treat various ailments.
* No empirical data supports the medicinal benefits or safety of FIJK.
* The study used 24 male Wistar rats, divided into groups receiving different dosages of FIJK.

column1: * Results showed that FIJK administration did not significantly change rat body weights but affected plasma biochemical indices.

column2: * FIJK caused significant reductions in rat plasma protein levels at higher doses.
* Elevated levels of triglycerides and LDL-C, and reduced levels of HDL-C were observed.
* Increased levels of ALT and AST indicated potential liver toxicity.

column1: * FIJK exposure led to oxidative stress and liver morphological changes in rats.

column2: * Elevated plasma MDA levels suggested lipid peroxidation.
* Depleted GSH levels indicated oxidative stress.
* Liver lesions included hemorrhage, ruptured vascular channels, and hyperemia.

column1: * The study highlights the need for scientific validation and regulation of herbal remedies in Nigeria.

column2: * Herbal products are not strictly regulated, leading to potential abuse.
* Repeated consumption of herbal mixtures may have toxic side effects.
* Empirical data is essential for informed consumer choices and public health safety.

641,"<summary>
* Identifying carriers of genetic disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents by informing them of genetic risks and reproductive options.
* Options include prenatal diagnosis, preimplantation genetic diagnosis, using donor gametes, adoption, or choosing not to have children.
* Carrier screening and testing are two approaches, with screening for those without increased risk and testing for those with higher risk.
* Preconceptional carrier screening aims to enhance reproductive autonomy and informed decision-making.
* Studies show positive attitudes towards carrier screening for cystic fibrosis among healthcare providers, patients, and the general public.
* Direct-to-consumer (DTC) genetic testing companies offer preconceptional carrier tests, raising ethical and practical concerns.
* DTC tests provide information on monogenic diseases without traditional healthcare professional involvement.
* Concerns include test validity, lack of medical supervision, inadequate consent procedures, and potential psychological impacts.
* Companies like DNA Direct, DNATraits, Pathway Genomics, and Counsyl offer various carrier tests, often without distinguishing between low and high-risk individuals.
* The Health Council of the Netherlands emphasizes the need for responsible criteria for genetic DTC screening.
* Ethical issues arise from the inclusion of a large number of disorders in DTC test panels.
* Screening criteria should ensure the condition is an important health problem and the test has known predictive value.
* The clinical utility of some tests is debatable due to variable disease expression and low penetrance.
* Companies may prioritize technical and economic aspects over policy considerations for test inclusion.
* Informed decision-making is challenging with heterogeneous test panels and variable test sensitivity and specificity.
* The importance of medical supervision and follow-up in genetic testing.
* Adequate information provision and informed consent are crucial for informed decision-making.
* Embedding carrier screening in healthcare settings ensures better information, consent, and follow-up.
* DTC tests risk disconnecting from medical supervision, leading to potential negative psychosocial impacts.
* Some companies have shifted to requiring physician involvement to address these concerns.
* The impact of preconceptional carrier screening on healthcare budgets and resources.
* Screening programs should balance health gains with costs and ensure informed reproductive choices.
* High numbers of carriers or false positives may increase healthcare visits and follow-up costs.
* Commercial companies claim users will pay out-of-pocket, but follow-up often occurs in traditional healthcare systems.
* Ensuring tests are suitable, have known predictive value, and provide quality information and counselling",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
642,"<summary>
* Substantial growth in operative fracture treatment options has occurred due to newer and better internal fixation devices.

column2: ** Specially designed intramedullary (IM) nails, plates, and screws have increased treatment efficacy and union rates.
** Titanium alloys and stainless steel are commonly used for orthopedic implants.
** After fracture union, implants lose their purpose and remain as foreign objects in the body.

column1: * The debate over the removal of asymptomatic hardware continues, with no clear guidelines.

column2: ** Presumed benefits of removal include functional improvement and pain relief.
** Surgical removal can lead to complications such as neurovascular injury and refractures.
** There are variations in viewpoints on hardware removal among countries and surgeons.

column1: * A study was conducted to investigate common indications for implant removal and identify which implants are most likely to require removal.

column2: ** The study included adult patients with hardware-related problems necessitating removal.
** Patients with fixation devices intended for removal after a definite interval were excluded.
** The study was conducted over a 7-month period starting February 2013.

column1: * The most common reason for implant removal was pain, discomfort, or prominent hardware.

column2: ** 39.75% of patients had hardware pain or discomfort.
** The average pain visual analog scale (VAS) score decreased significantly postoperatively.
** The most commonly removed implants included patella tension band wiring and olecranon plates.

column1: * Infection was the second most common reason for implant removal.

column2: ** 28.91% of patients needed hardware removal due to infection.
** The average duration since the first surgery was 47.57 months.
** Infection subsided in 87.5% of patients after removal.

column1: * Implant failure was another significant reason for removal.

column2: ** 9.52% of patients required removal and revision osteosynthesis for implant failure.
** Commonly failed implants included femoral IM nails and distal tibial locked plates.
** Reasons for failure included poor quality implants and faulty operative techniques.

column1: * Some patients demanded implant removal despite being asymptomatic.

column2: ** 20.48% of patients had implants removed on demand.
** Some of these patients developed complications such as persistent pain and superficial wound infections.
** Difficulty in removing hardware from the bone was a common obstacle during surgery.

column1: * The study concluded that routine removal of asymptomatic implants should not be practiced.

column2: ** Removal surgeries are associated with risks such as fractures, bleeding, and nerve injuries.
** The removal procedure may not always fulfill the",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 643,"<summary>

• The study investigates the effects of α-aminoadipic acid (AAA) on Müller cell gliosis and retinal ganglion cell (RGC) protection in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH), which mimics glaucoma.

column3: •• AAA treatment significantly reduced retinal thickness loss and RGC apoptosis in AOH-induced retinas compared to phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) control.
•• Immunohistochemistry and Western blot analyses showed that AAA treatment attenuated Müller cell gliosis and decreased tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) levels in the retina.
•• The findings suggest that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target for neurodegeneration in glaucoma by inhibiting Müller cell gliosis and downregulating TNF-α production.

column1: • Experimental procedures involved inducing AOH in adult male Sprague Dawley rats and treating them with PBS or AAA, followed by various analyses to assess retinal changes.

column3: •• AOH was induced by elevating intraocular pressure (IOP) to 110 mmHg for 60 minutes, and AAA was injected into the vitreous humor after 3 hours of IOP elevation.

•• Retinal sections were analyzed using immunohistochemistry for markers such as Thy-1 (RGC marker), glutamine synthetase (Müller cell marker), and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP, gliosis marker).
•• Western blot analysis was performed to measure retinal protein levels of TNF-α, and statistical analyses were conducted to determine the significance of the findings.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
644,"<summary>
* Laparoscopy-assisted endoscopic full-thickness resection with ligation device (LAEFTR-L) is a new technique developed to treat nonampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (SDNs).

column2: * It aims to avoid the complications associated with conventional endoscopic resection and surgical treatments.
* The procedure involves using a forward-viewing endoscope and a ligation device to resect the tumor without exposing the peritoneal cavity to malignant cells.

column1: * The study evaluated the efficacy and safety of LAEFTR-L in 5 patients from June to September 2015.

column2: * All patients underwent successful complete resection with no complications.
* The mean operative time was 173 minutes, and patients resumed a normal diet two days post-procedure.

column1: * LAEFTR-L offers advantages over conventional full-thickness resection (FTR) methods.

column2: * It avoids peritoneal exposure of tumor cells by retrieving the specimen intraluminally.
* The procedure does not require extensive experience in endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD).

column1: * Limitations and considerations for LAEFTR-L include tumor size and location.

column2: * Lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter are suitable candidates for this procedure.
* The technique is not applicable to lesions close to the ampulla of Vater due to technical difficulties in mobilization.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
645,"<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis.

column2: •• 90-95% of CAH cases are due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD).
•• This leads to androgen excess, causing ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid growth in both sexes.

column1: • CAH has been effectively managed since the discovery of cortisone in the 1950s.

column2: •• Typical treatment includes oral glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.
•• These treatments compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies and suppress adrenal androgens.

column1: • Four cases of CAH patients managed with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are reported.

column2: •• Adrenal masses were found in all four cases via abdominal CT scans.
•• Two cases required adrenalectomy due to increasing mass size and virilization.

column1: • CAH is an autosomal recessive condition involving mutations in the cytochrome P450 21-hydroxylase gene.

column2: •• The gene CYP21A2, located on chromosome 6p21.3, is responsible for active 21-hydroxylase.
•• More than 90% of mutations are due to recombinations between the active gene and its inactive pseudogene.

column1: • The pathophysiology of CAH is linked to the degree of enzyme deficiency.

column2: •• A defect in cortisol biosynthesis leads to increased CRH and ACTH secretion.
•• This results in hyperplastic adrenal glands and a state of hypocortisolism, hypoaldosteronism, and hyperandrogenism.

column1: • CAH is classified as classic (severe) or non-classic (mild/late-onset).

column2: •• Classic CAH is further subclassified as salt-losing or non-salt-losing (simple virilizing).
•• Non-classic CAH may be asymptomatic or show signs of androgen excess during childhood or puberty.

column1: • Diagnosis of CAH can be done through newborn screening programs.

column2: •• High concentrations of 17-hydroxyprogesterone in blood samples are diagnostic.
•• The gold standard is a corticotropin stimulation test measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels.

column1: • Medical treatment aims to suppress adrenal androgens without impairing growth.

column2: •• Glucocorticoids are given in doses sufficient to suppress CRH and ACTH secretion.

column1: 646,"<summary>
* Self-rated health (SRH) is a validated predictor of mortality and is influenced by lifestyle behaviors such as diet and physical activity.

column2: * SRH is measured on a five-point scale and has been widely used in various populations.
* Poor SRH is associated with chronic disease symptoms like tiredness, depression, and musculoskeletal pains.
* High fruit and vegetable intake and regular physical activity are linked to better SRH.
* Poor SRH is often reported by those with poor management of chronic diseases and unhealthy lifestyle behaviors.

column1: * The study examined the relationship between dietary and physical activity behaviors and SRH in a diverse population.

column2: * Data was collected from the Living for Health program in Miami-Dade County, focusing on low-income minority communities.
* Participants were categorized based on their SRH responses, dietary habits, and physical activity levels.
* Logistic regression models were used to analyze the data, adjusting for variables like age, BMI, smoking status, ethnicity, health insurance, and comorbidities.
* Significant differences in SRH were found based on gender, age, obesity, ethnicity, comorbidities, and lifestyle behaviors.

column1: * Gender differences were observed in the association between lifestyle behaviors and SRH.

column2: * Females reported poorer SRH, higher obesity rates, and lower physical activity levels compared to males.
* Low fruit and vegetable intake and high-fat food consumption were linked to poor SRH in both genders.
* Physical activity had a stronger association with SRH in females than in males.
* The study suggests that gender-specific interventions may be needed to improve SRH and prevent cardiovascular diseases.

647,"<summary>

* The endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (dx/ha) has become a popular alternative to open surgery for treating vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) in children, with success rates varying between 55% and 89%.

column2: * ** Despite its minimally invasive nature and quick recovery times, the procedure has a lower success rate compared to open surgery, necessitating further testing and potential reinjections.

column1: * Positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography is used to detect occult VUR and assess the success of dx/ha injections intraoperatively, but it only achieves an 80% correlation with postoperative cystograms.

column2: * ** While PIC cystography can identify de novo contralateral VUR and prevent postoperative issues, it cannot replace the need for postoperative studies due to its limited predictive accuracy.

648,"<summary>
* The accuracy of detecting fetal pathology depends on the expertise of the sonographer and inherent limitations of ultrasound.

column2: * Maternal obesity, oligohydramnios, and fetal head descent affect ultrasound sensitivity.
* MRI has become increasingly important in diagnosing prenatal anomalies.
* MRI is particularly useful for central nervous system pathology.

column1: * MRI is an adjunct to ultrasound for diagnosing ventriculomegaly.

column2: * Ventriculomegaly is defined by the diameter of the lateral ventricles exceeding 10 mm.
* Severity is classified as mild (10-12 mm), moderate (12-15 mm), and severe (>15 mm).
* Measurement errors can occur due to off-axis imaging or improper boundary selection.

column1: * Causes of ventriculomegaly include cerebrospinal fluid imbalance, abnormal cerebral development, and destructive disease processes.

column2: * Unilateral ventriculomegaly is often due to destructive processes.
* Bilateral ventriculomegaly is more common in developmental anomalies.
* Additional anomalies are reported in 70-85% of cases.

column1: * Fetal MRI is mainly performed on 1.5 tesla scanners.

column2: * No adverse health effects have been demonstrated for short-term exposure.
* HASTE sequence is commonly used for its short acquisition times and good signal-to-noise ratio.
* T1-weighted imaging is used for detecting hemorrhages or calcifications.

column1: * MRI has limitations such as fetal motion impact and relatively low spatial resolution.

column2: * MRI has excellent contrast resolution, differentiating gray and white matter.
* MRI can visualize cortical regions and the posterior fossa without sonographic limitations.
* Knowledge of normal cerebral development is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

column1: * MRI is sensitive in detecting small intraventricular blood deposits and corpus callosum dysgenesis.

column2: * MRI can screen for additional malformations like cortical anomalies and interhemispheric cysts.
* Accurate characterization of anomalies is important for prognosis and parental counseling.
* MRI is effective for assessing the posterior fossa in suspicious ultrasound findings.

column1: * MRI is useful for detecting cortical malformations and congenital infections.

column2: * MRI is ideal for cortical evaluation due to excellent tissue contrast.
* MRI can detect pathological white matter changes and cortical malformations from infections.
* MRI can identify focal brain tissue loss, hemorrhages, and ventriculitis sequelae.

column1: * MRI has a limited role over ultrasound in assessing cerebral ventricle size.

column2: * MRI is useful when fetal position and calvar",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 649,"<summary>
* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer in the US and the leading cause of cancer-related deaths.
* The American Cancer Society estimated 226,160 new lung cancer cases and 160,340 deaths in 2012.
* Lung cancer is often diagnosed at an advanced stage due to asymptomatic early-stage disease.
* SEER data from 1999-2006 showed 56% of cases had distant metastasis at diagnosis.
* Bone is a frequent site of metastasis in lung cancer patients, leading to skeletal-related events (SREs).
* SREs include pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and severe pain requiring treatment.
* The study focused on older lung cancer patients using SEER and Medicare data to analyze bone metastasis and SREs.
* The cohort included patients aged 65+ diagnosed between July 1999 and December 2005.
* 19.8% of patients had evidence of bone metastasis, with 51% of these experiencing SREs.
* The median time from cancer diagnosis to bone metastasis was 5.4 months.
* Bone metastasis was associated with higher mortality, with hazard ratios (HRs) of 2.4 for both bone metastasis with and without SREs.
* HRs varied by stage, with localized stage showing the highest HRs for bone metastasis.
* The study found no significant difference in mortality between patients with bone metastasis with SREs and those without SREs.
* This may be due to the short survival time in lung cancer patients.
* Limitations include the study's focus on patients aged 65+ with Medicare coverage and potential under-diagnosis of bone metastasis.
* Results may not be generalizable to younger patients or those with different insurance coverage.

650,"<summary>
• Fiber-reinforced posts offer superior esthetics and physical properties compared to cast posts.

column3: •• They are cemented with resin cements, which influence retention and restoration success.
•• Self-adhesive resin cements are less investigated but have satisfactory esthetic and mechanical properties.

column1: • Self-adhesive resin cements reduce application steps by eliminating dentin pre-treatment.

column3: •• They chemically react with hydroxyapatite crystals in the tooth.
•• They are resistant to moisture and release fluoride similar to glass ionomer cements.

column1: • Removing the smear layer is crucial for adhesive system penetration and resin cement bonding.

column3: •• Self-adhesive resin cements cannot completely remove the smear layer.
•• Sodium hypochlorite, EDTA, orthophosphoric acid, and lasers are used to remove the smear layer.

column1: • The study compared traditional irrigation systems and photodynamic diode laser on bond strength.

column3: •• 55 maxillary central incisors were used, divided into 5 groups with different treatments.
•• The highest bond strength was observed with the photodynamic diode laser and orthophosphoric acid.

column1: • Results indicated that different smear layer removal methods affect bond strength.

column3: •• Photodynamic diode laser increased bond strength without removing the smear layer.
•• Sodium hypochlorite and saline were ineffective in removing the smear layer.

651,"<summary>
• Recent efforts to study the mammalian gastrointestinal microbiome have led to significant findings.

column2: •• Major initiatives like the Human Microbiome Project and MetaHIT aim to characterize microbial communities and their correlation with diseases.
•• Studies show that gut microbiota composition is influenced by environment and maternal input rather than genetics.
•• High-throughput studies reveal significant interindividual differences in gut microbiota, with only a small core of shared bacterial species and genes.

column1: • The concept of enterotypes has emerged, classifying human gut microbiomes into three distinct clusters.

column2: •• Enterotypes are not influenced by geography, sex, age, or BMI but are associated with long-term diet.
•• Each enterotype has unique bacterial species and functional properties, such as energy harvesting methods and specific gene enrichments.
•• The enterotype concept requires further validation but holds potential for understanding health and disease correlations.

column1: • Gut microbiota plays a role in host energy balance and metabolism, influencing conditions like obesity.

column2: •• Germ-free mice studies show protection from diet-induced obesity, highlighting the role of gut bacteria in energy harvest.
•• Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) produced by gut bacteria are linked to increased body weight and adiposity.
•• Changes in gut microbiota composition, such as shifts from Bacteroidetes to Firmicutes, are associated with obesity in animal models.

column1: • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is linked to altered gut microbiota and genetic factors.

column2: •• Dysbiosis, characterized by reduced bacterial diversity and specific bacterial shifts, is associated with IBD development.
•• Genetic mutations in immune regulation genes, such as NOD2 and ATG16L1, contribute to IBD susceptibility and altered microbiota.
•• Certain bacterial species, like Prevotella and TM7, are associated with colitogenic microbiota and IBD pathology.

column1: • Gut microbiota influences various host responses beyond the gut, including liver function, glucose metabolism, and behavior.

column2: •• Microbiota-derived metabolites, such as methylamines, are linked to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and cardiovascular risk.
•• Gut bacteria can affect central nervous system (CNS) regulation, influencing behavior and stress responses.
•• The gut-brain axis allows microbiota to impact brain function, highlighting the importance of microbial influence on overall health.

652,"<summary>
* Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail, primarily caused by dermatophytes, yeasts (Candida), and nondermatophytes.

column2: * Dermatophytes like Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes are the most common, especially in toenails.
* Risk factors include aging, reduced peripheral circulation, diabetes, and sometimes nail psoriasis.

column1: * Treatment of onychomycosis is challenging due to factors like slow nail growth and thick subungual hyperkeratosis.

column2: * Topical and systemic antifungals are commonly used, but patient adherence is crucial due to long treatment durations.
* Newer drugs with better safety and efficacy profiles are needed, as current treatments have limited success.

column1: * A study investigated the efficacy of tazarotene 0.1% gel for treating distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis.

column2: * The study included 15 patients aged 14-70, treated for 12 weeks with daily application of tazarotene.
* Results showed complete clinical healing in all patients by the end of the study, with significant reduction in onycholysis, discoloration, and hyperkeratosis.

column1: * Tazarotene demonstrated fungistatic activity in vitro against various fungi, including T. mentagrophytes and C. albicans.

column2: * The study highlighted tazarotene's potential as an alternative treatment for onychomycosis, especially in cases with significant nail thickening.
* Further studies with larger patient cohorts and longer follow-up are needed to confirm its efficacy and monitor relapse rates.

653,"<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) is a key treatment for heart failure and left ventricular (LV) dyssynchrony.

column2: •• However, 25-35% of patients do not respond to CRT.

column1: • The study focused on patients who did not respond to CRT despite 6 months of therapy and adequate medical treatment.

column2: •• 24 non-consecutive patients, mostly male, with an average age of 72.8 years and mean ejection fraction of 22.5%, participated.

column1: • Acute haemodynamic response (AHR) was measured using endocardial pacing at various LV sites.

column2: •• A rise in LVdp/dtmax of 15% from baseline was considered a positive haemodynamic response.

column1: • 5 patients showed a significant increase in LVdp/dtmax with the implanted coronary sinus system after optimization.

column2: •• In 3 of these patients, endocardial pacing did not further increase LVdp/dtmax.

column1: • 9 out of 19 patients with an AHR from the implanted system <15% showed an increase above the 15% limit with endocardial pacing.

column2: •• The average AHR with the coronary sinus system was 9.6%, while at the optimal LV endocardial position it was 25.8%.

column1: • The study found that basal or mid-posterolateral segments had the highest AHR.

column2: •• 85% of patients with an AHR >15% had the longest Q-LV interval at the optimal endocardial site.

column1: • 10 patients were considered for LV endocardial pacing, with 5 agreeing to the procedure.

column2: •• All five patients showed clinical improvement with a reduction of at least 1 NYHA class after 6 months.

column1: • The study highlighted the importance of lead location for clinical response.

column2: •• None of the patients with a coronary sinus lead in a posterolateral position improved with endocardial pacing.

column1: • The study suggests that epicardial pacing at the optimal site may be a good alternative to endocardial LV lead placement.

column2: •• Larger randomized studies are needed to justify the technique of LV endocardial pacing.

654,"<summary>
* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in 500 to 1 in 1000 individuals and is present in all racial and ethnic groups.

column2: * The disease often becomes clinically apparent in the third or fourth decade of life.
* About half of the patients progress to renal failure.
* Risk factors for rapid progression include hypertension, renal hemorrhage, multiple pregnancies, male gender, and PKD1 genotype.
* Complications during pregnancy include hypertension, preeclampsia, anemia, and infected renal and hepatic cysts.

column1: * A 35-year-old full-term primigravida with ADPKD and oligohydramnios underwent an emergency lower segment cesarean section (LSCS).

column2: * Diagnosed with ADPKD in the seventh month due to flank pain, swelling, and decreased urine output.
* Hemodialyzed thrice a week for two months to maintain acceptable biochemical parameters.
* Preoperative investigations showed mild proteinuria, pus cells in urine, and elevated serum creatinine.
* Spinal anesthesia was administered successfully, and a 2.0 kg live male child was delivered.

column1: * Postoperative care included maintaining normal hemodynamic and biochemical parameters.

column2: * The patient did not require further hemodialysis postoperatively.
* No neurological deficits were observed.
* She was shifted to the nephrology unit after 72 hours and discharged on day 7.
* Women with moderate or severe antenatal renal insufficiency often experience deterioration of renal functions during pregnancy.

column1: * The pathophysiology of pregnancy exacerbating renal disease is not fully understood.

column2: * One hypothesis suggests increased glomerular perfusion causes further kidney injury.
* Another hypothesis involves preexisting renal disease inducing platelet aggregation and microvascular injury.
* Increased cardiac output and decreased intrarenal vascular resistance during pregnancy increase renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
* Serum creatinine concentration greater than 0.8 mg/dl and BUN concentration greater than 13 mg/dl suggest renal insufficiency during pregnancy.

column1: * Management of pregnant patients on hemodialysis includes frequent and longer sessions.

column2: * Early dialysis is recommended when GFR is approximately 10 ml/min.
* Problems include vascular access, cardiovascular instability, fluid and electrolyte shifts, and need for anticoagulation.
* Fetal heart rate monitoring is recommended during hemodialysis.
* BUN levels are kept below",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 655,"<summary>
* The study examines the pattern of milk yield in cows, focusing on the biological efficiency and persistency of lactation.

column2: * High persistency is linked to a slow decline in milk production.
* Low persistency is linked to a rapid decline in milk production.
* Heritability estimates for milk yield and persistency traits have been reported.
* Lactation curve models predict milk yield at any point of lactation.

column1: * Data was collected from 11,728 fortnightly test-day milk yields of 733 Karan Fries cows over 12 years.

column2: * The climate of the farm is subtropical with temperatures ranging from 2°C to 45°C.
* Annual rainfall is between 760 to 960 mm, mostly in July and August.
* Test-day milk yield is recorded over 24 hours and expressed in kilograms.
* Fortnightly intervals of 15 days were considered from the 6th to the 305th day of lactation.

column1: * The study used a gamma type function to analyze the data.

column2: * The equation used was yt = atbect.
* Constants were derived by transforming the equation on the log scale.
* Peak milk yield was attained in the 3rd and 4th fortnights.
* Both normal and mastitis cows showed a steady decline in milk yield with increased fortnights.

column1: * The study found differences in milk yield patterns between normal and mastitis cows.

column2: * Normal cows had higher initial milk yield compared to mastitis cows.
* Peak milk yield was higher in the 4th parity for both groups.
* The descending slope parameter was higher in later parities.
* Higher persistency was observed in the 1st parity, declining in subsequent parities.

column1: * The gamma function model was validated for predicting milk yield.

column2: * High goodness of fit (r value) was observed.
* RMSE values were low, indicating model accuracy.
* The model was effective for both normal and mastitis cows.
* Similar trends in lactation curves were observed in both groups.

column1: * The study supports the use of lactation curve parameters as markers for persistency.

column2: * Steeper rise in ascending slope from the 1st parity onwards.
* Higher initial milk yield in subsequent parities.
* Steeper decline in descending slope parameter.
* Validity of gamma type function confirmed by higher r and lower RMSE values.

656,"<summary>
* Male B6C3F1 mice were assigned to treatment groups at 12 months of age and fed NDGA-supplemented diets.

column2: * NDGA doses were 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, or 4.5 g/kg diet, with food consumption and health monitored regularly.

column1: * The study used an unbalanced statistical design to compare multiple treatments to a common control.

column2: * Weibull survival analysis and Kaplan-Meier survival curves were used to assess lifespan differences.

column1: * NDGA at 3.5 g/kg diet extended median lifespan by 12% but did not affect maximum lifespan.

column2: * Higher and lower doses of NDGA were ineffective in extending lifespan.

column1: * NDGA consumption was associated with increased incidence of liver, lung, and thymus tumors.

column2: * Despite increased tumor numbers, NDGA decreased the size of liver tumors by 24%.

column1: * Clinical chemistries showed no acute liver or kidney toxicity from NDGA.

column2: * Elevated triglyceride and glucose levels were observed, likely due to altered energy homeostasis.

column1: * NDGA extended the lifespan of Drosophila without affecting food consumption, body weight, or locomotor activity.

column2: * This suggests phylogenetically conserved targets and mechanisms of action between mice and flies.

column1: * NDGA's potential mechanisms for extending lifespan include inhibition of mTORC1 and IGF1R signaling.

column2: * However, NDGA also induced cancers, indicating possible molecular damage at optimal dosages.

657,"<summary>
* Genetic variation plays a crucial role in disease susceptibility and treatment response.

column2: * Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified genetic variants linked to complex diseases.
* Personalized medicine aims to improve medical decision-making through genetic insights.
* Applications include drug optimization, preventive interventions, and targeted treatments.

column1: * Biomarkers are essential for personalized medicine, with diverse definitions and applications.

column2: * Biomarkers can be substances or structures measured in the body to predict disease outcomes.
* Definitions vary, but a common one is from the Biomarkers Definitions Working Group (2001).
* Biomarkers are categorized into types like cancer biomarkers, diagnostic biomarkers, and prognostic biomarkers.

column1: * DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers have distinct characteristics.

column2: * DNA biomarkers are stable and reproducible, suitable for retrospective and prospective studies.
* DNA tumor biomarkers can vary within a tumor and are not typically used as surrogate markers.
* General biomarkers are continuous and can be used for therapy monitoring and pharmacodynamics.

column1: * Biomarker validation involves multiple phases, from discovery to health economics studies.

column2: * Phase I includes discovery, assay development, and retrospective validation.
* Phase II focuses on refining detection properties and developing algorithms.
* Phase III and IV involve prospective investigation, randomized controlled trials, and cost-effectiveness studies.

column1: * Regulatory guidelines and study designs are crucial for validating predictive biomarkers.

column2: * The FDA and EMA have procedures for co-developing drugs and companion diagnostics.
* Study designs include traditional randomized-control, biomarker-stratified, and adaptive designs.
* Proper validation ensures biomarkers are effective and safe for clinical use.

column1: * Reporting standards and transparency are vital for biomarker study credibility.

column2: * Reporting guidelines like STARD and REMARK improve study quality and readability.
* Validation of predictive biomarkers must be linked to specific therapies.
* Ethnically homogeneous populations may help detect biomarker effects in clinical trials.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
658,"<summary>
• The study investigates the flexural stiffness of myosin Va (myova) and its subdomains using tethered particle microscopy (TPM).

column2: •• Myova is a molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton.
•• The motor's processive movement is driven by ATP hydrolysis and amplified by lever arms.
•• High calcium levels reduce motor processivity by causing calmodulin dissociation from lever arms.
•• TPM was used to measure the flexural stiffness of myova constructs by analyzing the motion of quantum dots attached to the motor.

column1: • The results highlight the importance of lever arm stiffness and the compliance of the lever arm/rod junction in myova's function.

column2: •• Lever arms must be rigid to ensure proper gating and control of motor processivity.
•• The lever arm/rod junction's compliance allows myova to maneuver through actin intersections.
•• Calcium-induced calmodulin dissociation decreases lever arm stiffness, affecting motor function.
•• The study provides insights into the structural components critical for myova's functional capacities.

659,"<summary>

* The study aimed to determine if clinical outcomes after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
* Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped in 346 esophageal cancer patients.
* Associations with disease-free survival (DFS) were analyzed using Kaplan-Meier curves and Cox regression, adjusting for potential confounders.
* Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and DFS in patients with EAC or ESCC.
* Multivariate analysis revealed that EAC patients with the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) T/G genotype had significantly improved DFS.
* EAC patients with the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) GA/GA genotype had significantly reduced survival.
* The study suggests that inter-individual differences in germ-line DNA impact DFS in patients with EAC.
* The MDM2 T/G and CDH1 GA/GA genotypes confer risk of death in patients with EAC.
* These findings highlight the potential of host genetic variability in identifying individuals with better survival chances.
* Comprehensive preoperative staging has improved patient selection for potentially curative surgery, but many patients still present with recurrent disease within 2 years post-operation.
* The majority of these patients develop loco-regional recurrences and distant metastases.
* Despite attempts to improve outcomes, prognosis remains poor with a 5-year overall survival rate of 20-30%.
* The study of host genetic variability offers potential to identify individuals with the best chance of survival.
* SNPs in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes can lead to differences in protein expression and function.
* These differences can alter the risk for metastatic or aggressive tumors, affecting clinical outcomes.
* The study involved 346 esophageal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection with curative intent.
* Genotyping was complete in 95-100% of EAC and ESCC patients.
* The genotype distributions did not deviate from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.
* The study found that the MDM2 T/G genotype was associated with improved survival, while the CDH1 GA/GA genotype was associated with",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
660,"<summary>
• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic fungal infection in HIV-positive patients, with Candida albicans being the most frequently isolated species.

column2: •• OPC can manifest as erythematous patches or white, scrapable lesions and is often one of the first clinical signs of HIV infection.

column1: • The study evaluated the forms of OPC and their correlation with CD4+ cell counts in HIV patients over a 2-year period using quantitative data collection methods.

column2: •• The majority of patients with OPC had CD4+ cell counts below 200 cells/mm³, and pseudomembranous candidiasis was the most common clinical presentation.

column1: • Diagnosis and treatment of OPC are crucial in HIV-positive patients, especially those with CD4+ counts below 200 cells/mm³, as they are more susceptible to oral lesions.

column2: •• Fluconazole is generally effective in treating OPC, but resistance can develop, particularly in non-albicans Candida species.

column1: • The study found that 76% of participants had Candida species isolated from their oral cavity, with a higher prevalence of oral lesions in patients with lower CD4+ counts.

column2: •• The findings emphasize the need for continued awareness and management of OPC as a significant clinical sign in the HIV population.

661,"<summary>
• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with 1.67 million new cases annually.
• The disease spreads via the lymphatic system to locoregional lymph nodes.
• Sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) are the first draining nodes from a primary tumor.
• Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is crucial for staging and prognosis.
• The combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is the standard method for SLNB.
• The combined technique involves injecting a radioactive tracer and blue dye.
• Tracers are detected using a handheld scintillation counter (gamma probe) and visually.
• The gamma probe helps localize SLNs and determine the incision site.
• SLNs are removed and sent for histopathological examination.
• The technique has a 96% identification rate and a 5-10% false-negative rate.
• Drawbacks of the combined technique include stringent regulations and limited access to radioisotopes.
• Only 60% of patients in the Western world have access to SLNB.
• Alternative techniques are being explored, such as magnetic tracers.
• Magnetic tracers offer a radiation-free alternative.
• Superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO) tracers have been evaluated in clinical trials.
• SPIO tracers are administered interstitially and identified with a handheld magnetometer.
• The magnetic technique is noninferior to the combined technique.
• Identification rates range from 94.4% to 98.0%.
• There is a discordance in SLNs identified between techniques.
• Differences in particle size may influence SLN identification.
• A study evaluated three different-sized SPIO-based formulations in a porcine model.
• Tracers used were ferumoxytol, Sienna+, and ferumoxide.
• All tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration for comparison.
• Ethical permission was granted for animal experimentation.
• The porcine model closely resembles human lymphatic drainage.
• Mini-pigs were injected with magnetic tracers and measurements were taken at various intervals.
• Hotspots were marked and SLNs were removed for analysis.
• Ex vivo magnetometer counts were recorded.
• SLNs were defined as nodes with counts higher than 10% of the hottest node.
• Groin node clearance was performed to check for missed SLNs.
• Iron content in SLNs was quantified using vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM).
• V",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
662,"<summary>
* The study investigated serum vaspin and adiponectin levels in subjects with and without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and renal insufficiency (RI).

column2: * Serum vaspin levels showed no significant difference between patients with RI and those without RI.
* Serum vaspin levels were lower in diabetic patients compared to non-diabetic individuals.
* Serum adiponectin levels were higher in individuals with RI compared to those without RI.

column1: * Serum vaspin and adiponectin levels were analyzed in relation to various clinical parameters.

column2: * Serum vaspin levels were related to creatinine in non-diabetic patients and to age, systolic blood pressure (SBP), and uric acid in diabetic patients.
* Serum adiponectin levels were related to age, SBP, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP), creatinine clearance (CrCl), and creatinine in non-diabetic subjects.
* In diabetic patients, serum adiponectin levels were related to fasting blood glucose (FBG) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C).
* Multiple regression analyses showed that HbA1c was significantly associated with vaspin concentration, and CrCl was significantly associated with adiponectin concentration.

column1: * Gender differences were observed in serum vaspin and adiponectin levels.

column2: * Both serum vaspin and adiponectin levels were higher in women than in men.
* This trend was consistent in both total subjects and patients with T2DM.
* The study suggests that sex differences and vascular complications may influence serum vaspin levels.
* Adiponectin levels were higher in patients with lower body mass index (BMI), particularly in those with RI.

663,"<summary>

•• Data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials were used to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.

column2: •• The first study was a dose-exploratory trial in five hospitals with patients receiving intralesional injections of rhEGF at 75 or 25 µg, three times per week.
•• The second study was a confirmatory trial in 20 hospitals with patients randomized to rhEGF 75 µg, rhEGF 25 µg, or a placebo group.

column1: •• The total number of ulcers included in the analyses was 190, with additional data from an active postmarketing surveillance of rhEGF treatment in 1,440 DFUs.

column2: •• Diabetic patients (type 1 or 2), both sexes, >18 years of age with Wagner grade 3 or 4 DFUs >1 cm were included.
•• Patients with chronic, uncontrolled illness, psychiatric or neurologic diseases, neoplasia, or who were pregnant or breastfeeding were excluded.

column1: •• Surrogate markers of complete healing were generated: percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment (EOT).

column2: •• Ulcer areas and percent granulation were measured by planimetry using a validated portable wound measurement device.
•• Continuous variables are expressed as mean ± SD or median (25th and 75th percentiles).

column1: •• The area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was calculated for each candidate surrogate variable to evaluate its capacity and quality of discrimination among individuals.

column2: •• Cutoff points were generated to maximize both sensitivity and specificity.
•• The candidate surrogates were codified, and their association with the final outcome (complete ulcer closure) was assessed.

column1: •• Granulation tissue covering >75% of the ulcer area at the end of treatment was the most efficient predictor, with 79.5% correct classification and a high negative predictive value (93.5%).

column2: •• An earlier evaluation of this surrogate marker (granulation tissue covering >50% of the ulcer area at 2 weeks) was also adequate.

664,"<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults.

column2: * However, it is associated with higher early postoperative pain and subsequent chronic pain.

column1: * Modified TAPP repairs by needlescopic surgery (nTAPP) and single-incision laparoscopic surgery (sTAPP) have shown promising results.

column2: * nTAPP uses smaller trocars, while sTAPP reduces the number of ports to one umbilical port.

column1: * A study compared perioperative trauma and postoperative impact between nTAPP and sTAPP.

column2: * 85 patients with single-sided primary inguinal hernia were recruited for the study.

column1: * Demographic and surgical data were collected retrospectively.

column2: * Data included gender, age, BMI, hernia location and size, operative time, and hospital stay length.

column1: * Postoperative assessments included pain, abdominal wall mobility, cosmetic satisfaction, and sick leave duration.

column2: * Pain was measured using the visual analog scale (VAS), and mobility was assessed using Janda's test.

column1: * nTAPP had a significantly shorter operative time compared to sTAPP.

column2: * nTAPP: 54.8 minutes vs. sTAPP: 85.9 minutes (p < .001).

column1: * nTAPP patients experienced less immediate postoperative pain and shorter sick leave.

column2: * nTAPP: 11.2 days vs. sTAPP: 24.1 days (p = .02).

column1: * Both groups had similar long-term outcomes in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.

column2: * Cosmetic satisfaction VAS score: nTAPP 9.7 vs. sTAPP 9.6 (p = .836).

column1: * nTAPP showed advantages in reducing immediate postoperative wound pain and sick leave duration.

column2: * However, chronic groin pain incidence was similar between the groups.

column1: * Randomized controlled trials are needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery.

column2: * Future studies should compare nTAPP, sTAPP, and conventional TAPP repairs.

665,"<summary>
• The breathing process is essential for survival, with nose breathing providing optimal air conditions and mouth breathing lacking filtering and immunological activity.

column2: •• Mouth breathing in childhood can lead to pathological adaptations in facial structures, affecting speech, chewing, and deglutition.
•• Causes of mouth breathing include hypertrophy of tonsils, nasal mucosa edema, nasal septal deviation, and extended suction habits.
•• Multidisciplinary care involving otorhinolaryngologists, odontologists, phonoaudiologists, and others is crucial for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention.

column1: • Accurate diagnosis of mouth breathing causes is essential for effective treatment, with nasopharyngoscopy being the gold standard.

column2: •• Nasopharyngoscopy provides a dynamic, tridimensional view of the nasopharynx, assessing the size and relation of pharyngeal tonsils to other structures.
•• Cephalometry, a noninvasive exam, offers data on craniofacial growth and is more comfortable and cost-effective but tends to underestimate pharyngeal tonsil size.
•• The study aimed to verify the correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing pharyngeal tonsil hyperplasia.

column1: • The study included 55 children aged 7-11 years, excluding those with neurological disorders, craniofacial malformations, syndromes, or pharyngeal surgery history.

column2: •• Children underwent otorhinolaryngologic assessment, nasopharyngoscopy, and cephalometry to check for nasopharyngeal obstruction.
•• Nasopharyngoscopy used a graded scale to assess pharyngeal tonsil hyperplasia, while cephalometry measured the nasopharyngeal space in millimeters.
•• The correlation between the two exams was analyzed using Spearman's rank correlation coefficient.

column1: • Results showed a significant regular and positive correlation (r = 0.52) between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry.

column2: •• Cephalometry had a sensitivity of 35% and a negative predictive value of 72%, suggesting it might underestimate nasopharyngeal obstruction.
•• Nasopharyngoscopy is recommended for children with mouth breathing symptoms and normal radiographic exams for accurate diagnosis.
•• Cephalometry complements nasopharyngoscopy by providing information on facial growth and dental occlusion.

column1: • Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the gold standard for assessing nasopharyngeal obstruction due to its dynamic and tridimensional view.

column2: •• Cephalometry is useful for documenting and monitoring cranio",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 666,"<summary>
• The incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) in patients treated with breast-conserving surgery, systemic adjuvant therapy, and radiation therapy is less than 6%.

column2: •• Differentiating between true local recurrence (TR) and new primary tumor (NPT) is crucial for clinical relevance and therapeutic management.
•• TR is consistent with the regrowth of malignant cells not removed by surgery or not killed by radiotherapy, while NPT arises de novo from mammary epithelial cells.
•• Genetic sequencing and molecular techniques like DNA fingerprinting can help distinguish between TR and NPT, though criteria are not standardized.

column1: • A case study of a 35-year-old woman with a family history of breast cancer showed initial diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and later development of inflammatory breast cancer.

column2: •• Initial treatment included surgery, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormone therapy with tamoxifen.
•• Four years post-surgery, the patient developed IDC again, this time with different immunohistochemical markers, indicating a new primary tumor.
•• The patient received further chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and remains in complete clinical remission after breast reconstruction surgery.

column1: • Breast cancer survivors require careful follow-up and screening due to the risk of IBTR and second primary breast cancers.

column2: •• The risk of second breast cancer depends on factors like ER status, family history, and period of diagnosis.
•• Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for IBTR, but further studies are needed to determine the best systemic therapy.
•• Adjuvant tamoxifen has shown benefits in reducing contralateral and ipsilateral disease recurrence in patients with NPT.

667,"<summary>
* Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and its treatment:
* AMD is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 and older.
* Neovascular AMD, involving choroidal neovascularization (CNV), is the primary cause of severe central vision loss.
* Anti-VEGF therapy, including ranibizumab and aflibercept, has transformed the management of neovascular AMD.
* Aflibercept has a higher binding affinity to VEGF and a longer duration of action compared to ranibizumab.
* Study on switching from ranibizumab to aflibercept:
* The study involved 40 patients with treatment-resistant neovascular AMD.
* Patients were switched to aflibercept after persistent fluid despite ranibizumab treatment.
* The primary endpoint was the change in contrast sensitivity (CS) from baseline to week 12.
* Other outcomes included changes in best corrected visual acuity (BCVA), central retinal thickness (CRT), and vision-related quality of life.
* Results of the study:
* Mean CS increased significantly from 1.32 to 1.40 log units.
* Mean CRT decreased significantly from 354 µm to 332 µm.
* No significant change in mean visual acuity (VA) was observed.
* Two-thirds of patients experienced an improvement in vision-related quality of life.
* Implications and future considerations:
* CS should be considered an important measure of visual function alongside VA.
* The study supports switching anti-VEGF agents in treatment-resistant neovascular AMD patients.
* Larger and longer-term studies are needed to validate these findings.
* Multiple measures of visual function should be explored in future treatment studies of retinal diseases.

668,"<summary>
•• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, causing cognitive and physical impairments.

column2: •• White matter lesions may affect cognition in MS patients.
•• Relapsing-remitting MS is the most common type, found in 85-90% of cases.
•• MS is the third leading cause of asthenic diseases after traumatic and rheumatic diseases.

column1: •• The study aimed to evaluate the association between c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population.

column2: •• 74 patients with relapsing-remitting MS and 75 healthy controls were enrolled.
•• Blood samples were collected from Sina Hospital and Tehran Blood Transfusion Services.
•• The occurrence of MS was confirmed based on McDonald’s criteria and MRI results.

column1: •• Statistical analysis revealed no significant association between c424c/a polymorphism and MS.

column2: •• Genotype frequencies (AA, AC, CC) were not significantly different between MS patients and controls.
•• Allele frequencies (A and C) were also not significantly different between groups.
•• Logistic regression showed no significant odds ratio for MS development with different genotypes.

column1: •• Previous studies suggested decreased serum levels of IL-25 in MS patients compared to healthy controls.

column2: •• Polymorphisms within cytokine genes are associated with their expression.
•• The study hypothesized that c424c/a polymorphism might be associated with MS.
•• Results indicated that c424c/a polymorphism is not important in the pathogenesis of MS.

column1: •• Other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene may regulate its expression and be associated with MS.

column2: •• Polymorphisms like 4076A>A, 3672T>TA, 3712G>GA, and 3463C>CA may play a role.
•• The study's strong point was evaluating c424c/a polymorphism as the first report.
•• The weak point was the lack of evaluation of other polymorphisms and serum levels of IL-25.

column1: •• Larger sample sizes may be needed to better understand the role of c424c/a polymorphism in MS pathogenesis.

column2: •• The study concluded that c424c/a polymorphism is not a risk factor for MS development.
•• Further research is needed to explore other potential genetic factors.
•• The study was approved by the ethics committee of Rafsanjan University of Medical Sciences.

669,"<summary>
• Aortic aneurysms (AAs) can be life-threatening, with aorta size being the best criterion for intervention.

column2: •• Aneurysms of the ascending thoracic aorta (ATA) often result from cystic medial degeneration, while atherosclerosis is a common cause in descending thoracic and abdominal aortas.
•• Elderly males with hypertension are at high risk for both thoracic aortic aneurysms (TAAs) and abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs).

column1: • The study involved 502 Korean male hypertensive patients aged 65 and above, using non-contrast CT to measure aortic diameters.

column2: •• The prevalence of TAA was 36.5%, and AAA was 6.0%, with 3.2% having both TAA and AAA.
•• TAA was associated with older age, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, and absence of dyslipidemia, while AAA was linked to dyslipidemia and smoking history.

column1: • The study found that TAA was more prevalent than AAA among high-risk subjects, contrary to previous reports.

column2: •• Most TAAs had a diameter less than 50 mm, not requiring immediate intervention.
•• The study highlighted the need for further evaluation of TAA screening and management strategies in elderly hypertensive patients.

column1: • The study's limitations include the inability of CT scans to accurately measure the aortic root and its focus on elderly Asian males with hypertension.

column2: •• Results cannot be generalized to females, other ethnicities, or low-risk groups.
