670,"<summary>
•• Endometrial cancer has become the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries.

column2: •• Early screening methods for cervical cancer have improved significantly since the 1950s.

column3: •• This progress is due to better cytologic preparation methods and a unified evaluation system.
•• Drawing from cervical cancer screening success, there is a need for effective endometrial carcinoma screening.

column1: •• Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) are precursors to type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

column2: •• Endometrial glandular dysplasia is the precursor of type II carcinoma.

column2: •• Sensitivity was 73.6%, and specificity was 94.9%.

column3: •• Positive predictive value (PPV) was 71.9%.
•• Negative predictive value (NPV) was 95.3%.

column1: •• The study found no difference in specimen adequacy between SAP-1 and D&C in premenopausal women.

column1: 671,"<summary>
* Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, with nearly 1.7 million new cases in 2012.
* Highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America.
* Screening mammography has been associated with up to a 50% reduction in mortality rate.
* Digital mammography (DM) has largely replaced screen-film mammography (SFM) in the US.
* DM is less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity.
* DM offers some improved benefits in women with dense breast tissue but still has limitations.
* Tomosynthesis (DBT) is a 3D procedure that may help solve the problem of tumors being obscured by overlapping tissue in 2D mammography.
* DBT creates image slices of a tissue volume, reducing the problem of overlapping tissue.
* DBT can be used for both screening and diagnostic mammography.
* Combining DM with DBT improves the accuracy of mammograms.
* Studies show a 40% higher invasive cancer detection rate with DM + DBT compared to DM alone.
* DBT reduces recall rates and false-positive biopsies.
* Radiation dose is a concern with mammography, but DBT systems have been refined to reduce doses.
* Some digital systems using photon-counting detectors reduce doses by 40%-60%.
* Synthesized 2D images from DBT data can eliminate the need for double exposures, reducing radiation dose.
* DBT shows promise in demonstrating the same or higher accuracy as digital spot-compression mammography.
* DBT can eliminate the need for additional mammogram images in many cases.
* DBT may decrease the necessity for extra mammogram views, benefiting radiation dose and patient comfort.
* Contrast-enhanced DM and DBT are being studied to improve tumor detection.
* Contrast-enhanced DM takes advantage of malignant neovascularity.
* Dual-energy CEDM has shown high sensitivity and specificity in detecting breast carcinomas.
* Large population studies and clinical trials are ongoing to further evaluate DBT.
* Studies include the Oslo trial, the STORM trial, and upcoming trials by the American College of Radiology Imaging Network.
* DBT is being integrated with other modalities, such as automated breast ultrasound and computer-assisted detection.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
672,"<summary>
• Over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold medications have been criticized for lack of evidence supporting their efficacy.

column2: • This study demonstrates that diphenhydramine inhibits cough reflex sensitivity and is classified as an antitussive by the FDA.

column1: • The study involved 22 adult nonsmokers with acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI) who were given diphenhydramine, dextromethorphan, or placebo.

column2: • Results showed that diphenhydramine significantly inhibited cough reflex sensitivity compared to placebo, while dextromethorphan did not.

column1: • Capsaicin cough challenge testing was used to measure cough reflex sensitivity, with the concentration of capsaicin inducing 5 or more coughs (C5) as the endpoint.

column2: • The study found that diphenhydramine increased mean log C5 values significantly more than placebo.

column1: • Side effects were reported, with slight drowsiness being the most common for diphenhydramine and dextromethorphan.

column2: • Five subjects reported slight drowsiness after diphenhydramine, and five subjects reported side effects after dextromethorphan.

column1: • The study suggests that further clinical trials are needed to evaluate OTC cough and cold products to provide proper scientific data for informed treatment decisions.

column2: • The study contributes initial evidence demonstrating diphenhydramine's ability to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity in acute pathological cough.

673,"<summary>
• The global population is aging, particularly in developed countries, leading to increased cardiovascular disease prevalence.

column2: • Aging is linked to decreased resistance to cellular stress and is a major risk factor for conditions like diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.

column1: • Endothelial dysfunction, characterized by reduced nitric oxide (NO) production, contributes to atherosclerosis and other vascular disorders.

column2: • NO is crucial for vasodilation, platelet inhibition, and smooth muscle cell regulation, and its production is impaired by oxidative stress.

column1: • Oxidative stress, an imbalance between oxidizing agents and antioxidants, reduces NO bioavailability and promotes endothelial dysfunction.

column2: • Superoxide anions rapidly inactivate NO, leading to the formation of cytotoxic peroxynitrite, which further impairs endothelial function.

column1: • Inflammation plays a significant role in atherosclerosis, with markers like C-reactive protein (CRP) predicting cardiovascular events.

column2: • Aging increases levels of inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, IL-6), which perpetuate a cycle of endothelial dysfunction.

column1: • Exercise is a modifiable risk factor that improves endothelial function and reduces cardiovascular disease risk.

column2: • Regular aerobic exercise enhances NO availability, upregulates antioxidant defenses, and reduces inflammatory markers.

column1: • Exercise-induced oxidative stress triggers adaptive responses, increasing antioxidant enzyme expression and reducing oxidative damage.

column2: • The transcription factor Nrf2 plays a key role in regulating antioxidant defenses and is activated by exercise.

column1: • Exercise also modulates inflammatory responses, increasing anti-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-10) and reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α).

column2: • IL-6, released during exercise, has both pro- and anti-inflammatory effects and enhances lipid metabolism and glucose production.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
674,"<summary>
• Axillary lymph node status is a crucial prognostic factor in breast carcinoma, with prognosis worsening as the number of metastatic lymph nodes increases.

column2: •• The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classifies nodal disease into three groups based on the number of metastatic lymph nodes: N1 (1-3 nodes), N2 (4-9 nodes), and N3 (10 or more nodes).

column1: • The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of lymph nodes removed and examined, making it difficult to assess axillary lymph node status reliably without sufficient removal.

column2: •• Studies show that the number of metastatic lymph nodes increases with the number of removed lymph nodes.

column1: • Lymph Node Ratio (LNR), the ratio of metastatic to removed lymph nodes, provides more useful prognostic information than the number of metastatic lymph nodes alone.

column2: •• Different studies have identified varying LNR threshold values for prognostic significance, with higher thresholds in series excluding N1 disease.

column1: • The study evaluated the prognostic significance of the number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes and LNR in breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 axillary metastatic lymph nodes.

column2: •• Patients with fewer than 6 lymph nodes removed had significantly worse disease-free survival (DFS) and locoregional recurrence-free survival (LRFS) compared to those with more lymph nodes removed.

column1: • The most significant LNR threshold values identified were 0.20 for DFS, 0.30 for LRFS, and 0.15 for distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS).

column2: •• LNR had independent prognostic significance for DFS, LRFS, and DMFS, even when the number of removed lymph nodes was considered.

column1: • Patients with 1 positive node had significantly better DFS and DMFS compared to those with 2-3 positive nodes.

column2: •• Grouping patients based on the number of metastatic lymph nodes showed independent prognostic significance for DFS and DMFS.

column1: • LNR is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes and can be used to separate N1 disease patients into low- and high-risk prognostic groups.

column2: •• This provides more detailed and useful prognostic information than the TNM nodal disease classification, especially for distant metastasis development.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
675,"<summary>
• The classic methodology for activating OH functionality via ester derivatives of strong acids is inefficient and wasteful.
• Enzymatic phosphorylation by kinases using ATP or sulfation by sulfotransferases is more efficient.
• ATP recycling is feasible, but PAPS recycling is not efficient.
• Kinases and sulfotransferases are substrate-specific, limiting broad synthetic applications.
• ATP-independent phosphatases using inorganic polyphosphates are an efficient alternative.
• Phosphatases have a broad substrate spectrum and produce environmentally benign byproducts.
• The main drawback is the reversibility of phosphate transfer, leading to hydrolysis.
• Kinetic control is crucial to minimize hydrolysis and maximize product titers.
• Historical use of phosphatases for synthetic applications dates back to the 1940s.
• Axelrod and Appleyard achieved transphosphorylation using phosphatase-enriched extracts.
• Nordlie identified glucose-pyrophosphotransferase activity in E. coli alkaline phosphatase.
• Asano et al. applied acid phosphatases to nucleoside phosphorylation.
• Phosphatases like PhonSF, PhonSE, and PiACP are efficient in phosphorylating various alcohols.
• PhonSF generally delivered the highest product titers with primary alcohols.
• PhonSE showed preference for secondary alcohols.
• PiACP was selected based on high sequence similarity with robust nucleoside phosphorylation enzymes.
• Reaction conditions such as pH and phosphate donor type significantly affect product formation.
• Lower pH values and high-energy phosphate donors increase product titers.
• Polyphosphoric acid was not fully consumed by PhonSE, indicating preference for short-chain oligophosphates.
• Kinetic control and physical separation of the enzyme can optimize product yields.
• Scale-up was demonstrated using immobilized enzymes in a continuous flow reactor.
• Immobilized PhonSF on Relizyme HA beads showed high specific activity.
• The preparative-scale phosphorylation of 1,4-butanediol yielded 6.86 g of 4-hydroxybutyl phosphate.
• The process is environmentally friendly, producing innocuous byproducts.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
676,"<summary>
* Non-native biological invaders have been noted for centuries.

column2: * Phylloxera devastated European grapevines in the 1860s.
* Chestnut blight eliminated a dominant tree species in North America in the early 20th century.
* Charles Elton's 1957 BBC broadcasts and subsequent book raised awareness but did not spur widespread research or policy response.
* The SCOPE project in the mid-1980s triggered extensive research on invasions.

column1: * Research on invasions has revealed various impacts on native species.

column2: * Non-native invaders can eat, compete with, or infect native species.
* Some invaders vector diseases to native species while competing with them.
* Impacts can occur at population, community, and ecosystem levels.
* Peter Vitousek highlighted ecosystem-level impacts, such as changes in nutrient cycles and hydrology.

column1: * Genetics and evolution have become prominent in invasion biology.

column2: * Molecular genetic techniques reveal hybridization and introgression with native species.
* Hybridization can produce new invasive species, like Spartina anglica.
* Environmental DNA (eDNA) is used to detect invaders.
* Introduced populations often combine genes from multiple sources, creating novel genetic combinations.

column1: * Invasional meltdown and lag effects are significant phenomena.

column2: * Invasional meltdown occurs when introduced species facilitate each other's establishment.
* Lag effects mean that the full impact of an invader may take years to manifest.
* The commonness of lag effects suggests early action is crucial.
* Waiting for impacts to be recognized before acting can be detrimental.

column1: * Critics of invasion biology raise several objections.

column2: * Some argue that problems are overblown and similar impacts arise from native species.
* Others claim that introduced species can increase native biodiversity.
* Some view antipathy toward introduced species as xenophobic.
* Critics also argue that combating invasions is futile and inhumane.

column1: * Risk assessment tools have been developed to predict invasions.

column2: * The Australian Weed Risk Assessment (AWRA) is a prominent tool.
* These tools are not foolproof but have prevented some planned introductions.
* They help identify populations for rapid eradication or containment.
* Biosecurity measures, like those in New Zealand, can be effective.

column1: * Restoration ecology is intertwined with invasion biology.

column2: * Critics argue for abandoning traditional restoration ecology in favor of novel ecosystems.
* Modern restoration ecology aims to re-establish historical trajectories, not recreate the past.
,0,{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 677,"<summary>
• Schwannomas are rare, benign tumors of the nerve sheath that can cause significant morbidity due to nerve involvement or local mass effect.

column2: •• Approximately 25-45% of schwannomas are found in the head and neck, with the vestibular schwannoma being the most common, followed by trigeminal nerve schwannomas.

column1: • Vidian canal schwannomas are extremely rare and can present with various symptoms or be asymptomatic.

column2: •• Treatment options include surgical resection, radiation therapy, or conservative management, with the choice depending on patient factors, tumor characteristics, and potential risks.

678,"<summary>
• Posterior transpedicular pedicle screw fixation is widely used for managing unstable spine fractures, particularly burst fractures.

column2: •• Short-segment fixation, involving screws one vertebra above and below the fracture, is popular but can fail in some cases.
•• Adding intermediate screws at the fracture site improves construct stability and reduces screw breakage.
•• Biomechanical studies show that intermediate screws enhance stability in both monoaxial and polyaxial screw constructs.
•• Polyaxial screws facilitate easier rod installation and reduce stress on the construct compared to monoaxial screws.

column1: • The study used a calf experimental model to compare the stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation with monoaxial and polyaxial screws.

column2: •• Twelve fresh-frozen calf lumbar specimens were used, divided into monoaxial and polyaxial groups.
•• Specimens were tested for flexibility, then an unstable burst fracture was created in the L3 vertebra.
•• Constructs with and without intermediate screws were tested for flexion, extension, lateral bending, and axial rotation.
•• Results showed that intermediate screws significantly decreased the range of motion, indicating enhanced stability.

column1: • The addition of intermediate screws at the fracture level significantly increases the stability of short-segment pedicle fixation.

column2: •• Both monoaxial and polyaxial screw constructs benefit from intermediate screws, with monoaxial showing greater stability in flexion and extension.
•• Polyaxial screws provide better coupling with the connecting rod, reducing torsion and stress on the construct.
•• The study's limitations include the use of an animal model and the lack of comparison with long-segment fixations.
•• Despite limitations, the study supports using intermediate screws for better stabilization in lumbar burst fractures.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
679,"<summary>
• The discovery of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films has opened new synthetic routes for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).

column3: •• ESA bypasses high-temperature sintering, allowing the use of conductive plastic substrates.
•• ZnO/organic dye hybrid thin films show high incident photon to current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of around 90%.
•• CuSCN/dye hybrid thin films are being explored as potential photocathodes for DSSCs.

column1: • The study explores the use of rhodamine B (RB) as a structure-directing agent (SDA) for CuSCN thin films.

column3: •• RB incorporation affects the crystallographic orientation and morphology of CuSCN films.
•• High RB loading leads to highly porous CuSCN films after RB extraction.
•• The films exhibit dye-sensitized photocathodic properties, indicating potential for hole injection from dye excited states.

column1: • Challenges and future directions for improving dye-sensitized CuSCN photocathodes are discussed.

column3: •• Current limitations include the lack of stable hole-injecting dyes and suitable redox electrolytes.
•• Recent progress with p-NiO and Co complex redox systems offers hope for finding suitable combinations for CuSCN.
•• Efficient dye-sensitized CuSCN photocathodes could be combined with existing photoanodes for high-efficiency tandem DSSCs.

680,"<summary>
• Nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the embryonic communication between the notochord and the pharyngeal endoderm.

column2: •• It typically disappears during the second month of fetal development.
•• If obstructed, it can form a Tornwaldt's cyst; if not obstructed but crusts adhere, it forms the crust type.
•• The cystic type is more common and should be part of the differential diagnosis for nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts.

column1: • Symptoms of nasopharyngeal bursitis vary based on the type and can include nasal obstruction, eustachian tube obstruction, and rhinitis.

column2: •• Space-occupying lesions can cause nasal obstruction, dysphagia, and cranial nerve paralysis.
•• Rhinitis symptoms include choanal discharge, halitosis, and pharyngitis.
•• Occipital pain and pulsating headaches are often reported due to the lesion's location.

column1: • The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, with a peak incidence between 15 and 30 years.

column2: •• There is a Caucasian predominance and no gender predilection.
•• Most literature describes the cystic type, with little information on the crust type.
•• The true incidence of crust-type nasopharyngeal bursitis is not well-documented.

column1: • A two-year clinicoanatomical audit was conducted to identify the incidence and clinical presentation of nasopharyngeal bursa disease.

column2: •• The study was performed at a rhinology practice in a university unit during 2008-2009.
•• Six patients (four males and two females, mean age 54 years) were diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis.
•• The incidence was less than 1% of all rhinitis patients seen during the study period.

column1: • Surgical treatment combining endonasal and transoral approaches with electrocauterization was effective.

column2: •• Patients with either cystic or crust type underwent this surgical technique.
•• Complete recovery with no recurrence of symptoms was observed more than one year postoperatively.
•• Endoscopic examination and imaging are crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning.

column1: • Histopathological examination differentiates Tornwaldt's cyst from retention lymphoid cysts.

column2: •• Tornwaldt's cysts are lined with columnar epithelium.
•• Retention lymphoid cysts show lymphoid tissue only.

column1: 681,"<summary>
* The incidence of melanoma skin cancer has been increasing over the past few decades.
* Estimated 76,250 new cases of invasive melanoma were diagnosed in the USA in 2012.
* Australia has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world.
* Early diagnosis of melanoma is crucial for prognosis.
* Dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that improves diagnostic sensitivity by 10-30%.
* Dermoscopy requires significant experience to differentiate skin lesions accurately.
* Inexperienced dermatologists may have lower diagnostic accuracy with dermoscopy.
* Experts achieve 90% sensitivity and 59% specificity in skin lesion diagnosis.
* General practitioners show a significant drop in diagnostic accuracy.
* Diagnosis is highly dependent on subjective judgment and is scarcely reproducible.
* Automated analysis of digitized images has gained interest in the last two decades.
* Computational intelligence methods assist in faster data processing.
* Studies on automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images date back to 1987.
* Machine vision and computerized analysis are becoming increasingly important.
* Numerous computerized diagnostic systems have been reported in the literature.
* Preprocessing of images is essential to reduce artifacts and improve segmentation.
* Artifacts like hair, uneven illumination, and dermoscopic gel can affect border detection.
* Preprocessing steps include image resizing, masking, cropping, and color space transformation.
* Filters like mean, median, and Gaussian are used to smooth images.
* Specialized methods for each artifact type can be more effective.
* Feature extraction is crucial for differentiating malignant melanoma from benign lesions.
* The purpose is to reduce the original data set by measuring differentiating properties.
* Methods include statistical, model-based, and filtering-based approaches.
* Principal component analysis (PCA) and wavelet packet transform (WPT) are commonly used.
* The ABCD-E rule is computationally less expensive and reliable for clinical diagnosis.
* Feature selection is critical for successful classification.
* It aims to find the optimum number of features for the best performance.
* Methods include PCA, sequential forward selection, and correlation-based feature selection.
* The number of features retained is an important parameter.
* Studies show that using 5 to 20 features is enough for acceptable classification results.
* Classification algorithms are used to produce a diagnosis from extracted features.
* Approaches include k-nearest neighbor, decision trees, logistic regression, and neural networks.
* Support vector machines (SVMs)",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
682,"<summary>
* Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a chronic disease characterized by high blood glucose due to insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency.

column2: * Complications include cardiovascular disease, renal failure, and blindness.
* The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) reports 366 million people with diabetes worldwide, expected to rise to 552 million by 2030.
* Approximately 90% of diabetes patients have T2D, influenced by lifestyle and genetic factors.
* The PGC-1 gene is involved in mitochondrial biosynthesis and glucose transport in muscle.

column1: * The study investigates the associations between MFN2 and ESRRA genetic polymorphisms and T2D in Han Chinese.

column2: * 1204 unrelated subjects were included in stage 1, with 555 T2D patients and 649 non-diabetic controls.
* 546 unrelated T2D patients and 419 non-diabetic controls were included in stage 2.
* SNPs in MFN2 and ESRRA genes were selected and genotyped using various methods.
* Logistic regression analysis was used to adjust for sex, age, and BMI.

column1: * Significant associations were found between certain SNPs in the MFN2 gene and T2D.

column2: * The A allele and C allele of rs873458 and rs2878677 in MFN2 gene were protective against T2D.
* Replication in stage 2 populations confirmed the association of the C allele of rs2878677 with lower T2D risk.
* Combined population analysis showed significant effects of rs873458 and rs2878677 on T2D susceptibility.
* No significant association was found for other SNPs in MFN2 or ESRRA genes.

column1: * Haplotype analysis revealed significant associations with T2D.

column2: * A-C-G-T-C and G-T-C-T-C haplotypes in MFN2 gene were significantly associated with T2D.
* No significant differences in haplotypes of ESRRA gene were found in case-control subjects.
* The rs2878677/rs3766741/rs731703/rs11600990 model in MFN2-ESRRA showed significant interactions.
* The rs2878677/rs3774923/rs7656250 model in MFN2-PGC-1 also showed significant interactions.

column1: * The study confirmed that certain alleles in MFN2 gene are associated with higher T2D risk.

column2: * G allele of rs873458 and T",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 683,"<summary>
* Interindividual variations in platelet aggregation during clopidogrel therapy are linked to:
* Reduced exposure to active clopidogrel thiol metabolite.
* Differences in P2Y12 receptor occupancy.
* Carriers of CYP2C19 nonfunctional alleles show reduced platelet inhibition.
* Increased risk of adverse events and stent thrombosis.
* Clopidogrel bioactivation involves two steps:
* Oxidation to 2-oxo-clopidogrel by hepatic CYP450 enzymes.
* Generation of thiol metabolite in the second step.
* Paraoxonase-1 (PON1) may be the rate-limiting enzyme in this process.
* PON1 polymorphism (Q192R) affects enzymatic activity and risk of stent thrombosis.
* Study design and population:
* Conducted by Indiana University School of Medicine.
* Included subjects with coronary disease on dual antiplatelet therapy.
* Excluded subjects with certain medical conditions and drug use.
* Blood samples were analyzed for platelet aggregation and genotyping.
* Genotyping and statistical analysis:
* Subjects were genotyped for CYP2C19*2, CYP2C19*3, and PON1 Q192R SNPs.
* Statistical tests included Student's t-test, Wilcoxon test, and regression analysis.
* Clinical variables affecting platelet reactivity were considered.
* No significant deviations from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium were observed.
* Findings on PON1 Q192R and CYP2C19*2:
* PON1 Q192R was not associated with increased platelet aggregation.
* CYP2C19*2 carriers had higher platelet aggregation and lower platelet inhibition.
* No significant differences in platelet inhibition among PON1 Q192R genotypes.
* CYP2C19*2 polymorphism confirmed as a determinant of reduced platelet inhibition.
* Comparison with previous studies:
* Bouman et al. suggested PON1 Q192R affects clopidogrel response.
* Current study did not find significant association with PON1 Q192R.
* Consistent with Shuldiner et al.'s findings on PON1 gene.
* Confirmed association of CYP2C19*2 with reduced platelet inhibition.
* Study limitations and conclusions:
* Small sample size and lack of pharmacokinetic analysis.
* LTA subject to operator variability.
* PON1",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
684,"<summary>
* Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii, with cats as the primary host and humans as intermediate hosts.

column2: * Most people with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic.
* Pregnant women infected can transmit the parasite to the fetus, causing congenital toxoplasmosis.
* Congenital toxoplasmosis can lead to severe CNS involvement, including hydrocephalus and seizures.
* Seizures are a common symptom in congenital toxoplasmosis with CNS infection.

column1: * A 34-year-old woman with congenital toxoplasmosis presented with medically intractable seizures.

column2: * She had hydrocephalus and underwent VP shunting at 1 month old.
* She experienced decreased visual acuity and had chorioretinitis.
* Toxoplasma-specific IgG test was positive, indicating chronic infection.
* Seizures started with psychic aura and progressed to generalized seizures.

column1: * Despite polytherapy with AEDs, her seizures were poorly controlled.

column2: * She was referred to an epilepsy clinic for further evaluation.
* Brain MRI showed multifocal encephalomalacic changes, left HS, and amygdala hypertrophy.
* Brain CT confirmed parenchymal calcifications compatible with congenital toxoplasmosis.
* Video-EEG monitoring observed complex partial seizures leading to generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

column1: * Ictal and interictal SPECT and FDG-PET were performed.

column2: * Ictal hyperperfusion was seen in bilateral frontotemporal areas.
* Interictal SPECT showed hypoperfusion in the left frontotemporal area.
* SISCOM showed ictal hyperperfusion in left mesial temporal areas.
* FDG-PET demonstrated focal hypermetabolism in left medial temporal cortex.

column1: * Wada test revealed right hemisphere language and memory dominance.

column2: * Predictive of good outcome after left anteromesial temporal resection.
* Seizure focus was determined to be in the left temporal lobe.
* Epilepsy surgery was decided for seizure control.
* Left anteromesial temporal resection including calcified lesion was performed.

column1: * The case highlights the association of congenital toxoplasmosis with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE).

column2: * Infection can cause diffuse and multifocal parenchymal necrosis forming calcifications.
* Distribution and severity of calcifications vary with the date of maternal infection.
* Calcifications correlate with neurologic signs and symptoms.
* HS",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 685,"<summary>
• Approximately 20 million people have gallstones, with 1 million new cases of cholelithiasis diagnosed annually.
• The treatment of cholelithiasis is the most costly digestive disease, exceeding $5 billion annually.
• A 1992 NIH conference concluded laparoscopic cholecystectomy has advantages over open cholecystectomy.
• Reduced pain and disability from laparoscopic cholecystectomy can lead to cost savings for patients and society.
• Charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often surpass those of open cholecystectomy.
• Excess charges are attributed to equipment and technical requirements.
• Maricopa Medical Center identified excessive LOS and charges by comparing with 16 other hospitals.
• Reducing conversion rates or costs for laparoscopic cholecystectomy could help lower charges.
• A study compared charges between open and converted laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• 70 patients were reviewed, matched for age, sex, and diagnosis.
• The average charge for converted laparoscopic cholecystectomy was $19,922, and $13,042 for open cholecystectomy.
• Decision tree analysis showed open cholecystectomy was more cost-effective.
• Reducing charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy could make it more cost-effective.
• Sensitivity analysis indicated a charge of <$12,679.90 would be needed for cost-effectiveness at a 5% conversion rate.
• A reduction of $3,331 in charges would be necessary for all patients to be considered for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• The greater the reduction needed, the less likely efficiency can be achieved.
• Vanek and Borguet reviewed costs in a community hospital.
• Conversion from laparoscopic to open cholecystectomy resulted in a 57% increase in total charges.
• The increase was due to a longer hospital LOS of 4.7 days.
• They found open cholecystectomy charges were $8,160 versus $10,210 for laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• Comparative analysis of studies is challenging due to varying factors.
• Studies include different cholecystectomy categories and elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy patients.
• Geographical and socioeconomic factors, as well as disease severity, affect results.
• Health care payers should evaluate charge data for regional hospitals before contracting.
• Laparoscopic cholec",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
686,"<summary>
•• Type 1 diabetes involves autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells, leading to insulin deficiency.

column2: •• Glucose homeostasis is restored with exogenous insulin, and some patients experience partial remission (PR) or a honeymoon period.

column3: •• PR is characterized by reduced daily insulin requirements (DIR) and optimal glycemia and HbA1c (A1c) levels.
•• PR duration and intensity vary among patients.
•• PR is defined by insulin-dose-adjusted A1c (IDAA1c) levels.
•• Mechanisms underlying PR are largely unknown but may involve residual β-cell mass activity.

column1: •• The study included 242 children with type 1 diabetes, followed from diagnosis to adulthood.

column2: •• Diagnosis was based on ISPAD guidelines, elevated blood glucose, A1c, positive anti-islet antibodies, and lack of family history of genetic diabetes.

column3: •• Biometrics and biological features were collected at diagnosis and each consultation.
•• PR was defined as IDAA1c ≤ 9.
•• Screening for complications was performed yearly.
•• Severe hypoglycemia was monitored at each consultation.

column1: •• PR occurred in 56.2% of patients, with no complete remission cases.

column2: •• Mean age at diagnosis was 8.8 years, with no difference between subgroups.

column3: •• Most patients had no diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis.
•• Absence of DKA was significantly higher in PR patients.
•• PR duration was shorter than 1 year in 71.6% of patients.
•• PR mostly occurred during the first 6 months.

column1: •• Lower baseline A1c at diagnosis was associated with higher chances of PR.

column2: •• A1c levels at 3 months were strongly associated with PR duration.

column3: •• Lower A1c levels at 3 to 12 months were associated with longer PR.
•• Higher A1c levels at diagnosis did not impact long-term A1c levels.
•• A1c+2y was significantly lower in the PR population.
•• A1c+3y was lower in patients with PR lasting between 510 and 570 days.

column1: •• C-peptide secretion was significantly different in PR versus no PR patients.

column2: •• Higher baseline C-peptide concentrations were observed in PR patients.

column3: •• Age at diagnosis positively correlated with C-peptide levels at 2 years after diagnosis.
•• Initial C-peptide",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 687,"<summary>
* Oral health significantly impacts the quality of life across all age groups.
* Oral lesions can cause discomfort, pain, and interfere with daily activities such as eating, speaking, and social interactions.
* Symptoms include halitosis, xerostomia, and oral dysesthesia, which can further hamper social activities.
* The study focused on the prevalence of oral mucosal lesions in 5,100 geriatric patients in India.
* Conducted at Jodhpur Dental College General Hospital from September 2008 to October 2012.
* Included 3,100 men (60.8%) and 2,000 women (39.2%) aged 60 to 98 years.
* Findings revealed that 64% of the patients had various oral lesions.
* Males were more affected (66%) than females (34%), though the difference was not statistically significant.
* The most common lesions were nicotinic stomatitis (43%) and denture stomatitis (34%).
* The study highlighted the importance of identifying and addressing oral health issues in the elderly.
* Oral lesions were more prevalent in older patients compared to younger populations.
* Factors contributing to oral lesions include aging, systemic diseases, medications, and habits like tobacco and alcohol use.
* The study's results emphasize the need for targeted geriatric oral health care and further research.
* Community programs should educate both the elderly and younger generations about oral health.
* Adequate clinical and pathological facilities are necessary for screening and managing oral mucosal lesions in the elderly.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
688,"<summary>
•• Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor affecting less than 1% of primary bone tumors.

column2: •• Primarily affects the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones like tibia, femur, and humerus.
•• Rarely occurs in the head and neck region, particularly in the temporal bone or TMJ.

column1: •• Symptoms of chondroblastoma in the temporal bone include occlusal abnormalities, trismus, and hearing impairments.

column2: •• Other symptoms can include dizziness, otorrhea, and clicking of the TMJ.
•• Malignant changes are rare but can occur after irradiation.

column1: •• Accurate diagnosis is crucial to avoid delays and unnecessary treatments.

column2: •• Initial misdiagnosis can lead to inappropriate treatments and delayed suitable treatments.
•• MRI/CT scanning and histopathologic examination are essential for accurate diagnosis.

column1: •• A 41-year-old male patient was initially misdiagnosed with otitis media and TMJ disorder.

column2: •• Symptoms included chronic hearing loss, trismus, and dizziness.
•• Multiple unsuccessful treatments were attempted before accurate diagnosis.

column1: •• Re-examination revealed a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone.

column2: •• CT and MRI scans showed a progressively enlarging tumor mass.
•• Histopathologic studies confirmed the presence of chondroblastoma.

column1: •• Surgical treatment involved extensive procedures to remove the tumor.

column2: •• Radical mastoidectomy and subtotal resection of the temporal bone were performed.
•• Reconstruction was done using fascia lata, pericranial flap, and temporalis muscle.

column1: •• Postoperative recovery showed no residual tumor or recurrence after four and a half years.

column2: •• The patient experienced improvement in occlusal abnormalities and trismus.
•• No postoperative irradiation was performed due to the risk of malignant changes.

column1: •• The study emphasizes the importance of accurate and early diagnosis.

column2: •• Misdiagnosis can lead to inappropriate treatments and potential malignant transformation.
•• Immunohistochemical examination for s-100 protein helps differentiate chondroblastoma from other tumors.

column1: •• Total en bloc excision is recommended as the primary treatment approach.

column2: •• Curettage and irradiation are additional options but carry risks.
•• Early-stage diagnosis is vital for successful treatment, while modified surgical procedures are valuable for later-stage chondroblastoma.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
689,"<summary>

• The study aimed to evaluate whether accurately quantified sedentary behavior and habitual physical activity could predict levels of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and intrahepatic lipid (IHL) in adults with overweight/obesity.

column2: • Findings indicated no significant relationship between objectively measured physical inactivity and raised liver fat, and traditional risk factors like waist circumference, triglycerides, fasting glucose, or fasting insulin were more predictive of VAT and IHL levels.

column1: • Despite the well-documented benefits of structured exercise, the study found that habitual physical activity and reduced sedentary behavior did not significantly predict metabolically detrimental fat depots such as VAT and IHL.

column2: • The results suggest that while increasing incidental activity is important, structured exercise remains a more potent stimulus for reducing VAT and IHL and improving cardiovascular and metabolic health.

690,"<summary>

* This retrospective, observational study conducted at a tertiary eye care hospital in North India analyzed fireworks-related ocular injuries during the Diwali festival over five consecutive years (2011-2015).

column2: * A total of 53 eyes from 45 patients were examined, with the majority being males; injuries ranged from corneal abrasions to severe cases requiring surgical intervention, and the study highlighted the need for better public awareness and stricter regulations on fireworks.

column1: * The study found that the severity of injuries was higher among those who ignited fireworks themselves compared to bystanders, with common injuries including corneal abrasions, hyphema, and vitreous hemorrhage.

column2: * The study emphasized the importance of immediate medical attention and suggested measures such as prohibiting dangerous fireworks, promoting public displays by professionals, and enforcing stricter laws to reduce ocular morbidity and preventable blindness.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
691,"<summary>

* Subclinical hypothyroidism (SCH) is characterized by elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with normal free thyroxine (FT4) levels and is common, especially in women, the elderly, and iodine-sufficient populations.

column2: * SCH is often caused by chronic autoimmune thyroiditis and can result from inadequate thyroid hormone supplementation or poor adherence to treatment.
* The prevalence of SCH varies widely, and its clinical significance is debated, particularly regarding its association with cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality.
* Treatment is typically considered for pregnant or infertile patients, those with symptoms, or those at high risk of progression to overt hypothyroidism.

column1: * SCH is associated with various adverse health outcomes, including increased body mass index (BMI), blood pressure (BP), lipid abnormalities, and metabolic syndrome (MetS).

column2: * Higher TSH levels are linked to increased BMI, weight gain, and worsening BP and lipid profiles.
* SCH can lead to vascular problems, including increased vascular stiffness and endothelial dysfunction.

* Studies show mixed results on the benefits of T4 replacement therapy, with some indicating improvements in cardiovascular function and others showing no significant impact on survival or CVD morbidity.
* The ongoing TRUST study aims to clarify the benefits and risks of T4 replacement therapy in older adults with SCH.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
692,"<summary>
* Clostridium difficile is a major cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, with diagnosis often relying on enzyme immunoassay (EIA) kits.

column2: * EIA kits detect glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) and toxins A and B.
* EIA sensitivity is lower (~70%) compared to PCR and cytotoxigenic culture (~90%).

column1: * The study investigated patients with GDH-positive and toxin-negative stool specimens.

column2: * Patients were divided into three groups: toxin-positive stool, toxin-negative stool/toxin-positive isolate, and dual toxin-negative.
* The study aimed to understand clinical history and treatment needs for these patients.

column1: * Significant differences were found in diarrhea duration among the groups.

column2: * Positive stool group had longer diarrhea duration (10.6 days) compared to toxin-negative groups.
* Discrepant negative/positive group had intermediate diarrhea duration (7.9 days).

column1: * Treatment with vancomycin or metronidazole was more common in the positive stool group.

column2: * 82.1% of the positive stool group received treatment.
* Only 7.1% of the discrepant negative/positive group received treatment.

column1: * No significant differences were observed in clinical inflammation markers among the groups.

column2: * Markers included white blood cell count, C-reactive protein levels, and body temperature.
* This suggests no strong correlation between toxin detection and inflammation at symptom onset.

column1: * The study supports findings that toxin-negative patients have milder symptoms.

column2: * Diarrhea duration was shorter in toxin-negative patients.
* Toxin-negative patients may be colonized with another cause of diarrhea.

column1: * Limitations of the study include its retrospective nature and small sample size.

column2: * Absence of molecular biological testing was noted.
* Further large-scale analysis is required to confirm findings.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
693,"<summary>
* The DREAM trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial.
* Designed to determine if ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay type 2 diabetes in people with IFG or IGT.
* Included 5,269 participants with IFG, IGT, or both, followed for a median of 3 years.
* Participants were assessed for new-onset diabetes or all-cause mortality.
* 982 participants had OGTTs at baseline, after 2 years, and at the end of the study.
* Blood samples were drawn fasting and at 30 and 120 minutes after the glucose challenge.
* Primary outcome variable was the change in β-cell function over the follow-up period.
* Assessed using the insulinogenic index (IGI) and proinsulin (PI) concentration.
* IGI was adjusted for insulin resistance using HOMA-IR, and PI was adjusted using C-peptide.
* Rosiglitazone significantly improved β-cell function measures.
* Increased IGI/IR and reduced PI/C by 86% and 42%, respectively.
* Effects were consistent across glucose tolerance subgroups, though more modest in isolated IFG.
* Ramipril did not significantly affect β-cell function.
* No significant changes in IGI/IR or PI/C compared to placebo.
* Glucose-lowering effects of ramipril may operate through other metabolic mechanisms.
* Statistical analyses used SAS version 9.1, with p-values < 0.05 considered significant.
* Longitudinal analyses were conducted using random-effects models in PROC MIXED.
* Cox proportional hazards regression assessed the impact of treatments on diabetes incidence.
* The study had strengths and limitations.
* Strengths included large sample size, randomized double-blind design, and thorough characterization of participants.
* Limitations included the lack of detailed measures of β-cell function, relying on proxy measures like IGI/IR and PI.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
694,"<summary>

* Microbial communities exhibit complex interactions, such as synthetic mutualism in trans (SMIT), where auxotrophic E. coli strains complement each other's growth by cross-feeding essential metabolites.

column2: * These interactions can be quantitatively modeled using flux balance analysis (FBA) and the minimization of metabolic adjustment (MOMA) objective function.
* The efficiency of cooperation between strains is determined by the ratio of the benefit of metabolite uptake to the cost of metabolite secretion.

column1: * Experimental results show that certain pairs of E. coli auxotrophs exhibit significant growth improvements in minimal media due to metabolic synergy.

column2: * Approximately 17% of dissimilar pairings showed greater than 50-fold growth, indicating strong metabolic cooperation.
* Growth phenotypes varied, with some strains benefiting more than others, and no strain exhibited a universally cooperative phenotype.

column1: * Theoretical models and empirical data suggest that metabolic interactions are influenced by the stoichiometries of the metabolic reaction network.

column2: * Cooperation efficiencies can be predicted using stoichiometric information without detailed biochemical characterization.
* The correlation between cooperation profiles and metabolic network distances indicates that the emergent phenotype of SMIT growth is governed by simple stoichiometric relationships.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
695,"<summary>
• Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis characterized by adnexal skin tumors on the scalp and face.

column2: •• It is caused by mutations in the CYLD gene on chromosome 16q12q13.

column1: • A 71-year-old woman presented with asymptomatic lesions on her head, diagnosed as spiradenomas and one cylindroma.

column2: •• Her family history revealed similar lesions in her mother, uncle, and two daughters, suggesting autosomal dominant inheritance.

column1: • Genetic testing showed a heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in the CYLD gene in the patient and her two affected daughters.

column2: •• The unaffected daughter had a wild-type genotype, and her children showed no clinical signs.

column1: • BSS has a low risk of malignancy but requires long-term follow-up.

column2: •• The syndrome is associated with increased risk of salivary gland neoplasms and other tumors.

column1: • Clinical manifestations typically start at puberty and are more common in females.

column2: •• Cylindromas can form large ""turban tumors"" on the scalp.

column1: • Recent studies suggest a common apocrine origin for spiradenomas and cylindromas.

column2: •• The loss of CYLD's deubiquitinating activity is linked to tumorigenesis.

column1: • The genetic study confirmed the association of the c.1628_1629delct mutation with BSS.

column2: •• This mutation was previously reported in a family with multiple trichoepitheliomas.

column1: • Genetic counseling was offered to the patient's first-degree relatives.

column2: •• The family was informed about the 50% probability of descendants developing BSS due to its autosomal dominant inheritance.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
696,"<summary>
* Biological scaffold materials from human, bovine, and porcine origins are used for soft tissue repair.

column2: * These materials are preferred in contaminated settings due to rapid revascularization and bacterial clearance.

column1: * Early absorbable polymer scaffolds like Dexon and Vicryl degrade quickly and are not ideal for long-term hernia repair.

column2: * Dexon and Vicryl lose mechanical strength rapidly, leading to hernia formation and requiring subsequent permanent mesh repair.

column1: * Newer absorbable scaffolds like Gore Bio-A, TIGR Matrix, and Phasix Mesh degrade more slowly and provide longer support.

column2: * These newer materials show promising results in clinical applications but require larger trials for comprehensive evaluation.

column1: * Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug are made from poly-4-hydroxybutyrate (P4HB), a naturally derived, fully absorbable polymer.

column2: * P4HB degrades slowly, matching the rate of tissue remodeling, and reduces the inflammatory response compared to other polymers.

column1: * Mechanical testing showed that Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug repairs have similar burst strength and relative stiffness.

column2: * Both materials provided significantly greater strength and stiffness compared to native abdominal wall tissue.

column1: * Gel permeation chromatography indicated significant resorption of P4HB material over time without a significant drop in mechanical strength.

column2: * The configuration of P4HB (mesh or plug) did not significantly impact its resorption profile.

column1: * Histological analysis revealed mild to moderate inflammatory response and granulation tissue/vascularization for both Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug.

column2: * No significant differences were observed between the mesh and plug designs in terms of host tissue response.

column1: * Phasix Mesh and P4HB Plug repairs demonstrated durable scaffolds for soft tissue repair in a porcine model.

column2: * Both materials maintained mechanical strength over 52 weeks despite significant material resorption.

column1: * The study suggests that P4HB materials are effective for soft tissue repair, providing durable support and appropriate foreign body response.

column2: * Further research is needed to fully understand the long-term capabilities of these materials in clinical settings.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
697,"<summary>
* The study evaluates the diagnostic accuracy and impact of the Xpert vanA/vanB assay for detecting vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) directly from rectal swabs.
* The assay showed high diagnostic accuracy for vanA with a sensitivity of 87.1% and specificity of 99.7%.
* The vanB part of the assay had low specificity and positive predictive value due to a high number of false positives.
* Implementation of the Xpert vanA/vanB assay led to significant savings in isolation and transmission risk days.
* A total of 141 isolation days and 292 transmission risk days were saved due to faster PCR results.
* False-negative or false-positive PCR results resulted in minimal additional isolation and transmission risk days.
* The study was conducted in a large healthcare setting in Denmark, covering four university hospitals and multiple departments.
* The laboratory serves a population of 800,000 and includes primary and secondary healthcare sectors.
* The infection control units at these hospitals are integrated with the clinical microbiology department.
* The study highlights the importance of rapid PCR-based screening in controlling VRE outbreaks.
* Faster PCR results led to quicker outbreak declarations and implementation of infection control measures.
* The cost-effectiveness of the assay was noted, considering the high costs associated with isolation days and transmission risks.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
698,"<summary>
• There is evidence supporting the concept of a local tissue or cellular renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) in cardiovascular diseases.

column2: • Local aldosterone production and mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) expression in the heart play roles in cardiovascular diseases like hypertension and heart failure.

column1: • MR antagonists have shown benefits in patients with left ventricular dysfunction and myocardial infarction.

column2: • Eplerenone, an MR antagonist, has beneficial effects in patients with moderate heart failure.

column1: • The effectiveness of MR blockade in pathological states such as diabetes is unclear.

column2: • Signaling network alterations in diabetes require tailored therapies.

column1: • ACE inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin type-1 receptor blockers (ARBs) protect against hypertension and diabetes-induced end-organ damage.

column2: • ACEIs and ARBs do not completely block end-organ damage in diabetes and hypertension.

column1: • The aldosterone escape phenomenon occurs in up to 40% of heart failure patients.

column2: • Additional RAAS inhibition, such as combining ACEIs or ARBs with MR antagonists, is needed.

column1: • The study aimed to compare the effects of RU28318 (an MR antagonist), captopril (an ACEI), and losartan (an ARB) on ischemia/reperfusion-induced cardiac dysfunction.

column2: • The study used isolated hearts from normal and diabetic rats.

column1: • Drug treatments resulted in rapid cardiac function recovery within the first 10 minutes of reperfusion.

column2: • RU28318 showed the most rapid recovery in coronary flow and other cardiac parameters.

column1: • Triple therapy (captopril + losartan + RU28318) yielded the best recovery in cardiac function.

column2: • Triple therapy was effective irrespective of administration before or after ischemia.

column1: • In diabetic hearts, captopril + losartan dual therapy was as effective as triple therapy.

column2: • RU28318 was less effective in diabetic hearts when given after ischemia.

column1: • The study suggests that MR antagonists may represent a novel class of RAAS inhibitors.

column2: • MR antagonists could overcome limitations observed with ACEI and ARB combinations.

699,"<summary>
* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve both cosmetic appearance and natural functions of the nose.

column2: * Objective measurement of airway patency is essential in modern respiratory medicine.
* Acoustic rhinometry (AR) is the most common method for measuring nasal cavity geometry.
* AR is easy to perform and requires less cooperation from the subject.

column1: * Various factors influence nose geometry, including race, age, sex, height, weight, and smoking habits.

column2: * Study evaluated changes in nasal dimensions of healthy Iranian volunteers post-cosmetic rhinoplasty.
* Measurements were taken before and 3 months after surgery using AR.
* The study included only healthy individuals without prior nose surgery or nasal obstruction complaints.

column1: * Surgeries were performed by a single experienced surgeon, with or without septoplasty.

column2: * Measurements were taken in a controlled environment to minimize artifacts.
* The nosepiece used was anatomically sculptured and a tight connection was ensured.
* Measurements were performed during a breathing pause in a sitting position.

column1: * Significant findings included changes in nasal dimensions post-surgery.

column2: * Increase in minimal cross-sectional area (MCA1) and decrease in MCA2 were observed.
* No significant change in volume (V) and distance (D2) was noted.
* Septoplasty resulted in more significant increases in MCA1 and less constriction in MCA2.

column1: * Double osteotomy positively affected nasal patency by increasing MCA1.

column2: * Placing a columellar strut was beneficial for nasal patency.
* Regression analysis showed no fixed significant effect for septoplasty, osteotomy, or strut placement.
* Advanced equipment for AR is reliable with proper calibration.

column1: * AR evaluation is accurate compared to MRI and CT, especially after decongestant use.

column2: * AR provides objective documentation and diagnosis for nasal airway blockage.
* Suitable for evaluating nasal cavity in septoplasty and turbinoplasty cases.
* Reliable for determining functional and geometric changes post-surgery.

column1: * Comparison with other studies showed consistent findings.

column2: * Reduction in internal dimensions of the nasal cavity, especially anterior dimensions.
* Highlighted the importance of the second constriction during surgery.
* Emphasized the need for careful intervention in the region of the second constriction.

column1: * Cosmetic rhinoplasty may have mixed effects on nose function.

column2: * Condition of the patient before surgery is crucial for predicting results.
* Surgeons should be aware of common patterns of change in nose geometry.
* Osteotomy, septoplasty, and strut placement",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 700,"<summary>
• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths.

column2: •• Ongoing research aims to prevent early development of risk factors like atherosclerosis, hypertension, and dyslipidemia.
•• Low-grade chronic inflammation is a key process in atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease.
•• Pro-inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress contribute to disease progression.
•• Endothelial cells play a crucial role in maintaining vascular health.

column1: • N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health.

column2: •• Initially used for treating dyslipidemia due to their lipid-lowering action.
•• Later found to have anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects.
•• Fish is the major source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs like EPA and DHA.
•• Plant sources of n-3 fatty acids cannot replace seafood-derived n-3 PUFAs.

column1: • EPA and DHA have distinct effects on cardiovascular health.

column2: •• DHA is preferentially incorporated into myocardial cell membranes.
•• DHA influences beta-adrenergic systems and nitric oxide release, contributing to hypotensive and anti-arrhythmic actions.
•• EPA and DHA modulate ion channel activities in myocardial cells.
•• DHA has a greater impact on heart rate reduction compared to EPA.

column1: • Clinical trials have shown the cardioprotective effects of n-3 PUFAs.

column2: •• The GISSI-Prevenzione trial showed a 15% lower combined risk of mortality, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and stroke.
•• The GISSI-HF study revealed a moderate decrease in all-cause mortality and hospital admissions for cardiovascular disease.
•• The JELIS trial demonstrated a 19% reduction in major coronary events with EPA supplementation.
•• Higher doses and longer duration of n-3 PUFA intake may protect against non-fatal CHD events.

column1: • N-3 PUFAs influence lipid metabolism and inflammation.

column2: •• They reduce triglyceride synthesis and hepatic VLDL synthesis.
•• Both EPA and DHA reduce triglyceridemia over long periods.
•• N-3 PUFAs increase LDL cholesterol but mainly the larger, less atherogenic particles.
•• They modulate the inflammatory response by affecting cytokine production and oxidative stress.

column1: • Endothelial function is crucial in cardiovascular health.

column2: •• Endothelial dysfunction is an early",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 701,"<summary>
• Our understanding of H. pylori-induced inflammation leading to cancer is built on the work of three pioneering pathologists: Rudolf Virchow, Pelayo Correa, and Robin Warren.

column3: •• Virchow proposed that cancer arose from normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation.
•• Correa developed a model for gastric cancer development, linking it to chronic atrophic gastritis and H. pylori colonization.

column1: • Correa's work focused on the role of H. pylori in gastric cancer, leading to the hypothesis that environmental factors and diet contributed to gastric mutagenesis.

column3: •• He initially thought environmental factors like diet were responsible for the progression from gastritis to cancer.
•• Later, he considered the role of Campylobacter pylori (now H. pylori) in initiating the disease.

column1: • Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, earning them the Nobel Prize in 2005.

column3: •• They successfully cultured H. pylori and showed it caused gastritis and ulcer disease.
•• Their work laid the foundation for understanding the link between H. pylori and gastric cancer.

column1: • Initial studies in the 1980s and early 1990s provided weak evidence for a link between H. pylori and gastric cancer.

column3: •• Cross-sectional studies showed inconsistent results regarding H. pylori infection rates in gastric cancer patients.
•• More convincing evidence came from large cohort studies with nested case-controls.

column1: • The World Health Organization classified H. pylori as a definite carcinogen in 1994 based on cohort studies.

column3: •• These studies showed a significant correlation between prior H. pylori infection and subsequent gastric cancer development.
•• Subsequent research confirmed and expanded upon these findings.

column1: • H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer, with recent meta-analyses indicating a significant risk reduction.

column3: •• Eradication studies showed a 40% risk reduction in asymptomatic individuals and 54% in tertiary prevention.
•• High-risk populations in low-risk countries may also benefit from H. pylori eradication.

column1: • Population-based H. pylori screening and eradication programs have shown promising results in high gastric cancer prevalence areas.

column3: •• A pilot study in Taiwan showed a 25% decrease in gastric cancer incidence.
•• Other trials, including one in China, are underway to further evaluate the benefits.

702,"<summary>
• The study compares the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab therapies for neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) in Turkish patients.

column2: • Both drugs were found to be effective in preventing visual acuity (VA) loss and improving VA in some patients.
• The study included patients aged 50 or older with newly diagnosed nAMD and a minimum follow-up period of 12 months.
• Patients with other retinal diseases or previous treatments were excluded.

column1: • The study followed a standardized examination protocol and used various imaging techniques to monitor patients.

column2: • Measurements included best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT).
• Injections were performed under sterile conditions, and patients were monitored for complications.
• Monthly examinations and retreatments were conducted based on specific criteria.

column1: • Results showed significant improvements in BCVA and CRT in both groups compared to baseline.

column2: • No statistically significant differences were found between the two groups in terms of BCVA and CRT changes.
• The mean number of injections at month 12 was similar between the two groups.
• No serious ocular or systemic complications were observed.

column1: • Previous studies also reported similar findings regarding the efficacy and safety of bevacizumab and ranibizumab.

column2: • Studies by Landa et al. and Feng et al. found no significant differences in visual outcomes between the two drugs.
• The CATT study reported similar visual and anatomical outcomes for both drugs over a two-year period.
• Safety concerns remain a topic of debate, with some studies indicating higher rates of serious adverse events with bevacizumab.

column1: • The study's strengths include the exclusion of patients with other treatments and similar baseline characteristics between the groups.

column2: • 86.1% of patients in the bevacizumab group and 86.5% in the ranibizumab group had stable or improved VA after approximately 18 months.
• Visual and anatomical outcomes, as well as the number of injections, were similar between the two drugs.
• Both treatments showed significant improvements in VA compared to baseline over at least 1.5 years.

703,"<summary>
* Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, complicating 25% of pregnancies.

column2: * Classically diagnosed by the presence of proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension.
* Proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse outcomes.
* Hypoalbuminemia may serve as an indicator of PE severity.
* Hypoalbuminemia leads to intravascular dehydration and potential complications like HELLP syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

column1: * Study aimed to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE based on albumin levels.

column2: * Retrospective cohort study with 299 women from Anhui province.
* Ethics approval and informed consent were obtained.
* Participants divided into mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and severe hypoproteinemia (SHP) groups.
* Serum albumin measured using Beckman Coulter Unicel DxC800.

column1: * PE defined by hypertension and either severe features or proteinuria.

column2: * Severe features include severe hypertension, low platelet count, elevated liver transaminases, and more.
* Exclusion criteria: kidney diseases, preexisting proteinuria, essential hypertension, other chronic conditions, and twin pregnancies.
* Maternal outcomes evaluated: delivery mode, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, and more.
* Neonatal outcomes evaluated: perinatal deaths, preterm birth, neonatal asphyxia, and fetal growth restriction.

column1: * SHP group had worse maternal and neonatal outcomes compared to MHP group.

column2: * SHP group delivered 1.5 weeks earlier on average.
* Higher percentage of cesarean sections and lower rate of spontaneous delivery in SHP group.
* More frequent severe hypertension, abnormal liver or renal function, ascites, and abruptio placenta in SHP group.
* Worse short-term neonatal outcomes, including lower average birth weight and higher rates of FGR and NICU admission.

column1: * SHP is a significant risk factor for poor maternal and neonatal outcomes in PE women.

column2: * Odds ratio for cesarean section: 2.99.
* Odds ratio for poor maternal outcomes: 5.83.
* Odds ratio for poor neonatal outcomes: 4.43.
* SHP associated with increased risk of severe hypertension, abnormal liver or renal function, and abruptio placenta.

column1: * Pathophysiologic mechanisms of PE are unclear, but defects in placental implantation and function are leading theories.

column1: 704,"<summary>
• The development of humanized monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and small-molecule protein tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitors targeting VEGF-A signaling has shown promise in cancer treatment.

column2: •• Avastin (bevacizumab) has been successful in treating various cancers but has limitations, including resistance and refractoriness in some tumors.
•• Other growth factors like VEGF-C, VEGF-D, and fibroblast growth factor (FGF) may contribute to resistance against Avastin.

column1: • VEGF family members, including VEGF-B, VEGF-C, and VEGF-D, have distinct roles in cancer and other pathologies.

column2: •• VEGF-B is involved in cardiovascular diseases and type 2 diabetes, with limited data on its role in tumor biology.
•• VEGF-C and VEGF-D promote tumor angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and metastasis, making them potential targets for anti-cancer therapy.

column1: • Targeting VEGF-D signaling in cancer could inhibit both tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis.

column2: •• mAbs specific to VEGF-D's VHD or PTK inhibitors blocking VEGFR-2 and VEGFR-3 signaling could be effective.
•• Soluble forms of VEGFR-3 could sequester VEGF-C and VEGF-D, restricting tumor growth and spread.

column1: • The past 20 years have seen the development of various agents targeting VEGF-A signaling pathways, but there is a need for more specific and effective treatments.

column2: •• Small-molecule PTK inhibitors have shown dose-limiting toxicity, necessitating more specific inhibitors.
•• Genome-wide functional approaches and bioinformatics could help strategize effective targeting of growth factors and receptors.

column1: • Anti-angiogenic treatments may have pro-tumor effects, highlighting the need for careful evaluation and combination therapies.

column2: •• Other signaling pathways, such as those driven by PDGF, IGF, and FGF, also control tumor angiogenesis and growth.
•• Existing anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin could provide a cost-effective approach to cancer prevention, especially in Asian countries.

705,"<summary>
• Malaria remains a significant public health concern in Iran, especially in the southern and southeastern regions.

column2: •• Control measures have reduced malaria cases from 11,460 in 2008 to 3,239 in 2011.
•• Plasmodium vivax is the predominant species, with Plasmodium falciparum accounting for 10-15% of cases.
•• Iran has been in the malaria pre-elimination phase since 2009, focusing on prevention, active case detection, and timely treatment.

column1: • The study aimed to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections using microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR in Bagh-e-Malek, Minab district, Hormozgan province.

column2: •• Bagh-e-Malek was chosen due to its higher transmission rate and specific geographical and climatic conditions.
•• 200 healthy volunteers participated, with blood samples collected for analysis.
•• The study was approved by the ethics committee of Hormozgan University of Medical Sciences.

column1: • Microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR were used to analyze the samples.

column2: •• No Plasmodium parasites were detected using microscopy or RDT.
•• Nested-PCR identified 3 asymptomatic P. vivax cases (1.5%) that were missed by other methods.
•• All positive cases were female, and one had a malaria history 20 years prior.

column1: • The study highlights the importance of accurate detection methods for asymptomatic malaria in the elimination phase.

column2: •• Microscopy and RDT are commonly used but have limitations in detecting low parasite densities.
•• Nested-PCR is more sensitive and can detect sub-clinical parasitemia and mixed infections.
•• Combining all three methods improves sensitivity, specificity, and reliability for active case surveillance.

column1: • The study emphasizes the need for molecular methods in addition to conventional techniques.

column2: •• Microscopy requires skilled personnel and has limitations in detecting low parasitemia.
•• RDTs are easy to use but may be unreliable for asymptomatic infections and have a short shelf life.
•• Molecular methods like nested-PCR are valuable for detecting asymptomatic carriers and confirming Plasmodium species.

column1: • The results support the use of nested-PCR for malaria elimination efforts in Iran.

column2: •• Nested-PCR detected cases missed by microscopy and RDT, highlighting its importance.
•• A 12-year-old girl with a previous fever episode was identified as a P. vivax carrier by nested-PCR.
•• The study underscores the need for comprehensive detection tools to prevent malaria transmission and",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 706,"<summary>
* Over the last two decades, new immunotherapy approaches for cancer treatment have emerged due to better understanding of immune mechanisms.
* These include infusional cytokine therapies, intravesical BCG therapy, and active cellular therapies like sipuleucel-T for prostate cancer.
* Evaluating these therapies using traditional paradigms is challenging, necessitating the identification of biomarkers of biological response.
* Antigen-specific vaccines have shown some success in evaluating immune responses, but broadly active immune-modulating agents still lack appropriate biomarkers.
* Machine-learned Bayesian belief networks (ML-BBNs) were used to identify promising biomarkers and potential biomarker networks.
* The study trained several ML-BBNs to identify biomarkers related to declines in serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) and demonstrated the feasibility of this method.
* The study found that immune-active therapies elicit IgG responses to prostate-associated antigens, with responses differing based on the therapy.
* The use of ML-BBN modeling appears promising for identifying biomarkers in complex data sets, though larger sample sizes are needed for robust predictive models.

707,"<summary>
• The study investigates the use of piezoelectric materials, specifically polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) films, to mechanically stimulate bone growth in vivo.

column2: •• PVDF films were dip-coated with poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) to improve cell adhesion and electrical insulation.
•• Actuator devices were implanted in the left hind limb of a sheep, with control devices in the right hind limb.
•• The devices applied a 5V square wave at 1 Hz and 3 Hz for 15 minutes daily.
•• Histological and histomorphometric analyses were conducted to assess bone growth and biological response.

column1: • Results showed significant increases in bone mass and mineral apposition rate around actuated devices compared to static controls.

column2: •• Total bone area around actuators was significantly higher (39.91% vs. 27.20%).
•• New bone formation was more prominent in actuators, with woven bone and osteoid occupying 64.89% of the total bone area.
•• Mineral apposition rate was higher around actuated devices (4.44 µm/day vs. 2.70 µm/day).
•• Increased osteopontin (OPN) expression was observed around actuators, indicating mechanical stress response.

column1: • The study suggests that piezoelectric materials can effectively stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface, but further research is needed.

column2: •• The study was conducted on a single sheep, necessitating larger animal studies for validation.
•• Improved biocompatible materials should be developed to replace PVDF.
•• The potential cytotoxic effects of PVDF and silver nitrate particles need to be addressed.
•• The clinical application of piezoelectric materials holds promise due to their ability to generate a wide range of deformations and frequencies.

708,"<summary>
• The study was conducted in the Department of Oral Medicine and Radiology and a cancer center with a total sample of 90 individuals.

column2: •• The study group consisted of 60 OSCC patients aged 25-75 years, and the control group had 30 healthy volunteers without systemic illness or history of tobacco/alcohol use.

column1: • Serum L-fucose levels were estimated using a clinical chemistry autoanalyzer based on the Winzler method.

column2: •• Statistical analysis showed a significant difference in serum L-fucose levels between OSCC patients (10.85 mg/dl) and healthy controls (3.47 mg/dl) with a p-value < 0.001.

column1: • Serum L-fucose levels increased progressively with the stages of oral cancer.

column2: •• Stage I had 8.13 mg/dl, Stage II had 9.18 mg/dl, Stage III had 10.53 mg/dl, and Stage IV had 11.59 mg/dl, with Stage IV showing the highest levels.

column1: • No significant correlation was found between serum L-fucose levels and gender or age.

column2: •• Serum L-fucose levels are directly indicative of the degree of tissue destruction.

column1: • L-fucose is a monosaccharide involved in cell-to-cell communication and is increased in cancer and other diseases.

column2: •• It plays a role in tumor progression, cell adhesion, malignant transformation, and metastasis.

column1: • Fucosylation of glycoproteins is crucial for tumor cells to escape recognition and contributes to abnormal tumor characteristics.

column2: •• Elevated fucosylation levels are associated with increased metastatic potential and poor prognosis in cancer patients.

column1: • Estimation of serum L-fucose levels could be a promising approach for early detection, diagnosis, and prognosis of various cancer types.

column2: •• Elevated serum L-fucose levels have been observed in different malignancies, including breast, ovarian, colorectal, and brain tumors.

column1: • The study concluded a positive correlation between serum L-fucose levels and TNM stages of OSCC.

column2: •• Serum L-fucose levels can be used as a noninvasive, cost-effective biochemical indicator for cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, prognosis, and post-treatment evaluation.
