753,"<summary>
* Statistical modeling is used to investigate count data, particularly in medicine and health.

column2: * Poisson distribution is used if the mean and variance are the same; otherwise, negative binomial distribution is preferred.

column1: * Poisson regression is a subset of generalized linear models (GLM) and is used for count variables like blood donations and failed courses.

column2: * Zero-inflated models are used when count data have an excess of zeroes.

column1: * Various studies have applied Poisson and negative binomial regressions to different health and educational data.

column2: * Examples include modeling hospitalization periods, student health situations, and work accidents.

column1: * The study focuses on modeling the number of failed courses and semesters at Iran University of Medical Sciences.

column2: * It uses zero-inflated Poisson and negative binomial regressions with educational and demographic factors as predictors.

column1: * Data was collected from 670 students using stratified random sampling.

column2: * Information included demographics, educational levels, and university performance.

column1: * Descriptive statistics and regression models were used to analyze the data.

column2: * Results showed relationships between university average, educational level, gender, and marital status with failed courses and semesters.

column1: * University average had a negative relationship with the number of failed courses and semesters.

column2: * Higher university averages resulted in fewer failed courses and semesters.

column1: * Quota system also influenced the number of failed semesters.

column2: * Free quota system students had fewer failed semesters.

column1: * Gender and marital status affected the number of failed courses.

column2: * Males and single students had more failed courses than females and married students.

column1: * The study concludes that increasing university average and choosing free quota systems can reduce failed courses and semesters.

column2: * The research was supported by Iran University of Medical Sciences under grant number 370.

754,"<summary>
• Electrostatic interactions are crucial in enzyme catalysis, aiding ligand binding and stabilizing transition states.

column2: •• These interactions are influenced by conformational changes during the catalytic cycle, particularly in the active site.

column1: • Escherichia coli dihydrofolate reductase (ecDHFR) undergoes significant structural rearrangements, making it ideal for studying electrostatic effects.

column2: •• Thiocyanate probes were used to investigate local electrostatic environments in ecDHFR's active site.

column1: • Vibrational and C NMR spectroscopic techniques, along with computer simulations, were employed to analyze electrostatics and hydration.

column2: •• Experimental data showed changes in the active site electrostatic environment due to structural rearrangements.

column1: • Mixed quantum mechanical and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) analyses reproduced experimental vibrational frequency shifts.

column2: •• Theoretical models allowed examination of the electric field along the hydride transfer pathway, crucial for catalysis.

column1: • The study identified major components contributing to electrostatic interactions, including individual residues and ligands.

column2: •• The enzyme's conformational changes significantly impact the electrostatic environment, facilitating hydride transfer.

column1: • Future work aims to investigate additional probe sites and states in the ecDHFR system to provide a comprehensive electrostatic landscape.

column2: •• This will enhance understanding of the catalytic role of electrostatics and conformational motions in enzyme catalysis.

755,"<summary>
* Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI) and Superparamagnetic Iron Oxide Nanoparticles (SPIOs)

column2: * MPI is a three-dimensional imaging method that uses magnetic fields to visualize SPIO distribution.
* SPIO characteristics crucial for MPI include superparamagnetic nature, nonlinear magnetization, and magnetic saturation.
* MPI offers high temporal and spatial resolution with high signal-to-noise ratios.
* Potential applications include cardiovascular imaging and guidance of interventions.

column1: * Evaluation of Resovist as an MPI Tracer

column2: * Resovist, a T2* contrast agent for MRI, is the current benchmark for MPI but has limitations.
* The study compared Resovist from Bayer Pharma AG and Irom Pharmaceutical Co Ltd in rabbits.
* Results showed a rapid decline in MPI signal, indicating Resovist is not suitable for prolonged circulation.
* Differences in blood half-life between the two Resovist sources were statistically significant.

756,"<summary>
• Intracellular pathogens have evolved to coexist with host defense mechanisms over millions of years.

column2: •• In vitro studies exclude the inflammatory milieu.
•• In vivo studies face challenges in distinguishing pathogen-specific responses from general inflammatory responses.
•• Activation of complement cascade, coagulation pathway, and acute phase response occurs within minutes of infection.

column1: • The study hypothesized using transcriptomic responses of uninfected cells exposed to inflammation to measure baseline responses.

column2: •• Transcriptomic networks in infected cells represent pathogen-induced changes.
•• Networks in uninfected cells identify responses beneficial to the host.
•• Lack of these responses in infected cells might favor pathogen survival.

column1: • The study used a model of Leishmania infection to test the hypothesis.

column2: •• Leishmania donovani amastigotes infect resident tissue macrophages, including Kupffer cells (KCs).
•• Expression of an RXRA-centered transcriptomic pathway is aberrantly maintained in infected KCs.
•• Pharmacological manipulation of RXR activity enhances leishmanicidal activity.

column1: • Infected and uninfected KCs were isolated and analyzed for transcriptional events.

column2: •• Flow cytometry was used to discriminate between infected and inflamed KCs.
•• Microarray analysis generated transcriptomic profiles for each population.
•• Differentially expressed genes were identified between infected and inflamed KCs.

column1: • The study identified genes uniquely regulated in inflamed KCs but not in infected KCs.

column2: •• 1,088 genes were uniquely regulated at 12 hours post-infection.
•• Genes involved in inflammation and host defense were enriched in inflamed cells.
•• 241 genes were differentially regulated in inflamed cells but not in infected cells.

column1: • Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) identified key pathways in inflamed KCs.

column2: •• Lipid metabolism and small-molecule biochemistry pathway were highly enriched.
•• RXRA was identified as a key hub in this pathway.
•• Quantitative real-time PCR validated differential expression of network-associated genes.

column1: • Pharmacological intervention targeted RXR activity to perturb the gene network.

column2: •• HX531 (RXR antagonist) and LG268 (RXR agonist) were used.
•• Both treatments reduced parasite burden in liver and spleen.
•• LXR agonist GW3965 had no effect on parasite burden.

column1: • The study demonstrated the importance of RXRA-centered gene network in parasite survival.

column2: •• Perturbation of RXR function affected the entire gene network.

column1: 757,"<summary>
• The control of appetite involves complex coordination of physiological and environmental inputs.

column2: • Early theories focused on glucose, amino acids, and adipose tissue.
• Recent models emphasize signals from adipose tissue and the gastrointestinal tract.
• Major signals include leptin, ghrelin, PYY, GLP-1, CCK, amylin, and insulin.

column1: • Energy expenditure (EE) and energy intake (EI) are interrelated.

column2: • Increased EE is often met with increased EI.
• Resting metabolic rate (RMR) is a significant component of daily EE.
• Physical activity EE has different effects on appetite compared to RMR.

column1: • Exercise impacts appetite control through dual processes.

column2: • Acute exercise does not consistently increase food intake immediately.
• Repeated exercise sessions show partial compensatory responses.
• Exercise increases fasting hunger but also enhances post-prandial satiety.

column1: • Fat-free mass (FFM) is strongly correlated with meal size and daily EI.

column2: • FFM, not fat mass (FM) or BMI, drives food intake.
• RMR, largely influenced by FFM, acts as a physiological driver of food intake.
• FFM creates a physiological demand for energy, influencing appetite.

column1: • Leptin plays a crucial role in appetite regulation.

column2: • Leptin signals from adipose tissue inhibit food intake.
• Leptin insensitivity reduces tonic inhibition as adipose tissue increases.
• Leptin's role extends to influencing FFM and energy homeostasis.

column1: • Body composition should be considered in obesity research and management.

column2: • FFM and FM have different impacts on appetite and energy balance.
• High FFM individuals have a stronger drive to eat.
• Elderly with reduced lean mass have diminished appetite.

column1: • Modern diet and environment affect physiological regulatory processes.

column2: • High energy density foods lead to passive overconsumption.
• Positive energy balance is influenced by diet palatability and energy density.
• Understanding biological and environmental variables can aid in managing body weight.

758,"<summary>
• Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) is widely used in prosthetic dentistry for denture bases due to its excellent properties.

column2: •• Heat-polymerized PMMA resin is preferred for its esthetics, low water sorption, and simple processing.
•• Chemically activated resins are less common due to higher solubility and inferior color stability.

column1: • The study evaluated the effect of surface treatments on the shear bond strength of denture teeth to heat-polymerized and autopolymerized denture base resins.

column2: •• 60 maxillary central incisor acrylic teeth were divided into two groups and further subdivided into three subgroups based on surface treatment.
•• Treatments included untreated ground surface, monomer application, and airborne particle abrasion.

column1: • Results showed that surface treatments significantly improved bond strength.

column2: •• Two-way ANOVA indicated significant effects of resin type and surface treatment on bond strength.
•• Tukey's test revealed no significant difference between monomer and airborne particle abrasion treatments.

column1: • Failure modes varied between the two types of resins.

column2: •• Meliodent specimens showed predominantly mixed failure modes.
•• Futura Gen specimens exhibited mostly adhesive failures.

column1: • Conclusions highlighted the effectiveness of surface treatments in improving bond strength.

column2: •• Both monomer application and airborne particle abrasion significantly enhanced bond strength.
•• No significant difference was found between the two surface treatments in terms of bond strength improvement.

759,"<summary>
* The light emitted during arc welding contains intense ultraviolet radiation (UVR), which poses significant health risks to workers.

column2: * UVR exposure can cause acute health effects like keratoconjunctivitis and erythema, and delayed effects such as cataracts and skin cancer.
* Surveys indicate high incidences of UVR-related ailments among workers, even those wearing protective gear.
* Protective measures are necessary to mitigate UVR hazards in workplaces where arc welding is performed.

column1: * The study measured UVR hazards during gas metal arc welding (GMAW) of mild steel under various conditions.

column2: * Effective irradiance was measured using specific equipment and compared against American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists (ACGIH) guidelines.
* The study examined the influence of shielding gas composition (80% Ar + 20% CO2 vs. 100% CO2) and welding current (pulsed vs. non-pulsed).
* Results showed that UVR hazard increases with welding current and is higher for pulsed currents and certain gas compositions.

column1: * Findings highlight the need for adequate protection and awareness of UVR hazards in welding environments.

column2: * Effective irradiance increases significantly with higher welding currents and specific metal transfer modes.
* Pulsed welding currents produce higher UVR hazards compared to non-pulsed currents.
* Workers and supervisors must recognize the high UVR hazard, especially during spray transfer conditions, and implement protective measures accordingly.

760,"<summary>
•• A wide variety of microorganisms produce polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) as intracellular energy and carbon storage compounds.

column2: •• Bacteria with higher PHA content can survive longer in extreme environments.
•• PHAs are synthesized when carbon is available but other essential nutrients are not.

column1: •• PHAs are divided into short-chain-length (scl-PHAs) and medium-chain-length (mcl-PHAs) based on monomer units.

column2: •• Scl-PHAs consist of monomers with 3-5 carbon atoms.
•• Mcl-PHAs consist of monomers with 6-14 carbon atoms.

column1: •• PHA synthases are classified into four classes based on substrate specificities and subunit organization.

column2: •• Classes I, III, and IV synthesize scl-PHAs.
•• Class II is responsible for mcl-PHA synthesis.

column1: •• Extremophiles in polar areas are potential sources of novel enzymes for industrial applications.

column2: •• Shallow Antarctic reservoirs are underexploited sources of microorganisms with biotechnological potential.
•• Psychrotrophic bacteria adapted to variable conditions may offer advantages for industrial PHA production.

column1: •• The study aimed to determine if bacteria in freshwater reservoirs in glacier forefield areas can synthesize PHAs.

column2: •• Samples were collected from five shallow freshwater reservoirs and one stream near the Ecology Glacier in Antarctica.
•• DNA extraction and PCR amplification were performed to detect PHA-producing microorganisms.

column1: •• The study found that many microorganisms in Antarctic freshwater lakes possess genes responsible for PHA synthesis.

column2: •• Isolated strains mainly belonged to the Pseudomonas and Janthinobacterium genera.
•• The presence of PHA synthase genes suggests that these bacteria may have acquired them through horizontal gene transfer.

761,"<summary>
* Establishing vegetation on arid and semi-arid lands is crucial but uncertain due to reliance on unpredictable rainfall.

column2: * Vegetation helps reduce erosion, improve public perception, and reintegrate disturbed lands.
* Irrigation is expensive and often less successful than natural rainfall.
* Native plants are preferred over non-natives for long-term stability and public acceptance.

column1: * Modeling soil moisture using historical rainfall data can help estimate the frequency of successful vegetation establishment.

column2: * The study used a land surface model with 31 years of precipitation data from the Santa Rita Experimental Range.
* Two scenarios were evaluated: 2 days and 3 days of suitable conditions for germination.
* Results showed a higher potential for seeding success (68%) than previously estimated (10%).

762,"<summary>
* Major depression (MD) is a leading cause of disability and is projected to become the second leading cause of disability-adjusted life years by 2020.

column2: * Up to 40% of patients with MD do not show satisfactory improvement due to various biopsychosocial factors.

column1: * Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is defined by poor response to two adequate trials of different classes of antidepressants.

column2: * TRD is categorized into stages based on the number and type of failed antidepressant trials.

column1: * Neuromodulation therapies (NTs) are gaining interest for TRD due to their targeted approach and limited side effects compared to systemic psychopharmacological therapies.

column2: * NTs include seizure therapies, noninvasive therapies, neurosurgical approaches, and emerging techniques like focused ultrasound and optogenetic stimulation.

column1: * Evidence-based data on NTs for TRD has been emerging, with various studies showing their efficacy and safety.

column2: * NTs target specific brain circuits involved in MD, offering a more localized treatment approach.

column1: * Modified electroconvulsive therapy (mECT) remains effective for TRD but has significant neurocognitive side effects.

column2: * Research is needed to develop strategies to prevent relapse following successful mECT.

column1: * Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is FDA-approved for MD and TRD and has shown significant antidepressant effects with a safer profile.

column2: * rTMS can induce accidental seizures, but this risk is minimal with expert guidelines.

column1: * Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) and deep brain stimulation (DBS) have shown promising results in TRD, with sustained benefits and good functional status.

column2: * Further controlled studies with larger sample sizes are needed to establish their efficacy and tolerability.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
763,"<summary>
* Small RNA molecules, including siRNAs and saRNAs, play crucial roles in gene regulation, including RNA interference (RNAi) and RNA activation (RNAa).

column2: * RNAi typically downregulates gene expression, while RNAa can upregulate gene expression by targeting promoter regions.

column1: * The study developed a bioinformatic approach to design saRNAs targeting KLF4 and c-Myc genes to upregulate their expression in human mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).

column2: * saRNAs targeting the promoter regions of KLF4 and c-Myc (KLF4-pr1 and MYC-pr2) successfully increased mRNA and protein levels of these genes in a time- and dose-dependent manner.

column1: * The upregulation of KLF4 and c-Myc by saRNAs did not activate interferon response pathways, unlike lentiviral transduction methods.

column2: * This suggests saRNAs as a safer alternative for gene activation without triggering immune responses.

column1: * Microarray analysis showed that saRNA-mediated gene activation had a high degree of similarity with lentiviral transduction in terms of gene expression profiles.

column2: * However, some differences were noted, likely due to the different methods of gene activation rather than off-target effects.

column1: * Pathway analysis revealed that saRNA and lentiviral transduction differentially regulated pathways involved in cytoskeletal remodeling, macropinocytosis, and epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).

column2: * These differences highlight the potential advantages of saRNA over viral methods in avoiding unwanted cellular changes.

column1: * The study demonstrated that saRNAs could activate endogenous pluripotency factors and induce morphological changes in MSCs, supporting their potential use in stem cell research and reprogramming.

column2: * This method could provide a safer and more efficient alternative for generating induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells without the risks associated with viral vectors.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
764,"<summary>
• The study investigates the effects of taurine and taxol on renal damage in a rat model of unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO).

column2: •• Taurine is an organic acid with known benefits in renal fibrosis and various kidney diseases.
•• Taxol (paclitaxel) stabilizes microtubules and has shown efficacy in reducing fibrosis in kidney and liver models.
•• The study involved four groups of rats, including a sham-operated group, a UUO group, a taxol-treated group, and a taurine-treated group.
•• Stereological methods were used to measure kidney volume, structure, and histological changes.

column1: • Results showed that both taurine and taxol had protective effects on renal tissue after UUO.

column2: •• Taxol was more effective than taurine in preserving kidney structures such as glomeruli, proximal convoluted tubules (PCT), and distal convoluted tubules (DCT).
•• Taxol treatment resulted in a significant reduction in degenerative tubules and necrotic and fibrotic tissues.
•• Taurine also reduced necrotic and fibrotic tissues but increased the volume of degenerative tubules.
•• Both treatments improved the length and volume of renal tubules compared to untreated UUO rats.

column1: • The study confirmed the protective roles of taxol and taurine through various mechanisms.

column2: •• Taxol's protective effects are linked to its ability to modulate microRNA-192 and transforming growth factor-beta signaling.
•• Taurine's benefits are attributed to its antioxidant properties and ability to regulate blood flow, ion transport, and osmoregulation in the kidney.
•• Both agents have shown efficacy in reducing oxidative stress and inflammation in renal and other tissue models.
•• The findings suggest potential therapeutic roles for taxol and taurine in preventing renal fibrosis and structural damage.

column1: • The study concludes that taxol and taurine are effective in mitigating renal damage in the UUO rat model.

column2: •• Taxol demonstrated superior efficacy in reducing necrotic and fibrotic tissue volumes.
•• Taurine also provided significant protective effects, particularly in reducing oxidative and nitrosative stress.
•• The study highlights the importance of further research to explore the therapeutic potential of these agents in renal diseases.
•• The findings support the use of taxol and taurine as potential treatments for obstructive nephropathy and related conditions.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
765,"<summary>
* Pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs) trigger innate immune responses by detecting microbial components and activating transcription factors.
* PRRs lead to the expression of inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, type I interferons (IFNs), and antimicrobial genes.
* Aberrant activation of innate immune responses can result in inflammatory diseases like autoimmune disease and septic shock.
* Autophagy, a bulk degradation system, is essential for cellular homeostasis and host defense.
* Autophagy involves the clearance of old/damaged organelles, long-lived proteins, and pathogens.
* Autophagy-related proteins (ATGs) are highly conserved and play a critical role in autophagosome formation and pathogen elimination.
* ATGs are involved in the regulation of inflammatory responses and the maturation of phagosomes.
* ATG16L1 is essential for autophagy and regulates inflammatory cytokine production in response to endotoxin.
* NOD1 and NOD2, intracellular sensors, detect bacterial components and promote autophagy, enhancing antigen presentation and bactericidal responses.
* Autophagy is crucial for antiviral responses and the regulation of type I IFN production.
* ATG12-ATG5 conjugates suppress RLR-mediated activation of type I IFN promoters.
* Basal autophagy is responsible for TLR7-dependent type I IFN production in plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs).
* The role of ATGs in innate immunity and inflammation is complex and requires further in vivo studies.
* ATGs influence the development of specific cell types and lipid metabolism, indirectly affecting immune responses.
* Enhancing autophagic activity could be a therapeutic approach for infectious diseases and inflammatory disorders.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
766,"<summary>
* The association between betel quid chewing and oral cancer has been known for over a century.

column2: * Tobacco introduced by European settlers four centuries ago exacerbated the health risks.
* Betel quid with tobacco became culturally accepted in India.
* The causal link between betel quid with tobacco and oral cancer was established in the 20th century.

column1: * Betel nut alone was initially thought to be safe, but later studies showed it causes oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).

column2: * OSMF is a precancerous condition that has become more common among young Indians due to gutkha chewing.
* The incidence of oral cancer has increased among young adults due to OSMF.
* Industrial manufacturing and marketing of gutkha have contributed to the rise in oral cancer cases.

column1: * Oral cancer is a significant public health issue in India, with the highest number of cases globally.

column2: * The incidence rate is 12.5 per 100,000 people.
* Betel nut, betel quid, gutkha, and pan masala are proven carcinogens.
* Oral cancer is a major cause of cancer-related deaths among Indian men.

column1: * A retrospective study of 63 oral cancer patients at KVG Medical College was conducted.

column2: * Patients ranged from 47 to 73 years old, with a mean age of 61.20 years for males and 59.92 years for females.
* All patients had a history of chewing betel quid, gutkha, and pan masala.

column1: 767,"<summary>
* Patient blood management is crucial due to the risks associated with allogeneic RBC transfusions.

column2: * Risks include increased morbidity and mortality, severe postoperative infections, and high costs.
* Transfusion practices vary widely and are often guided by local policies rather than evidence-based practices.

column1: * Cardiac surgery patients, especially those with advanced age or long CPB times, are at high risk of postoperative bleeding.

column2: * Excessive bleeding can be caused by surgical factors and impaired haemostasis.
* Studies show increased long-term mortality after transfusions, but results vary based on surgery type and study design.

column1: * Guidelines recommend RBC transfusions based on the patient's risk of inadequate oxygenation rather than a single haemoglobin trigger.

column2: * RBC transfusions are generally indicated at Hb levels lower than 6.0 g/dl and rarely at levels higher than 10.0 g/dl.
* Institutions should develop local policies and guidelines for transfusion, focusing on individual patient needs and signs of ischemia or oxygen imbalance.

768,"<summary>
* Neurogenesis in mammals was once believed to occur only during embryonic life.

column2: * Recent studies show neuronal regeneration in specific tissues post-birth.
* Key areas include the hippocampus, dentate gyrus, subventricular zone, and olfactory epithelium.
* Damage to the olfactory periphery can destroy sensory neurons but recovery is substantial.

column1: * Olfactory epithelium (OE) has a unique capacity for regeneration.

column2: * OE contains heterogeneous populations of cells, including neural stem cells.
* Globose basal cells (GBCs) and horizontal basal cells (HBCs) are key stem cell populations.
* GBCs are multipotent and can differentiate into neurons and non-neuronal cells.

column1: * GBCs have been identified as potential neural progenitor cells.

column2: * GBCs proliferate at a high rate and are limited to the OE.
* Studies show GBCs increase during the regenerative process.
* GBCs can differentiate into various cell types, including neurons.

column1: * Experimental studies have used GBCs for neural regeneration.

column2: * GBCs can be isolated using fluorescence-assisted cell sorting (FACS).
* Pure GBCs can engraft into damaged OE and regenerate neural and non-neural cells.
* GBCs show positive markers for neural progenitor cells like NCAM, nestin, and SOX-2.

column1: * Electrophysiological studies show GBCs are non-excitable.

column2: * GBCs lack voltage-gated sodium channels.
* Only leaky potassium channels are present.
* This non-excitable nature is significant for their role in neurogenesis.

column1: * Olfactory epithelial stem cells are ideal for clinical research and therapy.

column2: * They share the same environmental niche as CNS cells.
* OE cells are easily accessible and can be biopsied for autologous transplantation.
* They regenerate completely without loss of function.

column1: * The study standardized methods for isolating and culturing OE cells.

column2: * Optimal cell densities for growth and neurosphere formation were determined.
* EGF and N-2 supplements enhance neurosphere formation.
* Multiple generations of neurospheres indicate self-renewal potential.

column1: * Future research areas include:

column2: * Using magnetic-assisted cell sorting (MACS) for better purity.
* Further electrophysiological studies to understand ion channels on GBCs.
* Animal studies to test GBCs in repairing spinal",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 769,"<summary>
* The central nervous system (CNS) was once considered immune-privileged.

column2: * Microglia play a crucial role in CNS innate immunity.
* The glymphatic system facilitates immune surveillance.
* CNS immune activity is more constant than previously thought.

column1: * Microglia originate from erythromyeloid progenitors in the yolk sac.

column2: * These progenitors express the chemokine receptor CX3CR1.
* They develop into CD45 c-kit CX3CR1 immature and mature cells.
* Microglia invade the brain during embryogenesis.

column1: * Microglia in the postnatal brain have multiple functions.

column2: * They are involved in immune surveillance and inflammatory responses.
* They phagocytose pathogens and apoptotic neurons.
* They play roles in synaptic pruning and angiogenesis.

column1: * Cortical spreading depression (CSD) involves rapid depolarization of neurons.

column2: * CSD is followed by changes in cerebral blood flow.
* It can be induced by various stimuli, including chemical and electrical.
* CSD is linked to conditions like stroke and brain trauma.

column1: * Microglia respond to CSD by increasing activity.

column2: * They exhibit increased NMDA-dependent potassium conductance.
* CSD induces ROS production and cytokine secretion in microglia.
* Microglia activation can lower the threshold for CSD induction.

column1: * Multiple CSD episodes cause significant microglial activation.

column2: * Single CSD events cause subtle changes in microglia.
* Multiple CSD events lead to HMGB1 release and microglial activation.
* Activated microglia may engage in synaptic repair.

column1: * Microglia express voltage-sensitive ion channels.

column2: * They sense electrical activity related to CSD.
* CSD initially elevates extracellular pH, then decreases tissue pH.
* Microglia may detect these changes via TRPV1 channels.

column1: * Microglia are involved in synaptic pruning and formation.

column2: * They engulf presynaptic and postsynaptic elements.
* Synaptic pruning is dependent on neuronal activity.
* Microglia secrete BDNF for synapse formation.

column1: * The role of microglia in CSD and brain health is complex.

column2: * They may contribute to neuroprotection through synaptic repair.
* The involvement of KCNN4/KCa3.1 channels in CSD initiation is worth investigating.

column1: 770,"<summary>
* Transposable elements (TEs) have historically been viewed as selfish, junk DNA, but recent evidence shows they play significant roles in genetic innovation and evolution.

column2: ** TEs can move within genomes, with retroelements using a copy-and-paste mechanism and DNA transposons using a cut-and-paste mechanism.
** TEs can be domesticated to form new protein-coding genes, contributing to important functions in various organisms.
** Examples include genes involved in placenta development, immune system diversity, and DNA repair.
** TE-derived genes have lost their ability to transpose, becoming fixed in the genome to avoid deleterious effects.

column1: * The study focuses on gin genes, ancient vertebrate domesticated genes with unknown functions, derived from gin transposons.

column2: ** Gin1 is found in mammals, birds, and reptiles, suggesting formation in a common ancestor of amniota.
** Gin2 is older, present in tetrapods, bony fish, sharks, and possibly urochordates, but lost in monotremes and placental mammals.
** Both genes have conserved the HHCC zinc finger, indicating potential DNA or RNA binding functions.
** Gin2 shows expression in brain and gonads in fish, with a role suggested during zebrafish embryogenesis.

column1: * Molecular domestication of TEs is a significant driver of genetic innovation, contributing to the diversification of vertebrates and other organisms.

column2: ** Many TE-derived genes are mammal-specific, indicating their role in mammalian evolution.
** Domesticated sequences in birds, reptiles, amphibians, and fish are harder to identify due to active TEs in their genomes.
** Future genome comparisons and functional analyses will likely uncover new domesticated genes and their biological functions.
** The presence of conserved intron positions suggests a unique origin or independent domestication events for gin1 and gin2.

771,"<summary>
• Progressive diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob affect millions globally and are expected to increase.

column2: • These diseases lead to high societal costs and significant loss in life expectancy and quality of life.
• They involve the aggregation of misfolded proteins that propagate and amplify within the central nervous system.
• Misfolded proteins can cause both loss of function and gain of pathological function, leading to cellular damage.

column1: • Molecular chaperones play a crucial role in maintaining cellular proteostasis by opposing protein misfolding and aggregation.

column2: • Cellular stress increases misfolded proteins, triggering a heat shock response to correct misfolding.
• Sustained heat shock response can imbalance proteostasis, leading to protein aggregation.
• The ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy are key in clearing misfolded proteins, but failures in these systems lead to harmful protein deposits.

column1: • Misfolded protein aggregates spread in a prion-like manner, contributing to disease progression.

column2: • Experimental evidence shows that aggregates from diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's can induce similar lesions in model animals.
• Aggregates can propagate through neuronal transport processes and affect interconnected brain regions.
• This prion-like behavior suggests that misfolded protein propagation is a common feature in neurodegenerative diseases.

column1: • Different strains of misfolded proteins can lead to distinct disease phenotypes.

column2: • Variations in protein aggregation can result in different neurodegenerative diseases, such as multiple system atrophy and dementia with Lewy bodies.
• Distinct strains of proteins like alpha-synuclein and tau exhibit different toxicities and propagation properties.
• These strains can recruit and imprint their structure on endogenous proteins, leading to diverse pathological outcomes.

column1: • Therapeutic strategies are being developed to target protein aggregation and propagation.

column2: • Small molecules like polyphenols can interfere with protein aggregation and stimulate proteostasis.
• Novel molecules that repair proteostasis networks and enhance cell stress pathways show promise in treating protein conformational diseases.
• Immunotherapy and neurotrophic factors are explored to clear polypeptides and protect neuronal cells.

column1: • Innovative treatments for neurodegenerative diseases are under investigation.

column2: • Neural stem cell-based treatments are considered for diseases like Parkinson's.
• Strategies to interfere with protein assemblies' propagation and seeding capacities are being developed.
• Molecular chaperones and antibodies have shown potential in preventing protein assemblies' uptake and toxicity.

772,"<summary>
• Hepatitis C virus (HCV) related morbidity and mortality are significant in patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC), affecting approximately 3.2 million people in the U.S.

column2: •• African Americans (AA) are twice as likely to be infected with HCV compared to non-Hispanic Caucasians and have historically had lower response rates to interferon (IFN)-based therapies.
•• New direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) have led to sustained virologic response (SVR) rates greater than 90%.

column1: • A study evaluated the effect of IFN-based therapies on outcomes in AA patients with HCV genotype 1, followed for an average of 8 years.

column2: •• The study included 346 AA patients, with 57% male and a mean age of 54 years.
•• The SVR rate was 15% based on intent-to-treat (ITT) and 23% based on patients who adhered to the protocol.

column1: • Patients achieving SVR had significant improvements in liver-related laboratory values and did not develop new cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

column2: •• Non-responders and untreated patients had a higher incidence of HCC and new cirrhosis.
•• Males were more likely to develop HCC than females, but achieving SVR reduced the risk of HCC in both genders.

column1: • The study confirmed that fibrosis, but not cirrhosis, at the first visit was a significant risk factor for HCC.

column2: •• Multivariate analysis identified fibrosis stage as the only independent predictor of HCC.
•• There was no reliable predictor of HCC development on an individual basis using serum assays or fibrosis markers.

column1: • The study highlighted the importance of achieving SVR to improve outcomes and reduce the risk of HCC in AA patients with CHC.

column2: •• Surveillance in patients with significant fibrosis, rather than just cirrhosis, is warranted.
•• Elimination of the virus remains the optimal goal of therapy, especially with the advent of more effective DAA therapies.

773,"<summary>
•• Stroke is the second most common cause of death globally, with 87% of deaths occurring in low and middle-income nations.

column2: •• Genetic influences, particularly polygenic ones, play a significant role in the pathogenesis of ischemic stroke.

column3: •• Beta-adrenergic receptors (2AR) are implicated in cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases.
•• Polymorphisms in 2AR, specifically at positions 16 (Arg>Gly) and 27 (Gln>Glu), affect receptor function.

column1: •• A meta-analysis was conducted to determine the association between 2AR polymorphisms and ischemic stroke.

column2: •• Inclusion criteria focused on case-control studies, English language publications, and stroke confirmed by MRI or CT.

column3: •• Exclusion criteria included non-case-control studies, lack of genotypic/allelic data, and duplicate publications.
•• Three studies were included for allelic association analysis, and two for genotypic association analysis.

column1: •• Results showed no significant association between Arg16Gly polymorphism of 2AR and ischemic stroke.

column2: •• Neither recessive nor dominant models of inheritance showed significant results.

column3: •• Allelic association also did not show a significant risk correlation.

column1: •• Significant associations were found between Gln27Glu polymorphism of 2AR and ischemic stroke.

column2: •• Both recessive and dominant models of inheritance showed significant associations.

column3: •• Allelic association indicated a higher risk of ischemic stroke with the Glu27 allele.

column1: •• The meta-analysis suggests Gln27Glu polymorphism of 2AR as an independent risk factor for ischemic stroke.

column2: •• Results align with previous studies showing associations with other diseases like obesity, dyslipidemia, and myocardial infarction.

column3: •• Discrepancies in findings across studies may be due to population-specific genetic variant prevalence.

column1: •• Limitations of the study include lack of haplotype analysis, gene-environment interaction studies, and multivariate analysis.

column2: •• Selection bias may have occurred due to hospital-based control selection.

column3: •• Heterogeneity may be due to deviation from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium in control subjects.

column1: •• Further well-designed, larger prospective cohort studies are needed to validate these findings.

column2: •• These studies should aim to provide a higher level of evidence.

column3: •• Understanding the molecular pathways conferring susceptibility to ischemic stroke is crucial.

column1: •• The study provides preliminary evidence supporting the increased risk of ischemic stroke associated with Gln27Glu polym",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
774,"<summary>
* Methadone is used in various therapies but has been reported to impair cognitive abilities.

column2: * Chronic exposure to methadone affects psychomotor performance, memory, and decision-making.
* Methadone maintenance programs show negative impacts on human cognition.
* Cognitive impairments include issues with attention, problem-solving, and emotional recognition.

column1: * Methadone induces changes in cytosolic free-calcium concentration ([Ca]cyt) in SH-SY5Y cells.

column2: * Four types of calcium responses were observed in SH-SY5Y cells exposed to methadone.
* Types 2 and 3 responses indicate early or delayed calcium deregulation.
* Methadone decreased transient responsive cells and increased deregulated cells.

column1: * The study investigated the mechanisms behind methadone-induced calcium deregulation.

column2: * Extracellular calcium entry was ruled out as a contributing factor.
* Intracellular calcium stores partially contributed to the rise in [Ca]cyt.
* Opioid receptors were found not to be involved in methadone-induced [Ca]cyt changes.

column1: * Mitochondrial handling of calcium is crucial in methadone-induced delayed calcium deregulation (DCD).

column2: * Drugs affecting mitochondrial calcium handling modulated methadone-induced DCD.
* Mitochondrial uncoupler FCCP and oligomycin affected the types of calcium responses.
* Inhibition of mitochondrial permeability transition pore (MPTP) formation by cyclosporine A reduced type 2 responses.

column1: * Methadone affects mitochondrial morphology and function.

column2: * Methadone induced mitochondrial fragmentation in a dose-dependent manner.
* Mitochondrial fragmentation correlates with methadone-induced toxicity.
* Methadone's effect on mitochondrial calcium uptake depends on respiratory substrates.

column1: * Methadone-induced DCD is linked to mitochondrial damage and cell death.

column2: * Altered mitochondrial calcium handling leads to changes in mitochondrial morphology.
* Swollen mitochondria are associated with neurodegenerative diseases.
* Imbalance in mitochondrial calcium homeostasis may explain clinical symptoms like memory impairment.

775,"<summary>
* Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (RRSO) is a preventive surgery for women with BRCA1/2 mutations.

column2: * Involves removal of fallopian tubes and ovaries.
* Aims to reduce risks of breast and ovarian cancer.
* Commonly used by women with BRCA1/2 gene mutations.
* Effectiveness compared to non-surgical options is unclear.

column1: * Meta-analysis of 10 studies was conducted to evaluate RRSO's effectiveness.

column2: * Studies included case-control and cohort designs.
* Pooled results showed substantial risk reductions.
* Hazard ratios (HRs) and odds ratios (ORs) were used.
* Analysis included 5703 participants.

column1: * RRSO significantly reduces breast cancer risk in BRCA1/2 carriers.

column2: * Summary HR estimate for breast cancer: 0.49.
* Greater reduction observed in BRCA2 carriers.
* Effectiveness may vary by age and timing of surgery.
* Hormonal modulation may play a role.

column1: * RRSO also reduces ovarian and fallopian tube cancer risks.

column2: * Summary HR estimate for gynecologic cancer: 0.21.
* Larger reduction in BRCA1 carriers.
* No post-RRSO gynecologic cancers observed in BRCA2 sample.
* Consistent findings across studies.

column1: * Limitations of the meta-analysis include:

column2: * Variable study designs and small sample sizes.
* Short follow-up times in prospective studies.
* Potential for publication bias.
* Lack of data on nonwhite populations.

column1: * Clinical management of BRCA1/2 carriers is complex.

column2: * Patient preferences should be considered.
* Accurate knowledge of risks and benefits is crucial.
* RRSO associated with improved overall survival.
* Other risk reduction options exist.

column1: * Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after RRSO raises questions.

column2: * Potential cardiovascular and bone health benefits.
* Unclear long-term effects on cancer risk.
* Studies needed on type, timing, and length of HRT.
* Important for understanding noncancer mortality.

column1: * Additional cancer risk reduction strategies are required.

column2: * Risk-reducing mastectomy substantially reduces breast cancer risk.
* Yearly MRI and mammography may benefit early detection.
* Combination of modalities recommended.
* Aim to maximally reduce cancer incidence and mortality.

column1: * Summary risk reduction estimates confirm RRSO's effectiveness.

column1: 776,"<summary>
* Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the oral mucosa with a prevalence of about 1-2% of the population.

column2: * Lesions rarely undergo self-remission and can have malignant potential.
* Characterized by dense subepithelial infiltration of lymphocytes and degeneration of basal keratinocytes.
* Lymphocytic infiltrate predominantly consists of T cells.

column1: * The IL-23/IL-17 axis is a newly discovered proinflammatory signaling pathway involved in chronic inflammation.

column2: * IL-23 is a heterodimeric cytokine composed of p19 and p40 subunits.
* IL-23 induces Th17 cells to produce IL-17, a proinflammatory cytokine.
* IL-17 activates various cells to produce inflammatory molecules.

column1: * The study aimed to investigate the expression patterns and regulatory roles of the IL-23/IL-17 axis in OLP.

column2: * Tissue and blood specimens were obtained from OLP patients and healthy volunteers.
* Immunohistochemistry and quantitative PCR were used to detect IL-23 and IL-17 expressions.
* IL-23 and IL-17 were found to be overexpressed in OLP lesions.

column1: * IL-23 and IL-17 expressions were positively correlated in reticular OLP lesions but not in erosive OLP lesions.

column2: * Suggests a regulatory role of IL-23 in the early stage of OLP.
* No correlation found in erosive OLP indicates other regulatory mechanisms.
* IL-23 may contribute to the induction of Th17 cells and IL-17 production.

column1: * IL-17 selectively regulates the expression of inflammatory mediators in oral keratinocytes.

column2: * Increases mRNA expressions of hBD-2, hBD-3, IL-8, CCL-20, and TNF-α.
* No significant effect on hBD-1, CXCL-9, -10, -11, CCL-5, and IL-6.
* Indicates a unique regulatory role of the IL-23/IL-17 axis in OLP lesions.

column1: * The study proposes a novel model of interaction between T cells and keratinocytes in OLP pathogenesis.

column2: * Keratinocytes produce a large amount of IL-23.
* IL-23 contributes to Th17 cell accumulation and IL-17 overproduction.
* IL-17 induces keratinocytes to produce various inflammatory mediators.

777,"<summary>
* The isolation of pure cell populations is crucial for clinical and basic research, including HIV diagnostics and stem cell biology.
* Essential for understanding the body's response to injury.
* Advances in stem cell biology have increased the need for isolating rare cells.
* Miniaturized cell separation devices offer advantages over conventional techniques.
* Benefits include small sample volumes, portability, low cost, improved sterility, and integration potential.
* Derived from semiconductor industry and synthetic chemistry advances.
* Cell separation techniques are broadly classified into size/density-based and affinity-based methods.
* Size-based methods do not require cell-specific markers, useful for isolating stem cells.
* Affinity-based methods include chemical, electrical, or magnetic separation.
* Microfluidic devices are commonly used for cell separation due to their small size and efficiency.
* Size-based devices ensure laminar fluid flow and can sort particles with high resolution.
* Affinity-based devices use markers like antibodies for high specificity separation.
* Magnetic separation techniques are effective but face challenges in continuous flow systems.
* Microscale magnetic separation is advantageous for small sample volumes.
* Efficiency and purity are comparable to macroscale systems.
* Adhesion-based separation systems use antibodies to bind target cells, similar to chromatography.
* Can separate cell populations with the same size/density.
* Microfluidic systems offer high purity and short residence times.
* Electrophoretic separation processes, such as dielectrophoresis (DEP), are used for sorting cells based on their dielectric properties.
* DEP retention, migration, and field-flow fractionation are common methods.
* Microscale systems handle small sample volumes and offer precise control.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
778,"<summary>
* Imaging techniques can identify morphological signs of cirrhosis, which are useful in clinical practice.

column2: * Different signs include the caudate-to-right lobe ratio (C/RL), right posterior notch (RPN), and expanded gallbladder fossa (EGF).
* C/RL has high specificity and accuracy but is time-consuming and not widely used.
* RPN and EGF are simpler visual signs with high specificity but lower sensitivity.

column1: * A study compared the diagnostic performance of C/RL, RPN, and EGF in diagnosing cirrhosis.

column2: * 95 cirrhotic patients and 57 control subjects were included, with MR imaging performed using a 1.0-t MR system.
* C/RL and RPN showed similar diagnostic performance, while EGF had lower sensitivity but high specificity.
* Combining these signs could improve diagnostic accuracy, but further studies are needed to correlate signs with the underlying cause of cirrhosis.

779,"<summary>
• The study aimed to evaluate optic nerve structure and visual function in glaucoma patients using OCT and SAP tests, with a focus on detecting disease progression.

column2: •• Progression was determined by statistically significant slopes of change in OCT RNFL thickness and SAP mean sensitivity, with specific cutoffs established from healthy eyes to account for age-related changes.

column1: • The study included 462 eyes of 305 glaucoma patients and 62 eyes of 49 healthy controls, with a median of 8 visits for glaucoma patients and 7 visits for healthy subjects over an average follow-up of around 3.6 years.

column2: •• Results showed that OCT was more effective in detecting progression in early-stage glaucoma, while SAP was more effective in advanced stages, especially with a higher number of follow-up visits.

column1: • The findings suggest that the relative odds of detecting glaucoma progression by structural (OCT) or functional (SAP) tests vary based on disease severity and the number of tests performed during follow-up.

column2: •• Clinicians may need to tailor the frequency and type of tests according to the stage of the disease, although combining structural and functional data might offer a better solution for monitoring glaucoma progression.

780,"<summary>
* The healthcare industry faces challenges in improving access, cost, and quality of care, with new technologies and innovations seen as potential solutions.

column2: * Research institutions are under stress due to competition for limited funding.
* NIH lost 22% of its funding capacity from FY 2003 to 2015.
* Fewer grants and discoveries result, with scientists leaving research or the US.
* Efficiency in translating research into products and services is crucial.

column1: * Successful healthcare innovation requires navigating the ""valley of death"" between academic research and commercialization.

column2: * Non-economic investments often lead to technologies languishing in labs.
* Financial investors focus on market risk rather than technical risk.
* Academic investigators often lack commercial readiness.
* Technology transfer offices face challenges in finding licensees for technologies without clear commercial value.

column1: * Institutions are adopting new approaches to support commercialization of academic research.

column2: * Adding business development functions to technology transfer offices.
* Creating programs like Stanford Biodesign and the Coulter Foundation.
* Providing educational opportunities and accelerators.
* Offering mentoring and pitch competitions to help teams achieve commercial exits.

column1: * Healthcare commercialization programs (HCPs) are emerging as a balanced approach.

column2: * They advance projects into commercialization while building team skills.
* Examples include modified I-Corps programs and the Coulter Foundation C3i program.
* NHLBI established NIH Centers for Accelerated Innovations (NCAIs) to support this effort.
* NCAIs provide product development funds and skills development.

column1: * HCPs differ from I-Corps programs due to unique healthcare challenges.

column2: * Complex buying dynamics with misaligned objectives between users and buyers.
* Reimbursement complexity and regulatory pathways.
* High professional and personal risks for healthcare professionals.
* Higher funding requirements for healthcare innovations.

column1: * Key features for effective HCPs include:

column2: * Team composition with clinical, technical, and business perspectives.
* Executive faculty with healthcare industry expertise.
* Content addressing healthcare-specific challenges.
* Style fostering strong rapport and objective feedback.

column1: * Ecosystem leverage is crucial for HCP success.

column2: * Integrating HCPs into broader programs like NCAI.
* Conducting HCPs early in the funding cycle.
* Focusing resources on teams with high translational success likelihood.
* Helping teams achieve commercially relevant milestones.

column1: * HCPs offer cost-effective ways to improve healthcare project efficiency.

column2: * Increase the likelihood of selecting and advancing projects to commercialization.

column1: 781,"<summary>
• Bladder cancer is strongly linked to smoking, with 85% of cases limited to the urinary bladder at diagnosis.

column2: •• Aromatic amines in tobacco smoke are confirmed carcinogens.
•• Passive smoking is a widespread issue, especially at home and work.
•• Smoking is often underreported due to social stigma.

column1: • The study assessed the reliability of smoking history using questionnaires and urine cotinine levels.

column2: •• Cotinine is a reliable marker of tobacco exposure, detectable even hours after smoking.
•• 36% of patients had cotinine levels indicating active smoking, while 4% showed passive smoking exposure.
•• The study found discrepancies between self-reported smoking habits and cotinine test results.

782,"<summary>
* Anal incontinence (AI) is a significant health issue affecting daily life and quality of life.
* Associated with hygienic problems, social limitations, and sexual dysfunction.
* No objective assessment methods exist; prevalence measured by self-reporting.
* Obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS) is a major cause of AI in women.
* Multiple vaginal deliveries increase AI risk regardless of sphincter injury.
* Age, obesity, and medical conditions like diabetic neuropathy also increase AI risk.
* Prevalence of AI varies widely among different populations.
* Higher prevalence in women attending gynecological clinics compared to the general population.
* Increased prevalence with age, especially among nursing home residents.
* Study aimed to assess AI prevalence and risk factors in pregnant women.
* Conducted as a survey in a large university hospital in Oslo, Norway.
* Included 2846 women with a response rate of 45%.
* AI identified by self-reported symptoms and St. Mark's score.
* Most women reported complete anal continence.
* Inability to control flatus was the most frequent complaint.
* Urinary incontinence (UI) significantly associated with AI.
* Prevalence of UI threefold among parous women compared to nulliparous women.
* 32.4% of women with AI also reported UI.
* Significant risk factors for AI among nulliparous women.
* Low educational level, dermatological disease, and rheumatoid arthritis.
* Low socioeconomic status and comorbidity also important indicators.
* Significant risk factors for AI among parous women.
* Previous OASIS and dermatological disease.
* Higher risk of AI with increasing number of vaginal deliveries.
* Study strengths and limitations.
* Unselected pregnant population and assessment of comorbidity and medication use.
* Response rate less than 50%, potential self-selection bias.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
783,"<summary>
* The study aimed to compare the hemodynamic effects of spinal anesthesia with hyperbaric bupivacaine in normotensive and hypertensive patients.

column2: * **60 patients aged 18-65 with ASA scores I-II were included, divided into hypertensive (Group H) and normotensive (Group N) groups.**

column1: * Blood pressures and heart rates were measured at multiple time points, and hypotension and bradycardia were treated with ephedrine and atropine, respectively.

column2: * **No significant differences were found between the groups in terms of age, sex, weight, height, sensory block height, incidences of hypotension and bradycardia, or fluid amounts infused.**

column1: * The hypertensive group had higher systolic, diastolic, and mean blood pressures at all measurement times compared to the normotensive group.

column2: * **The number of patients who developed hypotension was greater in the hypertensive group (6/30) compared to the normotensive group (1/30).**

column1: * The study found no significant difference in the incidence of hypotension between hypertensive and normotensive patients.

column2: * **This finding aligns with other studies that normalized preoperative blood pressure with antihypertensive treatment.**

column1: * The study's most significant limitation was the lack of measurement of basal sympathetic activities of the patients.

column2: * **Despite this, the study concluded that effective antihypertensive treatment improves vascular structural changes and decreases basal sympathetic activity.**

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
784,"<summary>
* Chronic pain and depression are common in primary care, often coexisting and complicating diagnosis and treatment.

column2: * Pain is linked to limitations in daily activities, poor self-rated health, and higher prevalence of depressive disorders.
* Primary care physicians often underestimate the intensity of pain in depressed patients.
* Optimizing antidepressant therapy and pain self-management can improve both conditions.
* Coexistence of pain and depression increases the risk of opioid misuse.

column1: * The study aimed to evaluate Dolotest as a screening tool for depression in primary care.

column2: * Conducted at Laegehuset Noerretorv in Denmark with 715 patients.
* Patients filled out Dolotest and Major Depression Inventory (MDI) questionnaires.
* Dolotest integrates pain intensity and its impact on quality of life.
* MDI follows ICD-10 criteria for major depressive disorders.

column1: * Results showed significant differences between patients visiting for pain and those visiting for other reasons.

column2: * 34.4% of patients visited due to pain, with 26.8% meeting depression criteria.
* Women scored higher than men in most Dolotest domains.
* Depression prevalence was higher in the pain group compared to the control group.
* Dolotest's ""low spirits"" domain had high sensitivity (78%) and specificity (95%) for detecting depression.

column1: * The study highlights the importance of screening for both pain and depression in primary care.

column2: * Visual Dolotest profiles facilitate communication about depression and pain.
* Coexistence of pain and depression leads to reduced function, work capacity, and increased healthcare costs.
* Treating both conditions together is crucial for optimal health outcomes.
* Dolotest proved to be an effective and easy-to-use screening tool in clinical settings.

785,"<summary>
• Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus from the Papillomaviridae family, with over 130 genotypes.

column2: •• High-risk serotypes can lead to cancers such as cervical cancer, while low-risk serotypes cause benign changes and genital warts.

column1: • HPV is a common sexually transmitted infection, with a global prevalence of 11.7%.

column2: •• In Nigeria, the prevalence is high, especially among women aged 15-23 years, with significant long-term risks if the infection persists.

column1: • A study was conducted on 350 women aged 15-49 at Ahmadu Bello University Teaching Hospital in Nigeria.

column2: •• Blood samples were analyzed for HPV IgG antibodies using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.

column1: • The seroprevalence of HPV IgG antibodies was found to be 42.9%.

column2: •• Higher prevalence was observed in women aged 45-49 years and those with secondary education.

column1: • HPV infection was associated with various sociodemographic factors but not significantly with smoking or contraceptive use.

column2: •• Women with children and those with early sexual debut had higher prevalence rates.

column1: • Recommendations include introducing subsidized HPV vaccines and improving public education on HPV and cervical cancer.

column2: •• Cervical cancer screening programs are also suggested to reduce the disease's impact in Nigeria.

786,"<summary>
• Rapid innovations in health care have led to an expansion of medical knowledge and a doubling of scientific papers over the past decade.

column2: •• Studies show that physicians face numerous questions from patients, highlighting a gap between research and clinical practice.
•• More than 40% of patients do not receive care based on the best scientific evidence, and 20% receive insufficient or harmful care.

column1: • Evidence-based medicine (EBM) aims to bridge the gap between research and clinical practice by integrating the best evidence with clinical experience and patient values.

column2: •• EBM helps confirm or reject previous practices and suggests new, more effective methods.
•• The main challenge is the transfer and translation of knowledge to enable quick, evidence-based clinical decisions.

column1: • A national evidence-based health care system (EBHCS) is proposed to ensure the best evidence is generated, stored, used, shared, and monitored.

column2: •• This system aims to provide effective and safe services systematically, according to stakeholder needs.
•• It includes a national system of clinical knowledge management, a national evidence-based practice system, and an integrated national network of clinical effectiveness.

column1: • The national system of clinical knowledge management focuses on promoting and guaranteeing clinical knowledge management.

column2: •• It produces knowledge products through reactive and proactive approaches.
•• These products include clinical guidelines, health technology reports, and systematic reviews.

column1: • The national evidence-based practice system (NEBPS) promotes and guarantees the use of clinical policies or knowledge products.

column2: •• Evidence-based care providers use these products to make clinical decisions.
•• Providers are classified into three levels based on their performance in producing and applying knowledge products.

column1: • The integrated national network of clinical effectiveness (NICEN) facilitates evidence-based practice.

column2: •• It includes components like electronic evidence-based performance portfolios and educational services.
•• This network ensures the delivery of the most effective services to patients.

column1: • The Ministry of Health and Medical Education plays a crucial role in providing infrastructure and frameworks for high-quality health care.

column2: •• Clinical effectiveness requires access to the best evidence.
•• National-level interventions are necessary for quality improvement and clinical effectiveness promotion.

column1: • Comparative studies of evidence-based practice systems in countries like England, USA, Canada, Australia, and Scotland were conducted.

column2: •• These studies focused on organization, stewardship, knowledge products, and performance monitoring.
•• The findings were used to develop strategies for implementing a similar system in Iran.

column1: • Focus group discussions and Delphi techniques were used to analyze and finalize the status and strategies for evidence-based practice in Iran.

column2: •• Experts evaluated strengths,",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: 787,"<summary>
• Human metapneumovirus (hMPV) is a significant cause of respiratory tract infections, particularly in infants, seniors, and immunocompromised individuals.

column2: •• hMPV is closely related to avian metapneumovirus (AMPV) subgroup C.
•• Symptoms range from mild influenza-like syndromes to severe lower respiratory tract infections.
•• Genome sequencing and comparative analysis are crucial for understanding hMPV's pathogenicity, evolution, and host interactions.
•• hMPV has two main genetic lineages, subtypes A and B, with subgroups A1/A2 and B1/B2.

column1: • Synonymous codon usage bias in hMPV genomes is influenced primarily by nucleotide composition, particularly the high abundance of A/U nucleotides.

column2: •• Preferred codons in hMPV end with A/U, reflecting a significant codon usage bias.
•• The G+C content of the hMPV genome is 36.91%, with 68.57% of codons ending in A/U.
•• Effective number of codons (ENC) values among hMPV genomes are stable, indicating conserved genomic compositions.
•• Mutation pressure, rather than natural selection, is the main determinant of codon usage bias in hMPV.

column1: • Comparative analysis shows that hMPV codon usage is more complementary to human cells than bird cells, aiding in persistent infection.

column2: •• hMPV and human cells share only one preferred codon, while hMPV and bird cells share six.
•• This complementary pattern benefits viral replication by reducing competition with host cell machinery.
•• Phylogenetic differences among hMPV genotypes influence codon usage bias and may affect viral replication and virulence.
•• Understanding codon usage patterns helps in studying viral evolution and host-virus interactions.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
788,"<summary>
* Protsweep, Domainsweep, and 2dsweep are tools for comprehensive protein annotation.

column2: * They analyze sequence similarity, small domains, and structural elements.

column1: * Protsweep performs a cascade of similarity searches to classify proteins.

column2: * It uses databases like SwissProt, Ensembl, and RefSeq, and classifies proteins into categories such as identical, homolog, and putative.

column1: * Domainsweep identifies domain architecture within protein sequences.

column2: * It uses various protein/domain family databases like Prodom, Prosite, and Pfam, and applies stringent thresholds to ensure accuracy.

column1: * 2dsweep predicts secondary structural elements and other features.

column2: * It combines multiple prediction algorithms and reports on elements like alpha-helix, beta-strand, and transmembrane regions.

column1: * Results from these tools are provided in HTML for visual inspection and XML for storage.

column2: * Users can access complete application outputs and database entries via hyperlinks.

column1: * Databases like UniProt/SwissProt, UniProt/TrEMBL, and RefSeq are automatically updated.

column2: * Ensembl data updates need to be done manually due to API inconsistencies.

column1: * The tools are implemented using the W3H task framework and are continually updated based on user feedback.

column2: * They are integrated into systems like LifeDB for protein analysis and annotation.

789,"<summary>
* Delirium in elderly patients is linked to increased morbidity, mortality, and prolonged hospital stays.

column2: * Identifying biomarkers like BH4 status, amino acid ratios, and neurotransmitter levels can improve understanding and care of delirium.

column1: * The study found significant biochemical differences in patients with delirium, suggesting disturbed neurotransmission and oxidative stress.

column2: * Higher Phe/Tyr ratios, lower Trp/LNAAs ratios, and lower arginine and citrulline levels were observed in delirium patients.

790,"<summary>
* Overweight and obesity rates are rising globally, with 1.4 billion overweight adults in 2008.

column2: * 200 million men and 300 million women were obese.

column1: * In the Netherlands, 60% of men and 44% of women are overweight.

column2: * High prevalence among ethnic minorities and low socioeconomic status (SES) groups.

column1: * WHO recommends 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity weekly.

column2: * Active transport like walking or cycling can help achieve this.

column1: * Studies show age and overweight inversely correlate with physical activity.

column2: * Male gender and white ethnicity positively correlate with being active.

column1: * High-SES populations show higher physical activity and lower overweight rates.

column2: * Unclear if findings apply to low-SES populations in deprived neighborhoods.

column1: * Dutch deprived neighborhoods have higher overweight rates and lower physical activity.

column2: * Important target group for physical activity interventions.

column1: * Study investigates personal and neighborhood factors associated with active transport.

column2: * Focus on Dutch deprived neighborhoods and interactions between variables.

column1: * Urban40 study evaluates health impact of interventions in 40 deprived Dutch neighborhoods.

column2: * Recruitment involved tailored interviewers and multilingual support.

column1: * Active transport measured using the SQUASH questionnaire.

column2: * Neighborhood characteristics assessed with the Neighborhood Walkability Scale (NEWS).

column1: * Results show younger participants more active; migrants walk more, Dutch cycle more.

column2: * Higher BMI correlates with lower active transport; traffic speed perception affects walking.

791,"<summary>
* Optic neuritis related to MS is an acute optic neuropathy, predominantly affecting young women.

column2: * Decline in visual acuity and contrast sensitivity.
* Pain increasing with eye movements.
* Dyschromatopsia and visual field changes.
* Incidence of 1-5 per 100,000 annually.

column1: * Study aimed to determine optic neuritis as the first MS clinical presentation.

column2: * Analyzed morphometric changes in the optic nerve and visual field.
* Used optic coherent tomography (OCT) and computer perimetry.
* Evaluated the efficiency of pulse corticosteroid therapy.
* Conducted at Sarajevo University Clinical Centre.

column1: * Clinical, retrospective study with 89 MS patients.

column2: * 10 patients had optic neuritis as the first clinical sign.
* Statistically significant findings (x=9.7, p=0.01).
* Unilateral optic neuritis in all analyzed patients.
* MS verification according to Paty or Brakhof criteria.

column1: * Ophthalmological parameters analyzed.

column2: * Visual acuity (VA) by Snellen charts.
* Visual field (VF) by Octopus 100.
* Thickness of peripapillary rim nerve fibers by Stratus Zeiss OCT.
* Followed up after 7, 15 days, 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.

column1: * Visual disturbances in MS patients with optic neuritis.

column2: * Centrocecal and paracentral scotoma.
* Diffuse sensitivity disturbances.
* Most frequent disturbances in the centrocecal region (50%).
* Thinning of nerve fibers in the upper quadrant after three months.

column1: * Visual acuity improvement after corticosteroid therapy.

column2: * Initial VA ranged from 0.1 to 0.3 with correction.
* Significant improvement to 0.6 to 1.0 after one month.
* Pulse corticosteroid therapy dosage: 1,000 mg for three days.
* Followed by 8 days of 1mg/kg body weight.

column1: * Optic neuritis study group findings.

column2: * Decline in vision and contrast sensitivity.
* Color vision disturbances.
* Visual field disturbances.
* Genetic impact on MS development confirmed.

column1: * Influence of external factors on MS exacerbations.

column2: * Stress, viral, and bacterial infections.
* Higher incidence in spring months.
* Cigarette smoking as a risk factor.
* Ratio of MS incidence",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 792,"<summary>
* The study assessed diabetes knowledge among the Karen ethnic rural community along the Thai-Myanmar border, revealing low overall knowledge levels.
* Only one-third of participants answered correctly on general knowledge, risk factors, and symptoms of diabetes.
* Significant gender disparity was found, with females having lower knowledge scores than males.
* The Karen community faces unique challenges in diabetes education due to language barriers and dynamic population patterns.
* Most senior adults cannot read Thai script, and the population is unstable due to migration.
* Health promotion services are hard to reach, necessitating culturally tailored education strategies.
* The study highlights the urgent need for diabetes education interventions in the Karen community to prevent a diabetes epidemic.
* Suggested strategies include mass media, printed materials in the local language, and community-based education programs.
* Special focus on women’s education through peer groups and local language TV programs is recommended to address health disparities.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
793,"<summary>
• Behavioral Health Home (BHH) services were implemented to improve somatic care for individuals with serious mental illness (SMI) at the University of Maryland School of Medicine.

column2: • BHH services aimed to identify abnormal hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels and provide individualized interventions.
• The program targeted highly prevalent conditions like diabetes and hypertension.
• The initiative was funded by the state of Maryland in 2013.

column1: • The BHH was embedded in the Division of Community Psychiatry, serving 2000 individuals annually.

column2: • Referrals were made for patients requiring the most assistance, particularly those in intensive services.
• Enrolled patients received a minimum of 2 BHH services per month, coordinated by a nurse case manager.
• Services included care coordination, comprehensive transitional care, and health promotion.

column1: • Preliminary results showed mixed outcomes in managing diabetes among the enrolled patients.

column2: • 33 patients had type 2 diabetes, with 4 newly diagnosed through the program.
• 4 patients improved to within recommended HbA1c levels, while 7 showed improvements but remained above target.
• 2 patients progressed from prediabetes to diabetes, and 7 had higher HbA1c levels after 10 months.

column1: • The BHH identified gaps in care, such as missed laboratory monitoring and diagnoses.

column2: • 54 patients did not have HbA1c levels checked as recommended.
• The program facilitated early recognition of medical disorders and proactive preventative care.
• A CDC Diabetes Prevention Program group was started within the mental health clinic.

column1: • Future research is needed to evaluate the effectiveness of BHH services.

column2: • The current study lacked a comparison group, limiting statistical analysis.
• Investigating both clinical and control samples would provide more robust data.
• Examining patient satisfaction with BHH and population-based health management services is warranted.
