949,"<summary>
• The Welsh Government discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education, focusing on the closure of schools and the new purpose of schools.
• Schools will support children of key workers, provide free school meals, and cater to children with additional learning needs.
• Schools will use digital tools for distance learning, including the Hwb digital learning platform.
• Headteachers and staff are expected to be in schools to plan and deliver these new purposes.
• Local authorities will identify strategic schools to remain open for these purposes.
• The decision to cancel summer exams was made to ensure fairness and continuity for students.
• Students will be awarded grades based on a range of information, including externally assessed work and teacher evaluations.
• The aim is to maintain the usual results day in August, though this may change due to the pandemic.
• Qualifications Wales and WJEC will provide clear communication to schools about the grading process.
• Discussions with universities and UCAS indicate support for this approach.
• Concerns were raised about the mental health and well-being of students and staff.
• Schools are expected to conduct check-ins with students to support their well-being.
• Online resources and counseling services will be promoted to help students.
• Youth services will play a role in supporting vulnerable children.
• The Welsh Government will ensure continuity of funding for youth services and other grant-funded organizations.
• The impact on early years and childcare settings was discussed.
• The Welsh Government will continue to pay for childcare under the childcare offer, even if children do not attend.
• Local authorities are expected to maintain funding for Flying Start childcare and early education.
• Childcare settings can apply for support packages available to businesses.
• The Welsh Government will not withdraw funding from settings that cannot operate due to public health advice.
• The potential closure of colleges and universities was addressed.
• Institutions are moving towards online learning and support for students.
• Colleges and universities will remain open for vulnerable students and those who cannot go home.
• Student maintenance payments and education maintenance allowance will continue as normal.
• The Welsh Government is in regular conversation with institutions to ensure support for students.
• Emergency legislation will provide Welsh Ministers with additional powers.
• Powers to temporarily close or keep open educational institutions and childcare premises.
• Flexibility to direct resources and staff to different institutions.
• Ability to relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings and nutritional standards for school food.
• These powers aim to ensure continuity and support during the pandemic",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

955,"<summary>

* The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on education in Wales, including school closures, support for vulnerable children, and the cancellation of summer exams.
* Schools will close for statutory education but will remain open to support children of key workers and vulnerable children.
* Digital tools and platforms will be used to support distance learning.
* Special provisions will be made for children on free school meals and those with additional learning needs.
* The Welsh Government will ensure continuity of funding for childcare and youth services.
* The committee addressed concerns about the cancellation of summer exams and the continuity of education for higher and further education institutions.
* Year 11 and Year 13 students will be awarded grades based on a range of assessments.
* Universities and colleges are moving towards online learning and maintaining support for vulnerable students.
* Student maintenance payments and education maintenance allowance (EMA) will continue as normal.
* Emergency legislation will grant Welsh Ministers powers to close or direct educational institutions and ensure the continuity of education.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"

959,"<summary>
* The meeting was focused on the functional design of a new remote control.
* The Project Manager outlined the agenda and time constraints.
* The minutes from the previous meeting were reviewed and accepted.
* New project requirements were introduced, including the need for the remote to be T_V_ specific and incorporate the corporate image.
* Marketing Presentation:
* Emphasized the need to sell four million units.
* Highlighted user dissatisfaction with current remote controls.
* Suggested focusing on a streamlined, attractive design.
* Discussed the potential for speech recognition technology.
* User Interface Presentation:
* Agreed with the need for a streamlined design.
* Proposed eliminating extraneous functions.
* Suggested focusing on essential functions like channel and volume control.
* Introduced the idea of a menu function for on-screen navigation.
* Industrial Designer Presentation:
* Discussed the basic components needed for the remote.
* Emphasized the need for cost-effective, mass-produced design.
* Raised concerns about the feasibility of including advanced features like speech recognition.
* Suggested the remote should be disposable rather than repairable.
* Discussion on Power Source:
* Considered the use of rechargeable internal batteries.
* Discussed the potential for a docking station to keep the remote in place.
* Rejected the idea of solar power due to cost and practicality.
* Agreed to research the cost implications further.
* Target Market:
* Debated whether to focus on younger, tech-savvy users.
* Considered the purchasing habits of different age groups.
* Discussed the possibility of selling the remote through T_V_ manufacturers.
* Agreed on the importance of making the remote appealing to early adopters.
* Final Decisions on Functions:
* Agreed on essential functions: power, channel, volume, enter key, and number keys.
* Emphasized the need for big, user-friendly buttons.
* Agreed to make the design attractive and easy to use.
* Decided to avoid overly complex features.
* Action Items:
* Kate to research components.
* Steph to focus on user interface design.
* Marketing to continue trend-watching.
* Each team member to work with their coach for further development.
* Meeting Conclusion:
* Agreed on the next steps and individual assignments.
* Planned to reconvene after further research and individual work.
* Emphasized the importance of meeting the new project requirements.
* Ended",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
960,"<summary>
• The group discussed the general support for the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.

column2: •• Alastair Birch emphasized the importance of upholding children's rights under the UNCRC.
•• Sally Jenkins highlighted the need for clarity in legislation for children, parents, and professionals.
•• The Bill is seen as a natural progression in how children are cared for in Wales.
•• Huw David stressed the importance of safeguarding and the cultural shift in treating children.

column1: • Evidence on the harm of physical punishment was discussed.

column2: •• Sally Jenkins cited global research indicating physical punishment is harmful to children.
•• The voice of the child is clear that physical punishment is emotionally damaging.
•• Physical punishment is part of a continuum that can lead to more severe abuse.
•• The Bill aims to provide clarity and prevent potential pathways to more serious abuse.

column1: • The role of local authorities in the implementation of the Bill was examined.

column2: •• Local authorities have been involved in discussions and workshops for over two years.
•• There is a need for greater clarity around the definition of corporal punishment.
•• Implementation will require collaboration with Welsh Government and other agencies.
•• Awareness-raising campaigns and support for parents are crucial.

column1: • Potential unintended consequences of the Bill were considered.

column2: •• Huw David emphasized the need for careful implementation and adequate resources.
•• The Bill should not criminalize parents but protect children from harm.
•• There is a need for investment in early intervention and prevention services.
•• The Bill could increase focus on the UNCRC and the voice of the child.

column1: • The impact on social services and other local authority services was discussed.

column2: •• Sally Jenkins noted that many referrals to social services result in no further action.
•• The Bill is not expected to significantly increase the number of referrals.
•• Social services aim for short-term intervention and support for families.
•• There is a need for additional resources for out-of-hours services.

column1: • The role of education professionals in supporting the Bill's implementation was highlighted.

column2: •• Training and awareness-raising for teachers and staff are essential.
•• Schools play a key role in providing support and safeguarding children.
•• The duty to report significant harm will remain unchanged.
•• Investment in family support services within schools is important.

column1: • The importance of awareness-raising campaigns was emphasized.

column2: •• Campaigns should involve education, social care, and preventative services.
•• Welsh Government and the National Assembly should lead these efforts.
•• Learning",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

963,"<summary>
* The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.

column2: * Witnesses included Sally Jenkins, Alastair Birch, and Councillor Huw David.
* The Bill aims to clarify the law regarding physical punishment of children.
* The current law is seen as ineffective and unclear.

column1: * Alastair Birch emphasized the importance of upholding children's rights under the UNCRC.

column2: * Articles 3, 4, 12, and 37 focus on the best interests and voices of children.
* Safeguarding environments like schools and colleges is crucial.
* The Bill aligns with the Rights of Children and Young Persons (Wales) Measure 2011.

column1: * Sally Jenkins highlighted the long-standing support for the Bill from social services.

column2: * The Bill would bring clarity for children, parents, and professionals.
* Physical punishment is rare but harmful and demeaning to children.
* The Bill represents a natural progression in child care and nurturing.

column1: * The committee discussed the potential harm of physical punishment.

column2: * Evidence suggests physical punishment is emotionally damaging.
* It can lead to more serious physical or sexual abuse.
* The Bill aims to protect children's physical integrity.

column1: * The need for greater clarity around corporal punishment was debated.

column2: * Simplicity in the Bill is important, as emphasized by the children's commissioner.
* Detailed discussions during the implementation phase are necessary.
* Full involvement of local authorities in implementation is crucial.

column1: * Huw David stressed the importance of awareness-raising campaigns.

column2: * Families, carers, and parents need to be taken along on this journey.
* Support for parents struggling with parenting should be universally available.
* Local authorities are already involved in exploring the Bill's implications.

column1: * The role of local authorities in the Bill's implementation was discussed.

column2: * Local authorities have been consulted and involved in workshops.
* The impact on social services and other services like housing and education was considered.
* The Bill should not undermine existing responsibilities but enhance child protection.

column1: * The potential unintended consequences of the Bill were considered.

column2: * Proper implementation and resources are key to avoiding negative impacts.
* The Bill should not criminalize parents but protect children from harm.
* The rise in looked-after children is due to multiple factors, not just the Bill.

column1: * The importance of training and awareness in education settings was emphasized.

column2: * Teachers and professionals need to be clear about their roles.

column1: ,0,{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

* Meeting focused on technical issues and project updates.

column2: * Discussion on system crashes.

column3: * Grad B mentioned no crashes recently.
* PhD G experienced a crash in the morning.
* Professor A suggested crashes might be related to usage frequency.

column2: * Agenda and attendance.

column3: * Liz and Andreas were absent.
* Grad B had the agenda and asked for additional items.
* Professor A planned to discuss NSF ITR briefly.

column2: * Digit transcription issues.

column3: * Grad B discussed errors in digit transcription.
* Options: discard and re-read or correct transcripts.
* Consensus to correct transcripts due to low error frequency.

column2: * NSF ITR proposal.

column3: * Professor A updated on the proposal status.
* Full proposal due in April.
* Discussion on potential funding and project impact.

column2: * Naming conventions for files.

column3: * Grad B proposed uniform naming for easier sorting.
* Discussion on naming length and structure.
* Plan to reorganize file structures and naming conventions.

column2: * Transcription updates.

column3: * Postdoc F switched to channel-by-channel transcription.
* Issues with time lags and efficiency.
* Discussion on handling overlaps and backchannels.

column2: * Harmonicity detection.

column3: * PhD C working on improving harmonicity detector.
* Issues with distinguishing harmonics from other frequency peaks.
* Discussion on potential solutions and algorithms.

column2: * Handling breaths in transcription.

column3: * Postdoc F raised the issue of encoding breaths.
* Discussion on the importance of breaths for speech recognition.
* Consensus to transcribe breaths within speech chunks only.

column2: * Speech recognition vs. discourse research.

column3: * Discussion on different needs for speech recognition and discourse research.
* Importance of capturing non-communicative elements for speech recognition.
* Plan to create a master transcript for both uses.

column2: * Future steps and collaboration.

column3: * Continued work on transcription and harmonicity detection.
* Potential new hires for NSF ITR project.
* Ongoing collaboration and discussion on technical issues.

** Industrial Designer introduced two prototypes of the remote control:

column2: ** The first prototype is a basic model costing around eight Euros.

column3: ** It has a surfboard shape to encourage ""surfing"" through TV channels.
** Features include an infrared LED, on-off button, volume control, and channel browsing.
** It is designed to be user-friendly and familiar to all age groups.
** The design is conventional with no significant technological innovations.

column2: ** The second prototype is a more advanced model costing around sixteen Euros.

column3: ** It includes an LCD screen, speech recognition, and multifunctional buttons.
** The design is more sophisticated and appeals to a younger demographic.
** It has additional features like a microphone for speech recognition and a blinking LED for battery status.
** The model is over budget but offers more functionality and innovation.

column1: ** Discussion on budget constraints and design evaluation:

column2: ** The project manager emphasized the importance of staying within the budget of twelve Euros and fifty cents.

column3: ** If the design exceeds the budget, it must be redesigned.

992,"<summary>
* The project team discussed the difficulties and requirements for implementing speech recognition in new remote controls.

column2: ** The Project Manager highlighted that the remote control is for a specific television, discarding the all-in-one idea.
** Marketing research showed that 75% of users find current remote controls unattractive, and 80% are willing to pay more for better-looking designs.

column1: * Marketing emphasized the need for a user-friendly design with fewer buttons.

column2: ** 50% of users only use 10% of the buttons on their remote controls.
** Simplifying the design could reduce costs and increase profits.

column1: * The team considered the potential of speech recognition and other novel features.

column2: ** Speech recognition could enhance user experience but has challenges with noise interference.
** Other features like glow-in-the-dark material and a whistle function for locating the remote were discussed.

column1: * The User Interface Designer focused on making the remote trendy and ergonomic.

column2: ** The design should appeal to the 25-35 age group, the main buyers of TVs.
** The remote should have an organic shape and be easy to use.

column1: * The Industrial Designer proposed integrating user feedback and practical limitations.

column2: ** Suggested a simple design with minimal buttons and programmable options.
** Emphasized the need for durable materials to withstand frequent use.

column1: * The team debated the feasibility of incorporating a TFT or LCD screen.

column2: ** Concerns were raised about the fragility and cost of these screens.
** Decided to prioritize speech recognition and other simpler features.

column1: * The Project Manager noted the need to exclude teletext and incorporate corporate colors and slogans.

column2: ** The remote should align with the company's branding, using yellow and the slogan ""We put the fashion in electronics.""
** The team discussed how to integrate these elements without compromising design.

column1: * Safety and durability were highlighted as important considerations.

column2: ** The remote should be made of child-safe materials.
** A rubbery, durable material was suggested to make the remote more resilient.

column1: * The team concluded with a plan to finalize the design and integrate all feedback.

column2: ** Reports and documents were to be saved in the project documents folder.
** The Project Manager would forward any additional information to the team.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: 994,"<summary>
• The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed school improvement and raising standards with Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Steve Davies, director of education.
• The OECD's involvement in Welsh education was highlighted, with a review expected to be published in March.
• The School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013's powers were discussed, with mixed usage by local authorities.
• The national evaluation and improvement resource was emphasized as crucial for self-evaluation and raising school standards.
• The importance of Estyn's role in the inspection process was noted.
• Schools causing concern were identified through various systems, including school categorisation and Estyn inspection reports.
• The need for early identification of struggling schools was stressed.
• A new multi-agency approach was introduced to support schools causing concern.
• The importance of sustainable improvement in schools was highlighted.
• The role of local authorities and consortia in school intervention was discussed.
• The role and effectiveness of regional consortia were examined.
• The Minister's change of opinion on the necessity of consortia was noted.
• Differences in the operation of consortia, such as ERW, were discussed.
• The potential withdrawal of Neath Port Talbot from ERW was addressed.
• The strategic delivery group's role in reviewing the middle tier was highlighted.
• The challenges of measuring long-term trends in educational attainment were discussed.
• Changes in performance measures were acknowledged as necessary but challenging.
• The importance of using data intelligently was emphasized.
• The role of Estyn and the WLGA in training on data usage was noted.
• The need for a broader suite of performance measures was highlighted.
• The attainment gap between pupils eligible for free school meals and their peers was discussed.
• The persistence of the attainment gap despite significant investment was acknowledged.
• Progress in some areas, such as PISA scores, was noted.
• The need for early intervention to address the attainment gap was emphasized.
• The underachievement of minority ethnic learners was also discussed.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
995,"<summary>
• Kirsty Williams AM discussed the involvement of the OECD in the Welsh Government's school improvement journey.
• The OECD conducted a rapid review at the beginning of the Assembly term.
• The feedback informed the national mission for Welsh education.
• A follow-up review was conducted, with a report expected in March.
• The OECD's role includes external verification and self-evaluation of the system.
• The use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013 was examined.
• Local authorities have extensive powers of intervention in schools.
• There is a mixed picture of how these powers are used across different authorities.
• Examples of successful interventions include schools in Flintshire and Torfaen.
• The Welsh Government encourages proactive use of these powers by local authorities.
• The national evaluation and improvement resource was discussed.
• It aims to develop robust self-evaluation skills within the school system.
• The resource is being developed with input from the OECD, middle tier, and practitioners.
• Estyn plays a critical role in the development and support of the resource.
• The resource will be introduced across the system in September 2020.
• The identification and support of schools causing concern were addressed.
• The school categorisation system is the primary tool for identifying schools needing support.
• Estyn's inspection reports and local intelligence also play a role.
• A new multi-agency approach is being piloted to support schools causing concern.
• The approach includes local authorities, regional consortia, Estyn, and Welsh Government.
• The role and effectiveness of regional consortia were evaluated.
• The Minister initially supported abolishing consortia but now sees their value.
• There is variation in the performance of different consortia.
• The strategic delivery group, chaired by Professor Dylan Jones, aims to clarify roles and responsibilities.
• Neath Port Talbot's potential withdrawal from ERW raises concerns about support for their schools.
• The challenge of closing the attainment gap between pupils eligible for free school meals and others was discussed.
• Despite significant investment, the attainment gap persists.
• PISA results show some progress in overcoming disadvantage.
• The focus needs to be on early intervention, starting from nursery and early education.
• Minority ethnic learners also face challenges, with some groups achieving while others do not.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
996,"<summary>

• The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed various aspects of school improvement and raising standards with Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Steve Davies, director of education.

column2: • Topics included the involvement of the OECD in Welsh education, the use of powers under the School Standards and Organisation (Wales) Act 2013, and the national evaluation and improvement resource.

column1: • The committee explored the effectiveness of regional consortia in school improvement, with a focus on the challenges faced by ERW and the potential withdrawal of Neath Port Talbot from regional working.

column2: • Discussions highlighted the importance of a consistent approach across consortia and the role of the strategic delivery group chaired by Professor Dylan Jones.

column1: • The Minister emphasized the need for a broader range of performance measures to assess school effectiveness, moving away from narrow indicators like level 2 plus.

column2: • The interim measures currently in place are being evaluated, with a focus on aligning them with the new curriculum and ensuring they drive the right behaviors in schools.

column1: • The committee addressed the persistent issue of the attainment gap between pupils eligible for free school meals and their peers, despite significant investment through the pupil development grant.

column2: • The Minister acknowledged progress in some areas but stressed the need for early intervention to make a lasting impact on disadvantaged learners.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
